HEADLINE: Citing an Economic Slump, Verizon Lays Off 2,700 Workers 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
Verizon Communications, the region's largest telephone company, laid off 2,700 workers in New York and New Jersey yesterday. 
 The workers make up 10 percent of the company's front-line repair and installation work force. 
 Yesterday's cuts were the first major layoffs by Verizon in New York, said John Bonomo, a Verizon spokesman. Verizon has 46,000 employees in New York State, including those in its wireless division. 
Verizon has warned of big layoffs for months. The company announced in May that it would lay off 2,100 workers, but instead it offered workers retirement and buyout packages.
Then, in October, Verizon announced that it might lay off 3,800 workers. The company continued to negotiate with union officials over new contracts for workers and called the layoffs a last resort.
But layoffs came yesterday, effective immediately, to 2,352 workers in New York State and 361 workers in New Jersey.
Mr. Bonomo called the cuts unavoidable in a telecommunications industry that is in an economic slump. Verizon is losing customers and faces increased competition from cellular phones and cable modem services, he said.
"This is a difficult step to take, but one that is necessary if we are to ensure a healthy and successful company in the future," he said. "Verizon is faced with a difficult economy, tough competition and a changing industry where many customers are using other technologies in place of our more traditional wire line services."
Union officials had argued that Verizon could avoid layoffs by bringing back work it had contracted to outside companies.
Bob Master, a spokesman for the Communications Workers of America, called the layoffs "devastating for workers and their families." 
"Customers are going to have serious problems with their service," he said. "They'll have more problems on the line and longer waits for repairs."
Mr. Bonomo dismissed the notion that service would decline.
The Communications Workers of America represents about 19,000 Verizon workers in New York, and other telecommunications workers in New York, New Jersey and parts of New England. 
The two sides have waged fierce publicity campaigns over the layoffs, competing for public support through advertisements.
Mr. Master blamed Verizon for losing money on bad investments and then cutting jobs to show Wall Street that it was trimming costs.
Verizon reported third-quarter earnings of $4.4 billion. Mr. Master accused the company of continuing to pay bloated salaries to its top executives. Mr. Bonomo responded that Verizon's profits in the New York market had been meager.
Verizon officials have criticized the union for overspending on advertisements to bring attention to union leadership, instead of concentrating its efforts on negotiating a solution for its rank-and-file workers.
Verizon says that it offered union officials a deal earlier this year that would have avoided the layoffs, a contract that offered a wage freeze and a shortened workweek. Union officials rejected it. Mr. Master said the offer "wasn't even worth talking about."

HEADLINE: Carriage Drivers Say Horses Are in Danger of Being Evicted 

BYLINE:  By CECILIA M. VEGA 

 BODY:
There are not a lot of opportunities for out-of-work horses during the holidays in New York City.
 Passing as one of Santa's reindeer is a long shot, and it would be a tough squeeze in a Nativity scene. 
 So the drivers in top hats who guide 30 of the horse-drawn carriages in and around Central Park are especially nervous because the city-owned building where the horses are stabled will probably be sold at the end of the year. That means they have to find a new stable, or, they say, everyone is out of a job. 
"Unfortunately, New York City doesn't have a whole lot of stable space, and there are not a whole lot of co-ops where you can just take these as pets," said Richard Rosenthal, a lawyer representing the drivers.
For the past two years, Shamrock Stables has housed a third of the city's carriage horses in a building on West 45th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues. Mr. Rosenthal said Shamrock's owner learned last week that the building would be sold to make space for a movie and television studio complex and that the month-to-month lease he has with the city would be canceled at the end of the month.
At a news conference at the stables yesterday, Mr. Rosenthal, who rode in on a horse-drawn carriage, said he would seek an injunction next week to prevent the eviction.
"They're part of the character and culture of this city," he said, standing in the stable surrounded by horses nibbling on hay meant for decoration. "Take a look at any movie with New York in it. They all show horses in Central Park."
Michael Sherman, a spokesman for the city's Economic Development Corporation, said that the property sale is expected to close sometime in the coming weeks and that his office is trying to help find a new space for the horses.
"We have been working behind the scenes to try to find them a location," he said. "It's very hard to find suitable stable locations in Manhattan."
He also said the city gave the stable owner more than a week's notice that the lease would expire, but he did not know exactly how much notice had been given.
Mr. Rosenthal said he had not been told the city would help find the horses a new home.
The 45th Street building was originally meant to house Police Department patrol horses, but instead the city moved the carriage horses there two years ago from a stable near Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive because of construction in the area, Mr. Rosenthal said.
Neither Shamrock's owner nor the drivers know what will happen to the horses or the carriages come January. Some of the horses belong to owners who hire the drivers, and others are owned by the drivers themselves.
The thought of having to pack up those horses and leave the stable, especially during the holidays, has worried everyone at Shamrock.
"I don't think the mayor wants 30 more people in the unemployment line," a carriage driver, Brendan McMahon, said. "At this time of year it's like a death sentence hanging over our heads."

GRAPHIC: Photo: If carriage horses like Maggie, at Shamrock Stables on West 45th Street, cannot find a new home in Manhattan by the end of the month, they may have to find a new line of work. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Wall Street Firms Ready To Pay $1 Billion in Fines
The nation's biggest brokerage firms have agreed to pay almost $1 billion in fines to end investigations into whether they issued misleading stock recommendations and handed out hot new shares to curry favor with executives during the stock boom of the 1990's, people involved in the negotiations said.
 As part of the settlement, which could be announced today, the firms will pay an additional $500 million over five years to buy stock research from independent analysts and distribute it to investors. Page A1. 

S.E.C. Selection Process Faulted
The Securities and Exchange Commission under Harvey L. Pitt was described as dysfunctional by a federal report examining its selection of an accounting oversight board. A1.

Barnes & Noble Lowers Forecast
Barnes & Noble, the largest bookseller in the country, said that it would miss its previous forecasts for the holiday shopping season because of disappointing sales of books and video games, providing the latest ominous signs for both businesses this year. Shares of Barnes & Noble fell $3.91, to $17.46 a share, reaching a low for the year. C7.

Jury Says Wal-Mart Broke Pay Laws
A jury in Oregon found Wal-Mart guilty of forcing its employees to work unpaid overtime in the first of 40 such suits to go to trial. A26.

Court Orders End to Oil Strike
Venezuela's Supreme Court ordered the state oil company, hobbled by a strike that has choked exports, to restart operations. A14.

Bush Weighs Monitoring of Internet
The Bush administration is planning to propose requiring Internet service providers to help build a centralized system to enable broad monitoring of the Internet and, potentially, surveillance of its users. A22.

Fed Chief Discusses Deflation
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, warned that deflation, a general decline in prices, could be more damaging to economic growth than inflation. C2.

Memos Cast Shadow on Drug Plan
Top executives at Warner-Lambert, which has since been acquired by Pfizer, approved a detailed plan by subordinates to market epilepsy medicine, for unapproved uses, according to internal memorandums. C2.

Japan Sees Little Growth Next Year
The Japanese government said that it expected the economy to grow about 0.6 percent in the fiscal year beginning April 1. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, left, eager to fend off another recession and bolster his waning popularity, has proposed tax cuts worth $19.9 billion and will probably step up government spending. World Business, Section W.

Dow Closes Lower for a Third Day
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 82.55 points, to close at 8,364.80, for a three-day loss of 262 points. The Nasdaq index lost 7.41 points, to 1,354.10. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 6.87 points, to 884.25. C7.

A stabilizing job market and higher stock prices helped push up a crucial measure of economic activity in November, the Conference Board reported. In addition, the Labor Department said that new jobless claims dropped last week, but remain high. C14.

NASD Adjusts Disclosure Rule
NASD said that it had revised its proposed rule covering conflict of interest disclosures by research analysts to remove any requirement that analysts not talk to reporters. C2.

S.E.C. Investigating Halliburton
The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a formal investigation into Halliburton's disclosure and accounting of cost overruns on engineering and construction jobs, the company said. Halliburton said it was cooperating with the agency. C4.

HEADLINE: 2 Rivals Vying for Control of Poland's Steel Group 

BYLINE:  By PETER S. GREEN 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
With its huge, smoke-spewing mills, vast work force and billions of dollars in debt, Poland's state-owned steel conglomerate, Polskie Huty Stali, seems an unlikely industrial prize, a leftover dinosaur at the tail end of Central Europe's post-Communist privatization.
 But with the slimmed-down, privatized Western European steel industry in surprisingly robust health, and with Poland set to join the common market of the wealthy European Union in 2004, the company, known as PHS, is poised to become the object of a bidding war by two of the most successful steel makers in Europe: the United States Steel Corporation, based in Pittsburgh, and the sprawling empire of the entrepreneur Lakshmi N. Mittal, based in London. 
 The Polish government is expected to set terms for the sale of a 51 percent stake in PHS, a company that accounts for 70 percent of the Polish steel market and has annual revenues of around 7 billion zlotys ($1.8 billion).
Luc Pez, an analyst at ING Bank in Paris, estimated that all of PHS was worth about $1.3 billion, given its towering debts. But the government is requiring that the new owner invest at least $350 million in new equipment, Mr. Pez said, so that will push the cash price for control of the company down to about $300 million. 
Representatives of both interested buyers have been visiting the mills to gauge their fair value.
"PHS would be an important part of our strategy in Eastern Europe," said Annanya Sarin, director of communications for Mr. Mittal. Mr. Mittal's two chief companies -- the privately held LNM Holdings, which will be bidding for PHS, and Ispat International, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange -- own mills in the Czech Republic, Romania and Kazakhstan, as well as in Western Europe and the United States.
John Goodish, president of U.S. Steel Kosice, a factory that the American steel maker bought three years ago in Slovakia and that is now United States Steel's only profitable major unit, said United States Steel was equally determined to win PHS's five mills.
"Polish mills would put us into whole new product lines," Mr. Goodish said.
Still, the big European steel makers Arcelor and ThyssenKrupp have canceled plans to bid.
And last week, as the European Union approved Poland's bid for membership, Poland tentatively agreed to reduce its production of finished steel products by 690,000 tons, giving Western Europe's steel industry some protection against cheap Polish imports. The move had been expected, and Mr. Pez said it should not affect the PHS sale.
Since the dawn of the microchip age, steel has been a tough industry in which to make a profit.
In Europe, governments and unions bent on preserving jobs made mills notoriously inefficient. Billions of dollars subsidized money-losing steel mills in the last quarter-century, until privatizations and mergers in the last few years returned Europe's mills to profitability.
In the United States, steel makers have been hobbled by union work rules, imports from countries with cheap labor and the huge legacy costs of cleaning up pollution and paying pensions to armies of laid-off workers.
Eastern Europe's surviving state-owned mills are an attractive proposition to producers seeking a low-cost place to make steel for either Eastern Europe's own growing markets or for export to Western Europe when Poland and seven other post-Communist countries join the European Union in 2004.
"They have a very healthy steel market in Poland, forecast to grow quite healthily because accession will give a boost to the economy," said Harvey Gordon, managing director of London-based EuroStrategy Consultants, which examined the Polish steel industry for the European Commission. Poland produces lots of automobiles and consumer durables like refrigerators and ovens, he said, "so there is an enormous scope for an indigenous steel industry."
United States Steel and Mr. Mittal's companies would probably want to use Poland as a base for westward exports as well as for selling steel in Poland, Mr. Gordon added.
First, however, the Polish mills will have to revamp, at a time when the country's economy is still troubled. 
Though Poland's economy is expected to pick up a bit in 2003, it has been faltering in the last three years. As sales of new cars fell 49 percent from 1999 to 2001, major carmakers like Daewoo and Fiat scaled back production in the country. Revenues at shipyards, usually another strong market for Polish steel, dropped 12 percent in local currency terms last year. Even though demand should remain stable, it is not expected to rise.
Inflation and a stubbornly unreformed agricultural sector have pushed down the value of the Polish currency, further depressing consumer demand at home.
Steel imports have risen sharply, accounting for about 40 percent of domestic steel consumption in 2001. And Poland's steel exports have dropped in trade mostly with European Union countries, according to the Metallurgical Chamber of Industry and Commerce, based in Katowice, Poland.
The Polish steel industry has shrunk a lot since the days when it helped feed the illusions of the Soviet empire. From 1992 to 1998, production capacity was cut to 13 million tons a year from 20 million tons, and the industry's work force fell to 31,600 at the end of 2001 from 147,000 in 1990, according to Bank Przemyslowo-Handlowy PBK in Cracow.
The industry is $1.25 billion in debt and is unable to compete, even in its home market, with foreign producers on price, quality or product range.
In October, Poland's center-left government announced a plan to cut the jobs of 6,000 more steelworkers, cut production 10 percent by 2006 and earmark 2.4 billion zlotys ($617 million) to help retire PHS's debt.
The five mills that make up PHS are Huta Cedler, which is focused on wire and wire rod; Huta Florian, a zinc-coating mill; Huta Katowice, an integrated mill producing I-beams, rail and similar so-called long products; Huta Sendzimira, which mostly makes flat and rolled steel; and Huta Czestochowa, a casting operation with a small rolling mill.
All are filled with aging machinery, some from the 1950's, and all are far behind their Western competitors in terms of quality. Last year alone, the two largest, Sendzimira and Katowice, lost more than 1 billion zlotys ($257 million) combined, and Sendzimira alone has debts of at least 1.5 billion zlotys.
Without investment, the Polish mills are unlikely to make a profit. Up to half of the production at some mills, including Sendzimira, is of low-margin unfinished products.
Mr. Goodish says his company, United States Steel, knows just what it would take to make PHS profitable. "Poland needs some dramatic restructuring," he said. "That's going to be a major challenge, to bring equipment up to today's standards and revamp the commercial, sales and marketing side."
Layoffs and investment will be needed, he said, but the most important factor will be the management practices that have made the Kosice plant such a success.
Mr. Mittal's companies would not divulge their plans for PHS.
Some experts wondered whether Mr. Mittal would be able to swallow the cost of acquiring and revamping PHS because this year he has bought both the Sidex steel mill in Romania and the Nova Hut mill in the Czech Republic. According to Ms. Sarin, Mr. Mittal's spokeswoman, money is not a problem for LNM. She said its profits were close to 25 percent of revenue in 2001.
Whoever buys the mills will have to move fast, said Michal Mierzwa, an analyst at Erste Securities Poland in Warsaw.
"Too many years were wasted in the 90's," Mr. Mierzwa said. "This is one of the last sectors to be privatized, and it is getting late."

HEADLINE: DIVISIVE WORDS: THE WHITE HOUSE; 
Anger Raises Concern About Bush Run in '04

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
The furor over Senator Trent Lott has ignited anger and unease at the White House in part because of the danger that it could derail President Bush's efforts to win over black and Hispanic voters and attract more of the white suburban moderates who are crucial to Mr. Bush's re-election in 2004, strategists in both parties say.
 Since his first race for governor of Texas in 1994, Mr. Bush has sought to reach out to minority voters, and since winning the White House, he has been more aggressive on that front than previous Republican presidents, driven both by political imperative and what his supporters say is a sincere belief in the need for racial reconciliation. 
 But strategists from both parties and independent analysts said Mr. Lott's approving statements about Strom Thurmond's run for the presidency in 1948 on a segregationist platform have already set back the president's efforts to bring more minority voters into his party without alienating its overwhelmingly white and largely conservative base.
The fallout from the controversy could have profound effects not just on Mr. Bush's re-election prospects but also on the Republican Party's efforts to build a broader coalition for years to come. 
Political advisers to Mr. Bush said simple arithmetic showed that the party could not afford to falter in its efforts to win a bigger share of the minority vote, especially among Hispanics, whose numbers are growing far faster than the electorate as a whole.
If the Republican ticket were to take the same percentages of the Hispanic, black and white vote in 2004 as it did in 2000, said Matthew Dowd, the White House's pollster, it would lose the popular vote by three million ballots and the Electoral College. In 2000, Mr. Bush received 544,000 fewer votes than Al Gore but won the Electoral College.
"This is not only something the president cares a lot about, but also something that's a political necessity for Republicans," Mr. Dowd said.
The political calculation goes beyond the controversy's effect on minority voters. The crucial political question now, strategists in both parties say, is whether Mr. Bush's condemnation last week of Mr. Lott's statements is enough to assure moderate white voters -- especially suburban women for whom racial tolerance is an important component of party identity -- that Republicans would no longer tolerate racism.
"Observing Bush's campaigns in Texas over the years, he talked very effectively about issues that motivated nontraditional Republican voters, black and Hispanic, to take a first look at the G.O.P.," said Scott Reed, a Republican consultant. "But the biggest Achilles' heel of the Lott episode is the damage it could do to our suburban women, the soccer mom moderate Republicans and independent women."
Recent Republican presidents have had consistent political trouble navigating racial issues. Each has taken steps under the pressure of campaigns that many political analysts interpreted as thinly veiled efforts to play the race card with conservative white voters.
Ronald Reagan kicked off his 1980 campaign in Philadelphia, Miss., and invoked "states rights," a phrase many civil rights groups consider code for segregation. The current president's father invoked Willie Horton, a black man who raped a woman while on a weekend furlough from a murder sentence, to appeal to white voters in his race against Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts in 1988. 
At the time of his greatest political peril in the 2000 Republican primaries, the current President Bush appeared in South Carolina at Bob Jones University, which has a history of banning interracial dating.
Mr. Bush's African-American supporters said he feels strongly about helping to erase racial divisions regardless of the political implications.
Mr. Bush is "secure in making certain he's the president of all Americans and making sure that all Americans have a seat at the table," said the Rev. Kirbyjon Caldwell, pastor of the Windsor Village United Methodist Church in Houston.
Mr. Bush has tried to address the priorities of minority voters in a way that blurs the line between the social attitudes supported by the traditional conservative Republican base and those that appeal to moderate voters. His main vehicle for straddling that line has been his "compassionate conservative" agenda, which supporters say will meet the needs of minority groups but in ways that conservatives assert will be more effective than the longstanding remedies prescribed by liberals. 
Mr. Bush has also relied heavily on symbolism, nowhere more so than at the 2000 Republican convention in Philadelphia. The convention featured prominent African-American Republicans like Colin L. Powell as speakers, but also gave time to gospel choirs, black preachers and other representatives of minority groups -- a sharp contrast to the audience of delegates, only 4 percent of whom identified themselves as black.
Mr. Bush won only about 8 percent of the black vote in the 2000 race, down from the 12 percent for Bob Dole in 1996.
Mr. Bush did better among Hispanics. He won 31 percent of the Hispanic vote in 2000, compared with Mr. Dole's 21 percent. Hispanic voters are much less politically homogenous than black voters, and it is unclear how much the renewed focus on the racial stance of the Republican Party might affect Hispanic voting patterns.
Asked about Mr. Bush's record in helping minority groups, his spokesman, Ari Fleischer, responded this week with a lengthy list of accomplishments, from last year's education bill to his advocacy of church-based social welfare programs.
"I think when you take a look at the administration's record in helping minorities, it's very broad-based and helpful," Mr. Fleischer said. "He's proud to be a different kind of Republican in that sense and to offer these proposals."
But Mr. Bush's record since taking office has done little to help him with liberal civil rights groups. In a report this week, People for the American Way, a liberal advocacy group, said there was a "yawning gap between the president's public pronouncements on equal rights and the ongoing record of his administration and Republican party leaders."
Other groups that track racial issues said Mr. Bush's record on judicial appointments, his selection of John Ashcroft as attorney general and his economic focus on tax cuts had done nothing to help win black support.
"The fact of the matter is that the administration's agenda is not by and large one that African-Americans find all that attractive," said David Bositis, senior political analyst at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a liberal-leaning research organization.

HEADLINE: DIVISIVE WORDS: THE PARTIES; 
National G.O.P. Members Weigh Against Lott in Poll

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY and JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
By more than two to one, members of the Republican National Committee say that Trent Lott should step down as the Senate Republican leader, warning that he is damaging the party's image and undermining its efforts to appeal to minorities, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.
 In a sign of Mr. Lott's apparently tenuous situation, only 16 percent of the members of the national committee -- the organizational backbone of the party, made up of elected and appointed officials nationwide -- said they believed that Mr. Lott would survive the cascade of questions about his views on segregation. Mr. Lott, of Mississippi, said two weeks ago that the nation would be better off if Senator Strom Thurmond, who ran for president in 1948 on a platform that advocated segregation, had been elected. 
 At the same time, a Times/CBS News poll of Democratic National Committee members found that Democrats were glum about their performance in the November elections -- and worried about the next round. More than 50 percent of the committee members said it would be somewhat difficult or very difficult to unseat President Bush in 2004 in their states. By contrast, nearly two-thirds of the Republican committee members said they thought Mr. Bush faced a very easy or somewhat easy task in winning re-election in their states. 
To recapture the White House, the Democratic committee members said, their party needed to move to the center. But they also said the party's candidate in 2004 should press to roll back the Bush tax cuts, campaign for stricter gun control laws and challenge Mr. Bush on the war in Iraq and measures to increase surveillance of ordinary Americans, according to the poll.
The Times/CBS News polls of the two political committees pointed to one unexpected confluence of views: The perception that Al Gore would have been a weak candidate had he decided to run in 2004. In interviews conducted mostly before Mr. Gore announced on Sunday that he would not run, 43 percent of Republicans said they hoped the Democrats would choose Mr. Gore at their convention 2004, presumably because they believed he would be defeated. And 42 percent of Democrats said they hoped Mr. Gore would not run.
Just 17 percent of Democrats questioned before Mr. Gore's announcement said that Mr. Gore was their preferred presidential candidate, compared with 19 percent who named Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts.
The two polls of the members of the Republican and Democratic national committees -- the most active partisans in the nation -- were conducted by telephone and fax from December 9 to 18.
Among Democrats, 313 of the 440 committee members were interviewed, while 128 of the 165 Republican committee members participated in the survey. Each poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points. And 97 Republican committee members were reinterviewed regarding Mr. Lott. The margin of error for that subgroup is plus or minus six percentage points.
The polls were conducted in what is typically a sleepy period in politics -- the weeks between Election Day and New Year's Day. But this season has given committee members plenty to talk about. For Democrats, it was Mr. Gore's exit from the presidential race, and the struggle by other candidates to take advantage of his departure. For Republicans, it was the battle over Mr. Lott, who has been in line to become the Senate majority leader in new Senate.
In the poll, 45 percent of Republicans said he should not be the party's leader, compared with 20 percent who said he should be. Thirty-six percent said they had no opinion. Nearly half of the committee members said they believed it would be bad for the party if Mr. Lott continued as its leader. But an overwhelming number said Mr. Bush should stay out of the fight, allowing the Senate to deal with its own difficulties.
"Trent Lott should step down," Lynn Windel, a Republican committee member from Oklahoma, said in a follow-up interview. "Our party has made such a concerted effort to dispel the myth that we are insensitive to minorities, especially to African-Americans, and his statement is so damaging."
But Arlene Ellis, a Republican committee member from Utah, said: "Trent Lott should continue because he has done a good job. What he said was repugnant, but he apologized."
If Mr. Lott steps aside, about one-quarter said they would like to see Bill Frist, the Tennessee senator who said today he was interested in running for Mr. Lott's post, get the job. 
Among many Democrats, the initial expectation was that Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, who was Mr. Gore's running mate in 2000, would inherit the bulk of Mr. Gore's support. But the poll of this decidedly unrepresentative group of Democrats, who tend to be more liberal than rank-and-file party members, suggested that this was not the case.
When committee members were recanvassed on the Democratic field after Mr. Gore made his announcement, Mr. Lieberman was the choice of just 2 percent, compared with Mr. Kerry, who was at the top of the field with 23 percent. 
Two other widely known Democrats who have been considering a race for president -- Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, and Tom Daschle, the departing Senate majority leader -- have apparently not stirred much enthusiasm among this class of Democratic activists. Five percent named Mr. Gephardt, while just 2 percent named Mr. Daschle.
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont was named by 4 percent of the respondents. Another likely Democratic candidate, Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, was the choice of 8 percent.
If there was a scattering of opinion about 2004, there was something approaching a consensus about the presidential contest of 2008: Forty-four percent of the Democratic committee members said they expected Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York to run for president then.
Members of both party committees say the economy will be a crucial issue in the 2004 campaign. But Republicans were much more likely to say that the war with Iraq and terror would also be a decisive issue in the race; nearly 9 of 10 Republicans said they believed Democrats would be vulnerable on each of these issues.
Even in the midst of the turmoil involving Mr. Lott, Republican leaders are much more optimistic about the presidential election and say the party should stay the course. Nearly 6 of 10 Republican members described themselves and their party as conservative. And in contrast to the Democrats, Republicans said the party should oppose gun control and champion limits on access to abortion. 
Among Democrats, most committee members said they were generally satisfied with the quality of their presidential candidates, and notwithstanding the setbacks of the last election, 74 percent said they believed that Terry McAuliffe should remain the party's political chairman. 
But there is abundant evidence that the Democratic Party is confused about where it should go. More than one-quarter said the party should position itself more to the left on issues in the coming year, while nearly 50 percent said it needed to be "more moderate." About 70 percent described the Democratic Party as moderate on most issues.
Yet on a variety of subjects that are likely to be prominent in a presidential campaign, the Democrats wanted their candidates to stake out positions on the left side of the political spectrum. 
In addition to opposing Mr. Bush's tax cuts and pushing for stricter gun control, Democrats said their nominee should oppose drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and opt for protecting the environment over producing energy. They also said the party should oppose any effort by the federal government to monitor telephone calls and e-mail of ordinary citizens as part of its anti-terrorism efforts.

How the Survey Was Conducted
The surveys of members of the Democratic National Committee and the Republican National Committee were conducted by The New York Times/CBS News on Dec. 9 to 18, mainly by telephone but also by fax if an individual preferred. 
Of the 440 members of the Democratic committee, 313, or 71 percent, were reached. Of the 165 members of the Republican committee, 128, or 78 percent, were reached.
Forty-three members of the Democratic committee who initially expressed support for Al Gore as the party's 2004 presidential nominee were called back after Mr. Gore said he would not be a candidate. Ninety-seven of the Republicans were called back about Senator Trent Lott.
Members of the national committees are either elected or appointed.
The sample for each committee was weighted by sex and census region to reflect the actual composition of that committee. 
In some cases, members answered the survey through their aides.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, results based on such samples will differ by no more than five percentage points in either direction from what would have been gotten by surveying every committee member.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any opinion survey may introduce other sources of error into the poll.
The complete results for each poll are online at nytimes.com/politics.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Speech Focuses On Deflation, Not Inflation 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned tonight that deflation, a general decline in prices, could be more damaging to economic growth than inflation.
 In a speech to the Economic Club of New York, Mr. Greenspan repeated past assertions that the United States was "nowhere near" falling into deflation. But he dwelt on the subject at considerable length in a somber speech that made it clear he is worried about the possibility. 
 "It now appears that we have learned that deflation as well as inflation are in the long run monetary phenomena," Mr. Greenspan said.
"Although the U.S. economy has largely escaped any deflation since World War II, there are some well-founded reasons to presume that deflation is more of a threat to economic growth than inflation," he continued. 
In a deflationary situation, he said, a central bank has somewhat more difficulty in responding because it is impossible to reduce interest rates below zero.
The Fed's benchmark interest rate on overnight loans between banks is now at 1.25 percent, its lowest level in 41 years and within striking distance of the "zero bound."
In both his discussion of deflation and his cautious assessment of the economic outlook, Mr. Greenspan reinforced the impression among many economists that the Fed did not plan to tighten monetary policy soon.
Speaking to the same forum in which he once warned about "irrational exuberance" in the stock market, Mr. Greenspan devoted himself today in large part to discussing the stock market bubble that burst two years ago.
As he has before, Mr. Greenspan disputed critics who have complained that he should have tried to prick the bubble before it became too big by tightening monetary policy sooner.
But his tone was subdued rather than defiant. "Weaving a monetary policy path through the thickets of bubbles and deflations and their possible aftermath is not something with which modern central bankers have had much experience," he said.
He offered a cautious assessment of the current economy. Though he noted numerous signs of health, he found at least as many reasons for warning that the economy is not yet out of the doldrums: the job market is weak, manufacturing is still in a slump, Europe and Japan are weaker than the United States, and "geopolitical risk" -- the euphemism for a possible war with Iraq -- is high.
This was the second time in a month that Mr. Greenspan has devoted considerable time to the topic of deflation. His comments tonight followed a more extended speech on the subject last month by another Fed governor, Ben S. Bernanke.
In all those comments, Fed officials have insisted that they do not face a situation like that of Japan, which has had declining prices for the past several years even though the Bank of Japan's interest rates have been around zero for five years.
Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues argue that they could, if necessary, pump money into the economy by buying up longer-term Treasury bills and perhaps even foreign securities.
But at least some economists argue that the Fed ought to be acting more assertively already.
"The U.S. economy looks as though it may well be falling from the high wire of a sustainable economic recovery," wrote John H. Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, earlier this month, soon after the Fed reduced the federal funds rate to 1.25 percent from 1.75 percent.
Mr. Makin, whose writings on the subject have drawn much attention at the Fed, contends that Mr. Greenspan needs to make a fundamental shift in strategy -- away from pegging monetary policy to interest rates and toward a renewed focus on money supply and price levels.
That would in some ways be a return to the strategy invoked by Mr. Greenspan's predecessor, Paul A. Volcker, at a time when inflation was soaring at double-digit rates.
Mr. Greenspan staunchly opposes a strategy based on money supply, which is very hard to measure in a world where money takes so many forms. He also contends that basing policy on inflation targets would be too much of a restraint on flexibility.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Strikers Ordered To Resume Oil Production 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
Venezuela's Supreme Court ordered today that the state oil company, hobbled by an 18-day antigovernment strike that has choked off oil exports, must restart operations.
 The court said striking employees from Petroleos de Venezuela, one of the largest oil companies in the world and a major supplier of crude oil to the United States, must abide by "decrees and resolutions" issued by the government to reactivate oil production. The strike has almost halted oil exports and left most of the country critically short of gasoline. 
 Strike organizers, members of a broad coalition of business and labor groups stridently opposed to the left-leaning rule of President Hugo Chavez, promptly rejected the decision. 
"There is no step back," Juan Fernandez, a former financial planning manager at the oil company, said in a nationally televised news conference this evening. He argued that the government misinterpreted the court's decision and that the walkout "would not be affected." 
He added, "We are exercising the rights provided in the Bolivarian Constitution of Venezuela." 
The decision to continue the strike was expected to heighten tensions as a growing opposition movement has debilitated the economy to pressure Mr. Chavez into calling early elections or resigning. 
Earlier in the day, government officials had warned that unless strike organizers adhere to the decision there could be sanctions, including jail time. "They have a chance to rectify," said William Lara, president of the National Assembly. 
The court did not elaborate on its decision, but legal experts called it a temporary restraining order until the court decides whether the strike should be declared illegal, a ruling that could take several more days.
The decision came as some basic foods disappeared from store shelves. The oil industry, which normally produces 3 million barrels daily and exports 2.5 million, has been severely debilitated, with the government saying production had fallen 70 percent. 
The standoff between the government and its opponents has caused consternation within the Bush administration, which has been urging both sides to negotiate in good faith under the mediation of the Organization of American States. The United States normally counts on Venezuela for up to 14 percent of its imported oil. 
Today, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said the United States was "worried about the fact that the oil sector is slowly shutting down, with economic consequences for all Venezuelans, but as well as others outside of Venezuela." He said political turmoil in Venezuela could "create the possibility of violence and deep political unrest" and blamed both sides, saying they have "been acting in a rather intransigent way." 
World oil markets have been rattled by the turmoil in Venezuela, as well as the prospect of possible war with Iraq, and prices have risen to above $30 a barrel. After the Supreme Court here announced its decision, the price of a barrel dipped slightly. 
Across Venezuela, lines up to a mile long formed at gas stations as supplies dwindled and drivers tried to fill their tanks. Many stations had closed. 
"I got up at 4:30 a.m. today to pump in gas, but even at that hour there was a half-hour-long line," Jorge Figueroa, a 35-year-old cabdriver said. The station that sold him fuel limited Mr. Figueroa to a dollar's worth, though in Venezuela that still fetches more than four gallons. 
In the food markets, worried shoppers scrambled to get some hard-to-find items, like beer, milk and the corn flour used to make a traditional corn-based Christmas dish, hallacas. 
"They are still supplying us," said Luigi di Bello, 74, a butcher shop owner, "but the deliveries are very irregular. Yesterday we asked for three sides of beef, and we only received one. We do not have chicken, and do not know when its coming. I'm selling now, but tomorrow, who knows?"
The government, which at first denied the strike was having an effect, has recently acknowledged that the nosedive in production is costing the equivalent of $50 million a year. 
Mr. Chavez has responded to the stoppage by firing four executives who helped lead the strike and sending in troops to take over oil installations and tankers whose crews declared themselves in rebellion. The military has also been authorized to commandeer private tanker trucks to keep gasoline supplies moving. 
Across Caracas today, though, people expressed little faith that things would get better soon, promising a dire Christmas for a country that has seen its economy badly battered by a year of political turmoil.
"I am going to have a Christmas without a car, and without money," lamented Jose Valera, 34, an out-of- work cabdriver.

An article yesterday about the general strike in Venezuela misstated the cost of the shutdown of oil production. It is $50 million a day, not a year.

HEADLINE: Hold Your Nose and Negotiate 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
President Bush finally turns out to have a clear, forceful plan to deal with North Korea's defying the West by restarting its nuclear warhead assembly line.
 The plan is to invade Iraq. 
 The White House is trying to play down the crisis on the Korean Peninsula so that it can focus public attention on Iraq instead. But North Korea raises risks that Iraq does not -- because it already has a couple of nuclear weapons, as well as artillery and missiles that can dump nerve gas on American military bases in Asia, and Taepodong missiles that can drop nuclear warheads on Alaska and, soon, the lower 48 states. 
Washington's failure to engage North Korea has in a few months turned a minor problem (a uranium program that would take years to produce weapons) into a major crisis (the restarting of a reactor with enough plutonium to produce five additional warheads). Now the administration is allowing the situation to drift on a trajectory that conceivably could end up as another Korean war. 
"The potential threat posed by North Korea at this point is worse than anything else that we face," said James Laney, a former ambassador to South Korea. "This needs to be attended to now, at the highest levels of this administration. We need to get engaged with South Korea and figure out how to solve this diplomatically, since war would be catastrophic." 
An official with an international organization puts it this way: "North Korea scares the hell out of me. I've been there, and it petrifies me. By comparison, Iraq doesn't scare me at all." 
Perhaps it's a cheap shot to complain about North Korea policy, because the North is a country made for pundits here in the peanut gallery -- it's possible to write with withering scorn about any alternative the administration could choose. All our options regarding North Korea are hideous, and those responsible for making policy on North Korea must have committed mortal sins in previous lives for God to torture them so. To his credit, Mr. Bush has so far shown a most un-Bushian patience in reacting to North Korean provocation. 
We now find ourselves with three choices. First, we can negotiate with North Korea, which shows some signs of seeking the same kind of tentative opening to the West that China pursued in the late 1970's. The downside is that negotiation would reward bad behavior, and so Mr. Bush has ruled out this option.
Second, we can ignore North Korea, focus on Iraq and hope that economic pressure brings the Dear Leader, Kim Jong Il, to his senses. That's what Washington is trying now, but it's not working. In fact, North Korea's economy is doing better than in the 1990's, and if it were pinched, North Korea could always raise cash by, say, selling smallpox virus to Al Qaeda. And even if we succeeded in squeezing North Korea economically, we would be bothered much more than the Dear Leader as tens of thousands of Koreans died of famine and disease.
Third, we can launch a military strike on the Yongbyon reactor. But North Korea would probably respond by turning South Korea (and American bases there) into what it describes as "a sea of flames."
"I think they would respond by shooting artillery toward South Korea and missiles toward Japan," said Kongdan Oh, author of an excellent book on North Korea. 
These are three terrible choices, but a president's job is to pick the least awful. And hands down that's the first one, negotiation. One way to hide our embarrassment at talking would be to get Russia to convene an international conference, in which the Dear Leader would give up his nukes and permit inspectors, and outside countries would recognize North Korea. 
As Robert Gallucci, a former ambassador with long experience in Korea, put it: "I don't have any difficulty with diplomacy backed by force. But what I don't understand is force with no diplomacy."
Ignoring North Korea doesn't work any better than ignoring a rambunctious toddler; it just encourages further provocation. Next North Korea may begin processing fuel rods at Yongbyon, a step that could give it five to eight more warheads in about four months. 
Granted there's no good North Korea policy, but it's still worth finding a better one -- like holding our nose and negotiating -- because North Korea is already what Iraq might become tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Quo Vadis, Karl? 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
The day after the Republican triumph in the midterm elections, a jubilant Trent Lott held a celebratory press conference. "Let's roll!" he exulted. (Good taste is not one of Mr. Lott's strong points.)
 Six weeks later, we have to ask: Roll where (aside from Baghdad)? The storm that has broken over Mr. Lott's head is justified. But it may also reflect buyers' remorse: post-election polls suggest broad public unease about where Mr. Lott's party is taking us. 
It's not even clear what the Bush administration wants to accomplish now that it has full control. Until now the administration has been all politics and no policy; John J. DiIulio tells us that there is a "complete lack of a policy apparatus," that all decisions are made by the political arm. For the past two years domestic policy has consisted of little more than checking off the boxes on a wish list drawn up circa 1999.
 Meanwhile, as problems that weren't anticipated in 1999 have arisen, the administration has done as little as possible, as late as possible. 
 This has been true even in the areas where George W. Bush gets highest marks from voters. Remember that the administration repeatedly rejected calls for a homeland security agency, changing its mind only when Coleen Rowley went public with tales of intelligence failures. And a growing chorus of critics say that hardly anything real has been done to make the country safer.
 Similarly, the administration tried to prevent any independent inquiry into what went wrong on Sept. 11, and how to avoid future attacks. Then, when he could no longer avoid an inquiry, Mr. Bush did his best to undermine that inquiry's credibility by choosing Henry Kissinger, of all people, to head it.
 And then there's corporate reform. At first the administration opposed doing anything. Then, after WorldCom blew up, it agreed to a modest reform bill -- only to undermine the bill's credibility both by trying to renege on promises to provide the Securities and Exchange Commission with adequate funds, and by pressuring Harvey Pitt not to choose a real reformer to head a crucial new panel.
 Finally, there's economic policy. Fears that the economy would suffer a "jobless recovery" similar to that of the first Bush administration are no longer hypothetical: over the past year G.D.P. has grown, but employment has continued to shrink, and the risk that the U.S. will slide into a Japanese-style pattern of slow growth and deflation no longer seems remote. 
 Again, the response has been to do as little as possible. As Congress failed to agree on an extension of unemployment benefits -- which means that 800,000 families will be cut off on Dec. 28 -- the administration simply stood on the sidelines. Last weekend, too late to help those families, Mr. Bush finally spoke up in favor of an extension, but failed to say whether he favored the merely cosmetic House plan or the more serious Senate plan; those who follow the issue know that this makes all the difference.
 Will things improve now that there's a new economic team? John Snow seems to be Paul O'Neill without the charm. Stephen Friedman will probably be more vigorous than his predecessor; The Washington Post reports that one of Mr. Bush's frequent complaints about Larry Lindsey was that he didn't get enough physical exercise. But Mr. Friedman will have plenty of time to work out; it has been made clear that his duties as economic adviser don't include actually giving any economic advice. 
 Meanwhile, if the trial balloons floated by the administration are any guide to the forthcoming "stimulus" package, it will consist of more items from the checklist: making the tax cut permanent, reducing taxes on dividends. Nice stuff if you make more than $300,000 a year and have a net worth in the millions, but pretty much irrelevant to the actual problems of the economy -- except the long-run deficit, which will get even worse. It seems that Karl Rove and his merry band of Mayberry Machiavellis are still calling the shots.
 It may be that the bad few weeks the administration has just had were the result of random events. But I think the public is finally waking up to the fact that the people in the White House know a lot about gaining power, but not much about what to do with it.

HEADLINE: SEOUL MAY LOOSEN ITS TIES TO THE U.S. 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 19 

 BODY:
Roh Moo Hyun, who favors continued engagement with North Korea and greater autonomy from the United States, triumphed today in a tight presidential election. The outcome, after a campaign marked by huge anti-American demonstrations, sets South Korea and the United States on the most divergent diplomatic paths in half a century of close alliance.
 The Bush administration has spent the last three months pressing traditional friends like Japan and newer ones, like Russia and China, to put heavy pressure on North Korea to force that country to abandon a once secret nuclear weapons program and to end its missile sales to the Middle East and Pakistan. 
 Mr. Roh, a lawyer, was the candidate of the governing Millennium Democratic Party. He staked his campaign on continued engagement with North Korea, despite its threatening nuclear program and quirky, often impenetrable diplomacy. He has forcefully ruled out deadlines for compliance or economic sanctions to force his country's impoverished Communist neighbor to respect its international engagements. 
In Washington, James A. Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, told reporters that the Bush administration viewed today's election as an opportunity to work with President-elect Roh "to build an even stronger relationship between our two countries for this new century."
Mr. Kelly sought to minimize differences between Mr. Roh and the administration on North Korea and other issues, suggesting that those differences might have been unfairly magnified during the heat of the campaign.
Mr. Roh's main rival, Lee Hoi Chang, a staunchly conservative former Supreme Court justice, said during the campaign that South Korea should suspend its assistance to North Korea until it cooperated on a host of issues, from arms control to the reunion of families separated since the Korean War. 
Mr. Lee's defeat today was his second; he lost even more narrowly to the departing president, Kim Dae Jung, five years ago. Mr. Kim was barred by the Constitution from seeking a second term.
Mr. Roh's commitment to engagement with North Korea, the most important legacy of his political mentor, President Kim, has been so pronounced at times that it produced a stunning last-minute turn of events that many here thought could have cost him the election.
In the final day of campaigning on Wednesday, Mr. Roh's comments about North Korea shocked a former rival candidate and 11th-hour supporter, Chung Mong Joon, scion of the Hyundai empire, causing him to drop their painstakingly arranged alliance.
With Mr. Chung standing nearby, Mr. Roh said that "if the U.S. and North Korea start a war, we will stop it," a comment read by some as implying that South Korea would take a neutral position.
Through a spokesman, Mr. Chung denounced the speech, saying, "The United States is our ally, and our view is that the U.S. has no reason to fight North Korea."
Mr. Chung's abrupt withdrawal of support was front-page news in every daily this morning, and most commentators here assumed that it would wreck Mr. Roh's chances.
The two men forged their alliance only last month after opinion surveys consistently placed Mr. Lee as the front-runner. Mr. Roh, who had been placing third in the opinion polls, defeated Mr. Chung in a hastily arranged primary and was catapulted into the front-runner's position.
This afternoon, with his triumph not yet assured, Mr. Roh restated the assertive diplomatic position he had taken throughout the campaign.
"We must have dialogue with the North and with the U.S.," Mr. Roh, 56, told a crowd in downtown Seoul. "In this way we must make sure that the North-U.S. dispute does not escalate into a war. Now the Republic of Korea must take a central role. We cannot have a war."
South Korean politics have a long history of treacherous twists, bold dirty tricks and corresponding conspiracy theories. So theories abounded today about Mr. Chung's motives. People invoked everything from a fear of a vendetta against Hyundai if Mr. Lee won to heavy backstage lobbying by Washington, which has 37,000 troops in South Korea.
"Almost everyone expected that Chung's move would do a lot more damage," said Yim Young Soon, a political scientist at Sungkyunkwan University in Seoul. "In the end, the fact that Chung defaulted seemed to solidify Roh's support. 
"On the North Korean nuclear threat, the conventional wisdom said it would help Lee Hoi Chang, but people who live close to the demilitarized zone turned out to prefer Roh's more peaceful approach."
Hwang Yeon Yae, 53, who owns a snack shop in a working-class Seoul neighborhood, said he and his friends talked all night about "Chung's betrayal." He added: "But the people here are strongly behind Roh, and I don't think it will change many people's minds. That's Korean politics."
That judgment proved correct. Nearly complete election results showed Mr. Roh winning with 48.9 percent of the vote, compared with 46.6 percent for Mr. Lee.
If relations with North Korea were at the center of the campaign from the very start, South Korea's ties with the United States were the barely concealed subtext.
Huge crowds have massed in Seoul and other cities to protest the recent acquittal by a United States military tribunal of two American soldiers in the accidental death of two schoolgirls who were crushed by an armored vehicle in June.
The outpouring of anti-American sentiment appeared to help Mr. Roh, who advocated the withdrawal of American troops from South Korea when he was a labor lawyer in the 1980's. The protests appeared to put Mr. Lee, whose diplomatic views are close to those of the Bush administration, on the defensive.
Already assured of strong support from the young and the working class, Mr. Roh edged toward the center, repeatedly stating that his opposition to American bases had been mistaken and that he valued the alliance with the United States.
Often asked during the campaign why he had never visited the United States, though, Mr. Roh was quick to flash his diffident side, replying pointedly that he was not interested in going to Washington "just for the sake of a photo op."
Mr. Roh's challenge now is to reconcile the dual yearnings of South Korea's sophisticated and increasingly affluent younger generations for more autonomy from the United States and reduced tensions with North Korea with continued reliance on American security.
"The challenge will be between accommodating popular aspirations and meeting the demands of the Bush administration," said Scott Snyder, Korea representative of the Asia Foundation. "The new president is going to face critical decisions in three areas: redefining the relationship with the U.S., managing relations with North Korea and reorienting Korea's relations in the regional context."
Mr. Roh's victory represents a rise against tremendous odds. In South Korea's highly class-conscious society, he was born to a family of peach and chicken farmers in a ramshackle farming village now within the city of Kimhae in the southeast. 
Mr. Lee, his chief rival, is a patrician lawyer and former prime minister, and Mr. Chung one of the richest men in South Korea.
Mr. Roh was too poor to attend college. Yet he studied law for years and was admitted to the bar in 1975. Mr. Roh spent the politically turbulent early 1980's defending student and labor activists against the military government and formally joined the democracy movement in 1987, winning a seat in Parliament from Pusan in 1988.

HEADLINE: Growing New Life at Ground Zero 

BYLINE:  By Michael Ableman; Michael Ableman, author of "On Good Land: The Autobiography of an Urban Farm," is founder of the Center for Urban Agriculture.

DATELINE: GOLETA, Calif. 

 BODY:
Proposals for rebuilding the World Trade Center site were unveiled this week -- a collective vision of towering skyscrapers, amphitheaters and broad avenues. Almost completely missing from the plans, though, was an essential element -- a sense of the earth.
 And so I'd like to add something to the mix: an urban farm to be built on a portion of the trade center site. 
 Two to three acres could feed hundreds of people, provide employment for many and connect New Yorkers to the source of their food. As a generator of jobs and food, a downtown farm would demonstrate that a successful economy can have local roots -- that it need not only be global.
As with all agriculture, the foundation of the project would be soil and seeds. Communities across America could send handfuls of earth, thereby building the farm from the soil of the entire nation. Seeds could come from various parts of the world and grow into a living example of our cultural diversity.
Imagine an orchard with hundreds of varieties of apples, where people could stroll down the alleys of the trees -- enjoying the shade and witnessing the gradual cycle from flower to fruit. Consider what it would be like to walk in the middle of winter through beautifully designed glass houses filled with the earthy smells and brilliant colors of an array of fresh food and flowers. Picture outdoor gardens winding through and around the new buildings -- gardens overflowing with herbs and berries and spring, summer and fall vegetables.
A market could be built, so people working in the new buildings and living in the neighborhood could buy fresh vegetables. They could also take part -- during their breaks or at the end of the day -- in tending the soil and producing something real for themselves and their community.
There could be classes and workshops on cooking and gardening, as well as celebratory public meals, to make use of the farm's yield. Joined to other proposals for rebuilding the site, the farm would provide New Yorkers with a new version of the town square, one that balances the hardscape of buildings and pavement with fertile soil, lush plantings and fresh foods.
The farm could be installed at street level -- or, to conserve valuable real estate, it could be placed atop buildings, where it would benefit from better sun exposure and air quality. As part of this sky-high farm, greenhouses could be warmed by the spent energy from the buildings beneath them and gray-water recycled for irrigation, creating a world-class model and laboratory for rooftop food production and energy conservation.
A World Trade Center farm could become a gathering place, a sanctuary, a cultural and social center as important for the health of Manhattan's civic life as its art museums, concert halls, theaters and restaurants. The gardens would be a symbol not just to Americans but to people all over the world. They would show that we know how to bring forth life and nourishment from the rubble of hate and destruction.
I do not believe that it is enough to consecrate the site with steel and concrete and extraordinary architecture. We must also honor lives lost with living seeds planted in their memories -- seeds that would grow and prosper for years to come.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Layoff Upsets Quest for the Good Life

BYLINE:  By ARTHUR BOVINO 

 BODY:
The good life. That's what Manuel Requejo envisioned, what he dreamed of, when he left Peru with his family about four years ago and came to the United States.
 The good life. He is still dreaming of it, still waiting for it to begin. 
 Mr. Requejo is 68, an age when many people are enjoying retirement or looking forward to it. 
But Mr. Requejo is not one of those people. He still feels that he must be the breadwinner in a family of seven, despite his age, his diabetes and his struggle to find a steady job in a flagging economy.
"I feel bad because I'm the head of the house and it's difficult," Mr. Requejo said.
Life was not always this hard. Until recently, Mr. Requejo (pronounced re-KAY-ho) had work and a regular paycheck. But he was laid off from his job at Kennedy International Airport cleaning floors, throwing away garbage and washing food containers for LSG Sky Chefs, a caterer for airliners.
Now, instead of a job, he has a job search. Instead of hope, he has worries.
"Rent payments worry me the most," he said in Spanish. "I worry about the food sometimes, too. But rice and beans you can eat every day. It's nutritious. I can stop eating myself so I can feed my grandchildren."
Five years ago, Mr. Requejo, his wife, Lidia, and their daughter Lily lived in Lima, Peru. Their older daughter, Gladys, had moved to New York in 1988 and found a steady job. In Lima, the Requejos were troubled by a constant stream of news reports about kidnappings, guerrilla warfare and terrorist attacks. Knowing of their daughter's success in New York, Mr. and Mrs. Requejo decided to follow her there in 1998.
Mr. Requejo found work with Sky Chefs. His weekly paycheck was more money than he could have hoped to earn in a month selling clothes on a street corner in Peru.
The Requejos were happy, and when they spoke to their daughter Lily in Peru, they urged her to join them in America. She came to New York last year with her son, Bryan, now 11, and her daughter, Evelyn, now 17 months old. (Lily Requejo's husband stayed behind in Peru, hoping to join her later.)
Five people became seven when Gladys and her son, Louis, now 11, joined the rest of the family in a $1,300-a-month apartment in Woodhaven, Queens.
The family was making enough money to put some of it in a savings account. "It was a good feeling for us to come to another country and have a good life," Mr. Requejo said.
He lost his job in October 2001 during a slowdown in the airline industry after Sept. 11. Since then, he has been on and off unemployment benefits, which, at best, provide $100 a week. He is applying for unemployment again until he can find work.
One of Mr. Requejo's co-workers at Sky Chefs recommended that he go to the Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens, one of the seven local charities that participate in The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
There, Mr. Requejo met a caseworker, Rosa Orihuela, herself from Peru. That meeting led to a shift in fortunes for the family.
Mrs. Orihuela secured $1,300 from the Neediest Cases Fund to pay their rent in October 2001. At the end of November, Catholic Charities also gave him Christmas gifts for the children.
"I'm very grateful to God for this agency for providing assistance," he said.
Mr. Requejo was well liked at work, a hard worker who often took overtime shifts. His employers told him that they would call him back to work if business improved. In the meantime, the Requejos lived off their meager savings, and Mr. Requejo looked for work at restaurants as a dishwasher. Work was hard to find because of his age and poor health, which often left him tired. Some days he rests before hitting the pavement in search of work.
In late April, Mr. Requejo got a call from Sky Chefs to return to work. But on the anniversary of the terrorist attack, he was laid off again. A few weeks later he was asked back again, only to be laid off once more, this time in October -- on his birthday.
"He called me back to explain what was going on," Mrs. Orihuela said. "But funds are very limited."
Her sympathy for the family stems, in part, from common experience. "I had the American dream too," she said. "I came because I knew how great this country was."
Ms. Orihuela was a social worker in Peru before she came to America, so Mr. Requejo feels comforted when discussing his situation with her.
Mr. Requejo's oldest daughter, Gladys, helps out when she can. His other daughter, Lily, sometimes escorts neighborhood children to school and back for $5 per family. The family has stuck together, though paying those bills is still hard.
"I'm grateful that I've been helped, and I hope to be called back to work," Mr. Requejo said. "But I don't know how much longer I can work."
Lily said, "We worry because when he's working he feels alive." 
Still, there are small pleasures. And hope for that good life persists.
His grandsons, Louis and Bryan, are fluent in English, do well in school and have made the transition to living in New York.
Under the television is a collection of English lessons on videotape. Gladys used them when she first arrived in New York years ago. They helped her get her job. Now Mr. and Mrs. Requejo are using them, too.
"It's a good thing she bought it when times were good," Mr. Requejo said with a laugh.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Trade Talks Fail to Agree On Drugs for Poor Nations

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization failed tonight to break a yearlong deadlock over providing impoverished countries with access to life-saving medicine, but the United States pledged that until a deal was reached it would not take any country to court for breaking current trade rules by exporting cut-rate medicine to poor countries.
 The United States said during the late-night sessions that it was unable to accept the draft accord because it covered medicines for more diseases than Washington thought should be included, according to a trade official at the sessions. 
 At issue is a draft agreement that would allow pharmaceutical companies in developing nations to export generic versions of patented drugs to countries too poor to make the medicine themselves. The corporations holding the patents would not be consulted. 
Wealthy nations, led by the United States, wanted to limit the number of diseases covered by the agreement to H.I.V. and AIDS; malaria; tuberculosis; or other infectious epidemics of comparable gravity and scale.
Developing nations like Brazil, India and China argued that governments deserved the right to determine which diseases constituted public health crises in their countries and that the proposed restrictions would undermine the original agreement reached at Doha, Qatar, at the start of a round of world trade negotiations in November of last year. An agreement on the drug issue would fulfill the mandate set at the Doha conference.
Supachai Panitchpakdi, director general of the W.T.O., said in a statement tonight that he was disappointed by the inability of the trade envoys to meet the year-end deadline on the matter. 
"I call on all governments to summon the political will and commitment that will be required to bridge their differences," he said.
The trade organization will take up the issue again next year, and officials said they hoped to reach an agreement by Feb. 11.
During the final debate, a representative of the Vatican reminded the trade representatives that their "promises to the poor must be honored," according to a W.T.O. official.
The United States made its pledge minutes after the talks broke down. Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, issued a statement saying that the Bush administration would call on other nations to join in the pledge and allow poor countries to import inexpensive generic medicines even if that amounted to breaking a patent.
"The United States has worked intensively to find a solution that will provide life-saving drugs to those truly in need, and will continue to work towards that end," Mr. Zoellick said. 
"We urge others to join us in this moratorium to help poor countries get access to emergency life-saving drugs."
The United States held the crucial role in meetings throughout the day. The chief aim was to find a compromise that "was not a general assault on the intellectual property rights of pharmaceutical companies," according to a senior trade official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
"What got us into this debate was a year's worth of demands by outside groups and the W.T.O. that the W.T.O. rules did not hinder countries from dealing with the AIDS crisis," the official said. "Now it seems that the original purpose is lost.
But several developing nations and nongovernmental organizations objected that it was unfair to rule out medicine to treat diseases like cancer and asthma in the new rule.
"President Bush wants to argue that the diseases American children receive treatment for are off limits to poor children in poor countries, but they cannot win that argument," James Love, director of the Consumer Project on Technology, a Washington lobbying group, said in an interview from Geneva.
Throughout the last week, Mr. Panitchpakdi appealed to trade envoys to have a sense of compassion and responsibility for the poor countries, said Peter Ungphakorn, a spokesman for the director general.
"Government after government has said this is vitally important, that it could save lives," Mr. Ungphakorn said. "While this is certainly an important political issue, no one knows economically or medically how much this will be used."
But officials at Doctors Without Borders, which has led a global campaign to broaden poor countries' access to medicines, said they were worried that the new rules would be so complicated and carry so many restrictions that they would discourage the importation of less expensive drugs.
"We're basically talking about a system that could help save millions," said Ellen 't Hoen, program director at Doctors Without Borders. "If a good system isn't created, you can imagine a world a few years from now where multinational companies control the patents for everyone."
The health implications of this trade decision often overshadowed the specific issue of protecting the intellectual property rights of the pharmaceutical companies.
Officials from the United States, Canada, the European Union, Switzerland and Japan said they were determined to protect the patents of their research-based pharmaceutical companies while ensuring that medicines were available to millions of people with AIDS, malaria and other diseases.
But they insisted that the lower-price drugs should be available only for major epidemics in poor countries and not for a wide variety of ailments. They fought proposals that would allow countries like Brazil, China and India to make generic copies of patented medicines and then sell them abroad without the consent of the corporations that hold the patents, saying it would open the door to copying Viagra as well as ointments for baldness.
"We can, and we must, find a reasonable balance between access and patent protection," said Alan F. Holmer, president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, a trade group.
