HEADLINE: US Airways And Unions Agree on Cuts 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
US Airways reached tentative agreements on concessions last night with unions representing its machinists and flight attendants, completing a package for an additional $200 million in wage and benefit cuts that the airline needed to avoid liquidation.
 The moves came as US Airways prepared to file a reorganization plan in United States bankruptcy court. The plan, which a judge will consider at a hearing on Jan. 16, was set to include proposals for returning the airline to profitability. It hopes to emerge from bankruptcy by spring. 
 The airline, however, planned to withhold details of the proposal until this morning, said David Castelveter, a spokesman for US Airways, which is the country's seventh-largest carrier.
The International Association of Machinists and the Association of Flight Attendants were the final two employee groups to agree to give US Airways additional cuts in pay and benefits, on top of an initial round of $850 million in concessions in the fall. The machinists originally refused to give more in concessions, while the flight attendants' union had said it would agree to more cutbacks only after other unions at US Airways had done so.
The machinists' union, representing 11,100 mechanics and other maintenance workers, said leaders at the airline agreed to cuts worth $59 million. A vote on the cuts was scheduled for early January. The flight attendants' union, representing 7,500 workers, did not disclose the size of its concessions. It said its members would vote on the package by Jan. 10.
Their concessions were part of a new round of cuts, worth a total of $200 million, that were sought by the airline over the last few weeks after its revenue fell short of the projections made when it filed for bankruptcy protection in August. 
David G. Bronner, the chief executive of the Retirement Systems of Alabama, which is serving as the primary lender to the airline, this month threatened to withdraw the debtor-in-possession financing he had extended to US Airways and seek liquidation if the unions did not agree to further concessions.
Scotty Ford, president of the machinists District 131-M, representing the airline's mechanics, alluded to Mr. Bronner's threat in announcing the tentative deal last night. "We believe the agreement affords US Airways the best opportunity to avoid liquidation and preserve our members' jobs," Mr. Ford said in a statement.
The Alabama pension system agreed in October to provide $500 million in financing in exchange for a 36 percent stake and voting control of the US Airways board. It has already given the airline $300 million, with the remaining $200 million to be provided after US Airways emerges from bankruptcy protection. Mr. Bronner could not be reached for comment last night.
This week, the pilots' union agreed to its share of the new round of concessions, worth about $99 million. On Wednesday, the airline reached a tentative agreement on new wage and benefit cuts with the Communications Workers of America, representing gate agents and customer service representatives, as well as the Transport Workers Union, representing flight controllers. Neither group has scheduled a vote on the proposals. 
Specific details on the contracts were not available, although the communications workers said they had won a seat on the airline's board after it emerges from bankruptcy protection. US Airways has promised 3 of 13 seats on the board to employee representatives. Mr. Bronner, however, will appoint seven members of the postbankruptcy board.
US Airways has won provisional approval from a federal loan-guarantee board for $900 million in financing, but that, like the remaining $200 million in the Alabama pension system's financing, cannot be drawn from until it emerges from bankruptcy protection.
Along with winning wage and benefit cuts, US Airways has begun cutting costs extensively throughout its operations. In the coming year, it plans to reduce spending on food and beverage service on its flights by 25 percent, according to a memorandum that was distributed to members of the airline's flight crews.
"What is crystal clear is that we are in a tough position with our goal of emerging from bankruptcy at the end of the first quarter," the memo said. "To assist in achieving this goal, cost savings measures have been announced. One of the most impacted areas is our on-board levels of service."
The memo said that US Airways passengers ranked in-flight food service as the fourth most important priority in choosing a carrier, behind personal attention, a frustration-free experience, and reliable flight schedules.
Specifically, the memo said US Airways would eliminate meal tray service on all transcontinental flights, and would serve only sandwiches aboard flights lasting more than 3 hours and 15 minutes, the memo said. 
International passengers will still receive hot meals. But by April, the airline plans to eliminate glassware on all its flights.
Among other amenities that have already been discontinued are printed menus for passengers on cross-country flights, along with souvenir pilots' wings for young passengers, the memo said. Mr. Castelveter said he was not familiar with the memo, but said the airline was focusing on reducing its costs wherever possible.
US Airways announced yesterday that it had asked the Transportation Department to allocate six slots at Reagan National Airport in Washington so that it could begin regional jet service from there to three new cities: Mobile, Ala.; Pensacola, Fla.; and Savannah, Ga.
One of Mr. Bronner's goals when he invested in US Airways last fall was to win new service to Alabama. Approval of the new routes would accomplish that; Mobile is about 160 miles from his office in Montgomery.

GRAPHIC: Photo: US Airways flights have been operating as usual as the company has negotiated with its unions and prepared a reorganization plan. (Shawn Thew/Getty Images)(pg. C2)

HEADLINE: Bargains Are Plentiful For Shoppers This Season 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY

 BODY:
Even intrepid bargain hunters are shocked by the prices they are seeing in the stores this holiday season.
 Last year, Old Navy sold ribbed cotton turtleneck sweaters for $30; this year, a comparable sweater is $24.50. Women's wool dress pants at Banana Republic dropped to $98 from $116 for a similar pair last year. DVD players are selling for an average price of $130.53, down about $50 from last year. Sears is offering Panasonic digital cameras for $400, more than $100 less than last year. 
 Even as consumers are getting hefty discounts, the stores have been cutting deals of their own. Retailers have been squeezing suppliers even harder this year: agencies that buy apparel for retailers estimate that factories have cut prices 10 to 20 percent, particularly on popular items like sweaters and cotton pants. 
As a result, some retailers are able to offer big markdowns while still preserving their profit margins. And consumers are reaping the benefits.
"It is going to be a promotional Christmas," said Dorothy S. Lakner, a retail analyst at CIBC World Markets. "The big difference between this year and last is that some of the promotions have been planned, which should be a better profit for the retailer."
Factory prices in apparel and electronics have been declining for at least a decade, pushed down by cheap overseas labor, competition from new suppliers in Asia and Africa and pressure from American companies like Wal-Mart Stores that have made low prices their mantra. 
But the decline in the factory price of goods is particularly acute this year partly because of the terrorist attacks last year, according to manufacturers and retail analysts. After the attacks, orders were drastically cut, leaving many suppliers with full warehouses and idle equipment. When retailers starting make orders for this year's holiday, manufacturers had little choice but to agree to further price cuts. 
Considering that retailers typically strive for markups of at least 50 percent on apparel and 15 to 20 percent for electronics, those price cuts mean more leeway for retailers. 
"This has provided some margin cushion to the retailer in these difficult times," said Richard E. Jaffe, a retail analyst at UBS Warburg. "Retailers were quick to mark down but had the cushion to be able to take the first markdown without getting hurt."
For example, hooded fur-trimmed coats by Sean John cost $265, about the same as last year. But according to Wongo Enterprises, a Hong Kong-based agency that deals in outerwear, the factory price of the coats, which are also made for DKNY -- a unit of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton -- dropped to $56 from $65 last year. 
Samson Cheng, the general manager at Wongo, said the drop in price of the down jackets mostly resulted from bargain-hunting retailers.
"When we quote the price they usually say, 'Oh, your price is very high,' " Mr. Cheng said. "In order to survive, you've got to lower the price."
Jonathan Mayer, the vice president for corporate communications at Perry Ellis International, said that last year the company bought a suede fabric shirt from a Chinese factory for $8 and sold it under a private label at a specialty men's chain for $15. This year, Perry Ellis got an 8 percent discount from the manufacturer and sold the shirt for $13.75 in stores, keeping the company's profit margin intact. 
Retailers were also able to eke out further discounts on consumer electronics, where costs can fluctuate wildly from one year to the next. The average factory price of plasma televisions, for example, dropped to $5,556, a decline of 23 percent from last year, according to the Consumer Electronics Association. Camcorders dropped 5.4 percent, to about $400; MP3 players fell 32 percent, to $94. 
Retailers generally do not like to talk about their manufacturing contracts and several companies declined to speak specifically about pricing, citing policies against discussing proprietary information. Gap, which makes its clothing in 50 countries including China, did confirm that a pricing war of sorts was taking place.
"It always is a global competitive environment when you're negotiating prices with vendors," said Alan Marks, vice president for corporate communications for Gap, which owns Old Navy and Banana Republic.
Where the pricing squeeze is being most felt is in the factories themselves. Apparel manufacturers enjoyed some relief this year from cheaper raw materials. Cotton prices are at a 20- to 30-year low, according to Nancy Chen, a spokeswoman for Li & Fung Ltd., an apparel buying agency based in Hong Kong. 
But William Mak, the director of Greenway Garment Factory Ltd. in Hong Kong, which makes women's underwear and pajamas for Federated Department Stores and for the May Company, said that while lower prices allowed him to trim prices by 5 percent this year, he was still being pressured to cut them further. 
"Other factories, other countries are lowering their prices, so I can't keep my price," Mr. Mak said. "And buyers are screening you. They are facing a very tough business also." 
Some of the hardest hit apparel manufacturers are in Pakistan, where factories were shunned after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks over concerns about security. According to one T-shirt and sweatshirt manufacturer in Faisalabad, even aggressive discounts and low prices have not been enough to bring back business. 
"This year I have not been able to sell any goods to America at all," said the manufacturer, who did not want to be identified, but said he once had contracts with American Eagle, Polo and Kohl's department stores. "If I've not been able to do business with them, you can imagine the state of affairs with me." 
Even if the economy improves, manufacturers said they believed that pricing pressure would continue. They are also concerned about what will happen to their businesses in 2005, when the World Trade Organization is scheduled to eliminate quotas on textiles, a move likely to elevate the price war to new levels. 
George Fontini, a partner at Mudd Jeans, a marketer of denim pants to teenage girls, said that lower manufacturers' prices had helped retailers -- his company paid 5 percent less to his suppliers in China this year -- but that much of the difference was already being passed on to shoppers. 
"The consumer's done very well," he said. "Retailers are not getting windfall profits. We do fancier finishings, we put more embellishment on the garment, and we sell it cheaper than we did years ago."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ashraf Sajid, a garment worker in Lahore, Pakistan, was laid off for eight months after the Sept. 11 attacks. (Keith Bradsher/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Judge Rules Most Players In Enron Case May Be Sued
A federal judge in Houston ruled that virtually all of the banks, law firms and investment houses that played roles in the construction of Enron's off-the-books partnerships could be sued by investors seeking to regain billions of dollars they lost when the company collapsed.
 The decision only dismissed claims against two defendants -- Deutsche Bank and Kirkland & Ellis, the Chicago law firm -- while allowing the suit to proceed against almost a dozen other institutions and firms, including Citigroup, J. P. Morgan Chase, Merrill Lynch and Vinson & Elkins. Page C3. 

No Deal Made on Low-Price Drugs
The World Trade Organization failed to break a yearlong deadlock over how to give countries access to life-saving medicine, but the United States pledged that until a deal is reached it would not take any country to court if it broke current trade rules and imported cut-rate medicine to the world's poor countries. C3.

Stocks Rise, Ending a 2-Week Slide
The Nasdaq composite index rose 8.95 points, or 0.7 percent, to close at 1,363.05. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 146.52 points, or 1.8 percent, to 8,511.32, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 11.51 points, or 1.3 percent, to 895.76. All three stock gauges ended the week higher. C4.

Boeing Scraps High-Speed Plane
Boeing is scrapping plans to build a futuristic, high-speed plane called the Sonic Cruiser in favor of designing a fuel-efficient aircraft. Boeing hopes the new plane will be 17 to 20 percent more fuel efficient than the 767. C2.

Benefits for Rochester Workers
About 5,500 employees and retirees of the former Rochester Telephone will receive full pension benefits under an agreement reached yesterday. The pension plan had been threatened by the bankruptcy filing of Global Crossing, which purchased the telephone company, then known as Frontier, in March 1999. C2.

Ford Settles Some S.U.V. Claims
Ford Motor has agreed to pay $51.5 million to settle state government claims that it misled consumers about the safety of its sport utility vehicles and failed to disclose known tire failure risks. The agreement does not affect private legal claims against Ford. C3.

Turkish Media Executive Sentenced
Cem Uzan, a Turkish media executive, was sentenced to 15 months in prison for contempt of court for failing to give testimony related to charges he and family members owe billions of dollars to Nokia and Motorola. Mr. Uzan's sister, Aysegul Akay, was sentenced to six months in prison for contempt after failing to appear at hearings over the last two months. C3.

Halliburton Shares Decline Slightly
Shares of Halliburton fell slightly as investors absorbed the company's announcement that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun a formal inquiry into a change in its accounting practices in 1998. The shift from an informal investigation to a formal one means the S.E.C. has the power to subpoena documents or other evidence. C2.

G.D.P. Grew 4% in Third Quarter
Gross domestic product, the gauge of total economic activity, grew at a 4 percent annual rate in the third quarter, the Commerce Department reported. C14.

Alabama Court Reverses Verdict
The Alabama Supreme Court reversed a $3.5 billion jury verdict against Exxon Mobil in a dispute over royalties for offshore natural gas leases. The decision sends the case back to a lower court for retrial. C4.

HEADLINE: Left Has Hard Time In Era of Terrorism 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
In a 1976 symposium published in Commentary called "What is a Liberal -- Who's a Conservative?" the novelist Tom Wolfe offered an unorthodox explanation of those vexed political terms. He declared that they were more the result of instinct than reason and more a reflection of schoolyard wrangling than adult sophistication. Forget political philosophy. Political conflicts grow out of rivalries like those between jocks and freaks that once split the nation's high schools. "My Childhood Enemy!" Mr. Wolfe cries out in epic extravagance, "O My Faithful Schoolyard Phantoms!"
 But as Mr. Wolfe also knows, schoolyard enmities are hardly matters of innocent play. Caricature and mockery abound, but consequences are serious. Trent Lott's recent declarations, for example, did indeed have an adolescent aura, mixing exaggeration with elastic principles. His first comment portrayed a liberal caricature of the conservative: a racist wanting to turn back the clock. Then, in his apologies, he became a conservative's caricature of a liberal, guiltily and naively donning the mantle of virtue. But more was always at stake than posturing and declarations of allegiance. 
 In fact, conservative and liberal categories really do offer opposing views of the world, providing different explanations for events in history, different descriptions of human nature and different philosophies of political justice. These ideas have always changed with historical circumstances, but after 9/11, some of liberalism's perspectives have come under increasing scrutiny. 
In an article called "The Case for Liberalism" in the December issue of Harper's, for example, George S. McGovern tries to revive liberalism as a loyal opposition in the face of possible war. He says its definition as a political philosophy is "based on belief in progress, the essential goodness of man and the autonomy of the individual, and standing for the protection of political and civil liberties." In contrast, conservatism's function, Mr. McGovern argues, is "to cling tightly to the past"; it cannot be relied upon for "constructive new ideas" that might lead to a "more just and equitable society or a more peaceful and cooperative world." Conservatism's main contribution, he suggests, is just to keep a critical watch on liberalism, whose virtues should be transparent.
Mr. McGovern's version of conservatism is hardly recognizable as the conservatism of recent decades; his version of liberalism is also formulaic. But if liberalism is considered in its broadest sense, Mr. McGovern's sweeping assertions about its obviousness might be true. Much of political modernity, with its ideas of democratic rule, individualism and human rights, actually represents a triumph of classical liberalism. In fact, attitudes like Mr. Lott's aside, much contemporary conservatism honors similar ideas, making it less an opponent of liberalism than an alternative interpretation of the liberal world.
This is one reason that events since 9/11 have been so traumatic. While ethical and political acclaim for this larger sense of liberalism in the West is uncontested, it is barely present in Arab governments, virulently opposed by Islamic radicalism and rejected by many in the growing Muslim fundamentalist populations in European urban centers. Meanwhile the United States has been engaged in a new form of war, one goal of which is to transform preliberal societies into modern democracies while protecting against incursions at home. This requires an uncompromising scrutiny of liberalism's doctrines, ambitions and limitations.
Yet Mr. McGovern avoids the issue. He refers to terrorism as "one of the more vexing problems facing us" but argues that it does not justify an "obsession with external threats and internal security." Other liberals have been more attentive. Last spring in Dissent magazine, for example, Michael Walzer argued in an essay called "Can There Be a Decent Left?" that the overemphasis on civil liberties misses the real nature of the threat. Mr. Walzer more broadly accused the American left of having been "stupid, overwrought, grossly inaccurate" in its condemnations of the United States. Its rationalist and materialist analyses, he continued, have also led to an inability "to recognize or acknowledge the power of religion in the modern world." The left has thus become alienated from its own country, he said, and unrealistic in its expectations. Comparable arguments have been made by Todd Gitlin in Mother Jones and by Michael Kazin in the current Dissent.
Each of these writers says one strain of American liberalism has gone awry when its celebration of equality and its distrust of power are taken to extremes. Liberalism also presumes a society in which equality and liberty have been established and disruption controlled through the use of reason. So when force becomes necessary, it is a source of discomfort, because it implies the failure of reason and the curtailment of liberty. 
Recent events increased discomfort because in many ways, liberalism's international future is at stake. In the West liberal democracy became possible only after centuries of economic growth and philosophical debate. In his classic 1927 book, "The History of European Liberalism," the Italian scholar Guido de Ruggiero showed how principles of liberal government developed in England, France, Germany and Italy over three centuries. How, then, can preliberal or fundamentalist societies be quickly transformed into liberal democracies? And if they are not, how are their militant threats to liberalism to be addressed?
There are no simple answers to these questions, but they address issues at the heart of the liberal idea. Consider, for example, the philosopher John Rawls, who died last month. He struggled to define a philosophy that could take the messiness of the world into account while preserving an ideal of reasoned and just liberalism. In a 1993 essay, "The Law of Peoples," he tried to envision a reasonable international counterpart to his ideal of a just society made famous in his 1971 book, "A Theory of Justice."
But Rawls began that essay stipulating that he would consider only peaceful, nonexpansionist, legitimate governments who honored human rights.
The same limitation applies to Rawls's vision of "justice as fairness." He imagined that if a group of people were designing a just society without knowing what their place in that society would be, behind that "veil of ignorance" they would make sure that the society would be most fair to its least privileged members because that is who they might end up being. Inequalities in intelligence, character and wealth would still exist, but in Rawls's view "men agree to avail themselves of the accidents of nature and social circumstance only when doing so is for the common benefit."
But this noble ideal assumes that human decisions have a fundamentally rational foundation, that material goods are the main measure of privilege, that an interest in egalitarianism is paramount, and these hypotheses are surely not universally accepted.
Rawls's notion of fairness also assumes an almost static world that can be managed without worrying about the irrational and the unexpected. But it is in response to challenge and disruption that the system would be tested. In the face of internal challenge and external attack, Rawls's system might even display the kind of intolerance outlined by Mr. Walzer.
None of this means, of course, that the broad liberal ideas of the West are to be discarded; just the opposite. But the challenges being mounted also mean that the particular incarnations of liberalism will change under pressure; conservatism will also have a role, leading to other kinds of intellectual confrontations. Edmund Burke once wrote, "Politics ought to be adjusted, not to human reasonings, but to human nature, of which reason is but a part, and by no means the greatest part." That is something that really is learned in the schoolyard.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Rawls sought a liberal philosophy that would accommodate both ideals and the messiness of the world. (Jane Reed/Harvard University, 1990)

HEADLINE: A Nation That Exports Oil, Herring and Peace 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI

DATELINE: OSLO 

 BODY:
With a population of about 4.5 million, a cruelly tenacious winter and an awful lot of herring, Norway will never stand out as an economic powerhouse, a vacation paradise or the culinary envy of the world.
 But its claim to global fame is an arguably rarer one. Now more than ever, Norway seems to be the international capital of peace. 
 The Nobel Peace Prize, awarded here since 1901, is only a glossy part of it. Just before former President Jimmy Carter swept into Oslo earlier this month to receive this year's medal, Norwegians brokered a once-unthinkable power-sharing agreement between the government of Sri Lanka and Tamil rebels, who had been at war for two decades. 
Just after Mr. Carter left, the Indonesian government and separatists from Aceh Province signed a peace treaty, the fruit of negotiations financed by the Norwegian government.
True enough, the 1993 Oslo accords between the Israelis and the Palestinians did not, ultimately, turn out well.
But the effort was valiant, and it touched off a frenzy of Norwegian peace-making, or at least peacetrying, that has put peace somewhere alongside oil and timber as one of this country's signature exports.
"If we can make a difference, we feel it is our obligation," said Foreign Minister Jan Petersen, perhaps understating the Norwegian knack for, and interest in, all matters peaceful. "We do what we can."
That turns out to be quite a bit, and it inevitably raises the question: what makes Norway such a welcome interloper and lulling force?
"We're small, we're way up here and we have no colonial past," said Vidar Helgesen, a deputy foreign minister with a leading role in the Sri Lanka talks.
Because Norway does not -- and, really, could not -- have grand designs on other countries, it does not engender suspicion, Mr. Helgesen and other diplomats here said.
In addition, Norway is not perceived to be doing the bidding of larger, more muscular and more meddlesome nations. While it belongs to NATO, it does not belong to the European Union. It has its alliances, but wears them lightly.
"We are not Americans and we are not Europeans," said Nils Morten Udgaard, who writes a column on foreign affairs for Aftenposten, one of Norway's largest newspapers. "We are just ourselves."
Norway has never really lorded it over other countries, so it does not carry its olive branch across reservoirs of bad blood.
Rather, the Norwegian government and Norwegian charities have financed so much humanitarian work in volatile countries that Norway is often a welcome guest in those places. 
Norway is rich -- its per-capita gross domestic product is among the highest in the world -- and relatively untroubled, so it has money and time to lavish on faraway missions with uncertain deadlines.
It is also remote, an incalculable benefit when negotiations actually end up here. Several diplomats said that the 1993 Oslo accords worked, at the time, because the participants were so far from the glare of television cameras and the second-guessing of political peers.
"It's easy to be discreet here," said Janne Haaland Matlary, a professor of international politics at the University of Oslo. "This is not, after all, the center of the world."
But it is certainly peaceful. Candles flicker in countless windows. Professional boxing is against the law. Drivers rarely honk, and are seldom given reason to.
"We're not known for being aggressive," said Henrietta Berggren, the manager of a trendy Oslo restaurant where, on a recent night, the conversation never rose above a tranquil hum. The background music -- the softer side of Alanis Morrisette, the moodier reaches of Moby -- was, in two honestly chosen syllables, peaceful.
Over the last decade, Norwegians have had a hand in peace talks between Communist rebels and the Philippine government; Croatia and Yugoslavia, and Colombia's government and the FARC rebel movement. Norwegians have ventured into Cyprus and Somalia and Sudan.
In 1996, they helped negotiate a cease-fire, signed in Oslo, between leftist guerrilla leaders and the Guatemalan government, ending an armed conflict that had claimed 100,000 lives over 35 years.
Norwegian diplomats say there is no one model that they follow, and that such flexibility is crucial.
Sometimes they ferry proposals between the two sides in a conflict. Sometimes they merely provide the meeting rooms. Sometimes they consult early, and closely, with the United Nations, and sometimes not.
Always, they say, the two sides must already be willing to talk, and often, a key to success or nearsuccess is Norway's willingness to let the process begin quietly or even secretly.
Mr. Helgesen said Norwegians had been working with Sri Lanka, at the invitation of its government, since 1998, which was about two years before the world got a whiff of it.
Much of what Norway did, he said, was simply remind the two sides of their interests, although Norway also helped draft a cease-fire agreement that the sides signed in February and the power-sharing plan that was announced in Oslo in December.
He said Norway was also careful not to hurry the talks.
"As long as the discussion lingers, we don't interfere," he said. "We're very patient."
Indeed, since most Norwegians endorse these efforts, no one government feels political pressure to get quick results, and that allows Norway to assume an informal, unthreatening posture, he and other diplomats said.
Norwegians say they have been propelled in their peace efforts by a heritage of Lutheran missionary work and socialist idealism.
But Norwegians also get something more than satisfaction out of their deeds.
"We gain some access," said Mr. Petersen, explaining that Norway's place at so many negotiating tables elevates its relevance and usefulness to larger countries with which it trades.
Norway recently got the ears of European countries to which it exports seafood, he said, because Norway had privileged insight into elections in Africa that those countries wanted to monitor.
"You can put it this way," Mr. Petersen said. "We talked about Zimbabwe and fish."
Norway also gains a source of pride and a mission and identity all its own.
After Jan Egeland helped forge the 1993 Olso accords, he wrote a book that compared Norway and the United States. Its title was "Impotent Superpower, Potent Small State."
Mr. Helgesen, in a speech in Jakarta earlier this year, noted that Norway "cannot be the fire brigade" for the world.
"But," he added, "we can be a kind of social worker."
The association with peace-making, Ms. Matlary said, "makes Norway interesting."
"Our reputation," she said, "is impeccable."

(Associated Press); (Reuters); Jimmy and Rosalyn Carter toured Oslo's sculpture-filled Vigeland Park earlier this month before Mr. Carter received the Nobel Peace Prize. HEADLINE: Democrats Pondering Approach On Tax Cuts 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
Faced with the certainty that President Bush can get Congress to pass a package of tax cuts, Democratic lawmakers are still struggling with how to put their own stamp on the issue.
 The question for Democrats is no longer whether to support tax cuts, at least as part of a short-term economic stimulus package, but how deep the tax cuts should be and who should get them. 
 On Thursday, one senior Democrat, Senator Max Baucus of Montana, outlined a $160 billion stimulus package that included $75 billion in block grants to states, a one-time income tax break worth about $300 a worker and more money for highway construction.
"It's designed to provide stimulus and to be as immediately effective and responsible as possible," said Mr. Baucus, the top Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee. 
But the senator's announcement of a plan on his own startled some Democratic colleagues, a number of whom have quite different ideas of the best way to proceed.
Today several Democrats quietly questioned the large size of Senator Baucus's proposal for new grants to the states, as well as the absence of any conditions on how state governments would use the money.
Other Democrats like the idea of funneling money to states, many of which face huge budget shortfalls, but have other ideas about where to cut taxes. Senator Jon Corzine of New Jersey, for instance, has proposed giving every worker a reprieve from paying Social Security and Medicare taxes on the first $10,000 in wages. 
As in the Senate, Democrats in the House have yet to agree on a plan, and officials predict they will not do so until sometime in January. 
About 170 House Democrats attended a two-day closed-door forum on economic issues this month. According to some present, there was almost unanimous agreement on a need to support some kind of short-term tax relief as well as other assistance for lower- and middle-income workers, including an extension of unemployment benefits.
"The key is to get money in people's pockets," said Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, a senior Democrat on the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee. "The direction we're going is a tax cut for the middle class, the people who will be spending money."
That appears to be in sharp contrast to proposals being drafted by the White House, which are likely to focus on accelerating rate reductions for people in upper income brackets and reducing taxes on corporate dividends, a step that would primarily benefit wealthy taxpayers.
As a practical matter, Republicans have sufficient control of the House to pass almost any tax package the president proposes. Senate Democrats have some ability to block legislation through filibustering, but even that ability is limited.
Where Democrats can make an impact is in scoring political points by accusing Republicans of catering to the rich and portraying themselves as promoters of tax relief for working families.
Mr. Bush is not expected to announce his tax plan until January, but administration officials have said it will almost certainly include speeding up tax cuts that were expected to take effect in 2004 and 2006, some kind of reduction in taxes on corporate dividends, added tax write-offs for business on new investment in equipment and more incentives for people to put money into their pension plans.
Most of those proposals would be of primary benefit to the wealthiest taxpayers. According to an analysis by the Tax Policy Center, a joint venture of the Urban Institute and the Brookings Institution, the top 5 percent of income earners would receive about 64 percent of tax reductions if cuts scheduled for 2004 were pushed ahead to next year. A similar pattern holds for the impact of cutting taxes on corporate dividends.
Democrats have seized on the idea of a stimulus package to argue for one-time tax breaks rather than permanent tax reductions, and for a mix of spending programs in addition to the tax cuts.
In the House, though, there is little incentive for compromise, if only because Republicans there need little help to pass legislation. The situation could be quite different in the Senate, where last year Mr. Baucus reached a deal with Republicans that helped the president get his 10-year, $1.35 trillion tax cut enacted.
Some Democrats fear that Mr. Baucus will be too ready to compromise for their taste. On Thursday he said he was "open" to working with Republicans, and Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who will become chairman of the Finance Committee in January, said he looked forward to "working with Senator Baucus on a job-creating plan that will have bipartisan support."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ON IRAQ'S BORDER; 
U.S. Demands for Help Roil Turkey's Government

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
With the United States pressing Turkish leaders to cooperate in a possible invasion of Iraq, senior officials describe a government in turmoil as it struggles to decide.
 Officials of Turkey's recently elected government said in interviews this week that they had missed deadlines set for them by American officials eager for a Turkish commitment, and that they were weighing how far to go in helping the United States. 
 Prime Minister Abdullah Gul said the effects on his country of a possible war were almost entirely negative. He also said that Turkish public opinion was overwhelmingly against cooperation with the United States. 
"There are many demands from the U.S. government," said Mr. Gul, who became prime minister last month. "Turkey is a democratic country. We have to convince our people, we have to convince our Parliament. Whether we fully cooperate or do nothing, we are going to suffer." 
He and other officials said what they feared most were the economic consequences of another war in the region. Turkey is suffering through its worst recession in 50 years, and officials say a new war could cripple any new chances for recovery. 
If Turkey did cooperate with the United States, officials added, they also fear that it would gain a reputation among Islamic nations as a kind of Muslim policeman for the West. They noted that their country's soldiers were already called upon to supervise security forces in Afghanistan, and that American planes had run hundreds of missions into Afghanistan from the Turkish air base in Incirlik. 
"We will be seen in the Muslim world as a country that is killing other Muslims," said one Turkish official. "This would be very difficult to accept."
Yet if the government chooses not to cooperate, it risks serious damage to its most important alliance, with the United States. Turkey, a secular Muslim democracy, is a longtime member of NATO. 
As Mr. Gul put it in the interview, "Everything is happening out of our control." 
A specific concern for him and others in any American-led assault is its size, which is likely to be large and ambitious. Local press reports indicate that American officials have asked Turkey for permission to bring as many 90,000 American troops through Turkey for an operation in northern Iraq, using several Turkish air bases and seaports.
Mr. Gul declined to discuss details of his talks with American officials, but he did not dispute the accuracy of the reports. "There is no smoke where there is no fire," he said. 
Western diplomats here said they could not confirm the Turkish reports, though American officials have indicated that an attack from the north would most likely involve tens of thousands of troops.
A senior Turkish official told The New York Times early this month that the Pentagon wanted the option to deploy "tens of thousands."
For all the angst, a senior official here said he expected the government to make a decision "in a matter of days." Western diplomats cite "positive signals" in recent days. 
"In a short period of time, we will let them know," Mr. Gul said. 
Yet some Turkish officials say they are still not sure that the Americans fully appreciate their dilemma. The Turkish economy has shrunk as much as 10 percent in the past year. A recent public opinion poll found that 83 percent of Turks oppose allowing the United States to use Turkish bases for an Iraqi operation. 
"The Americans are polite, but they are very insistent, they are very focused," said a Turkish official. "The Americans want us to make a decision immediately."
Turkey's Kurdish population also looms large in the equation here. Iraq, too, has large numbers of Kurds. 
It fears a reprise of what happened during the Persian Gulf war in the early 1990's, when a half million Iraqi Kurds arrived at Turkey's border seeking refuge from the Iraqi Army.
An overarching fear for Turkish officials is that an American war would break up Iraq and clear the way for an independent Kurdish state. That, they point out, could restart the Kurdish insurgency in their own country, which led to fighting that took many lives in the 1990's. 
The Americans have assured the Turks that they would block the creation of an independent Kurdish state from Iraq. But Mr. Gul indicated that he was concerned that the current American-backed Kurdish groups in northern Iraq were already acting as an independent state. 
"There is a de facto situation in Iraq now despite the official denials," Mr. Gul said. "This a reality we cannot deny." 
Another reality is that the looming decision on helping the United States is being seen as a test for the governing Justice and Development Party, whose leaders have flirted with Islamist politics in the past. 
Since taking power, new leaders, including Mr. Gul and Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the party leader, who may become the prime minister, have reaffirmed their ties to the United States and Europe and avoided any hint of bringing Islam into public life. 
But if they do decide to accommodate the United States, Turkish leaders have done little to prepare the public for a large role in an Iraq conflict, which could come early next year. There have been no parliamentary votes on the subject, and few speeches by Turkish leaders. 
"Everybody knows that 80 to 85 percent of the Turkish people would say no to war in Iraq," said Cuneyd Zapsu, a senior adviser to Mr. Erdogan. "As a democratic country, how can we say yes?" 
If Turkey joined in with the United States it would probably be asked to let American planes use its airspace to fly missions over Iraq, and to use its air bases as a staging area for American troops. And a senior Turkish official said the Americans had also requested that Turkish forces join the Americans in the attack. 
"They want our troops as well," the official said. 
Although Mr. Gul did not indicate what Turkey would decide, he seemed to be searching for some kind of compromise that might fall short of what the Americans want but which might be acceptable to Turkish public opinion. 
"We are a strategic ally of the United States," he said. "It is our right to exercise all the alternatives. We want to be honest about what we can do and what we cannot."

HEADLINE: DIVISIVE: THE REACTION; 
Fear of Economic Fallout In Senator's Hometown

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Dec. 20 

 BODY:
The Northrop Grumman shipyard here is shut down for the holiday season, so Jeff Walters, 37, had time today to pick up a couple of shirts at the Bargain Annex in Pascagoula's faded downtown shopping plaza -- and to chew over the news that Trent Lott had resigned as Republican leader of the Senate.
 "It's going to hurt the shipyard," said Mr. Walters, who on workdays spends his hours banging sheet metal into shape in the bowels of what will eventually become a destroyer. "It's going to hurt bad." 
 Like many of the thousands of people who work in the defense industry here, Mr. Walters, of Big Point, praises Senator Lott for bringing home the federal contracts that have kept the Mississippi Gulf Coast afloat for decades. In Pascagoula, a city of 26,000, Northrop Grumman Ship Systems employs 11,000 workers. 
Mr. Lott also helped land the $47.5 million high-rise bridge that will open across the Pascagoula River next year, cutting down on traffic backups for shrimpers and drivers alike.
Mr. Walters, like many Mississippians who have watched Mr. Lott's downfall in the last two weeks, called the whole thing unfair. "I don't think he needs to step down," Mr. Walters said. "I think he just made a mistake."
A few steps away, Vincent D. Jones, who builds the hulls of Navy ships, was Christmas shopping with his sons Vincent Jr., 14, and Eric, 16. Mr. Jones, who is black, rolled his eyes when he said that he works in a shipyard building named for the Confederate States of America. His view of Mr. Lott's decision to step down was more nuanced.
"What he said at the time was a wrong thing to say," Mr. Jones said of Mr. Lott's Dec. 5 remark that the nation would have been better served had Strom Thurmond won the presidency in 1948. Mr. Thurmond ran that year as a segregationist.
"We're not living back in 1948," Mr. Jones said. "He shouldn't have brought that up. He burned some bridges. But he's done a lot for this community. It's going to hurt the economy."
As Pascagoulans learned of Mr. Lott's decision to give up his leadership post, Mr. Lott avoided a crowd of reporters and photographers gathered outside his waterfront home.
At one point a local real-estate broker walked up and drove a homemade sign into the lawn with "We love you Sen. Lott" scrawled on it in black ink. Mr. Lott's wife, Tricia, came outside with a handwritten note signed by the senator, asking the news media to "please go home."
Elsewhere in Mississippi, Republican and Democratic officials alike seemed to take Mr. Lott's resignation in stride, balancing compassion for the senator with the hope that some gain could come from the episode.
"I know that Republicans around the state are hurt and angry about the way Senator Lott has been treated," said Jim Herring, the state Republican chairman. "I encouraged them to take out their frustrations next year at the ballot box by electing Republicans from top to bottom, from governor to coroner."
Phil Bryant, the Republican state auditor, said he was friends with Mr. Lott. "I am just incredibly sad about the whole ordeal," Mr. Bryant said. "Us politicians are human, also, and it's difficult to watch him go through this."
But he added: "Our party ebbs and flows. We'll get through this. We intend to use it as an opportunity to energize our efforts to reach out to the minority community."
Gov. Ronnie Musgrove, a Democrat, called Senator Lott's departure from his leadership post "unfortunate for Mississippi, just as his recent remarks were unfortunate for the state." He added, "His remarks are not a reflection of the Mississippi of 2002, and we hope they will not have a negative impact on our efforts to build a better quality of life in Mississippi."
Rickey Cole, chairman of the state Democratic Party, called on Mr. Lott to concentrate full-time on Mississippi's needs, to "develop a greater sensitivity on issues of race," and to take the lead to demand that Republicans "repudiate the Southern strategy of subtle appeals to and appeasement of racism."
But Freda McKissic Bush, an obstetrician-gynecologist in Jackson and a Republican political operative, called Mr. Lott's resignation a defeat for her party. "It saddens me to think that the Democrats will rattle their cage and we'll jump," she said. 
Dr. Bush, who is black, said that partisan politics, not race, were at the heart of the campaign to oust Mr. Lott. "It was a political agenda to undermine the strength of the Republican Party," she said. "They saw an opening and they took it. Unfortunately, the Republicans responded to it by removing Trent Lott. I shudder to think what the next thing will be."
At the Singing River Mall in Gautier, a few miles west of Pascagoula, Charles T. Hollis, 49, sounded a slightly more hopeful note. He was, after all, ringing a bell for the Salvation Army. "It may be for the best, the best for Mississippi," Mr. Hollis said of the senator's announcement. "It might heal old wounds. We need to get on to other problems like the economy."
He paused, stopped ringing his bell, and looked out at the setting sun. "It's one bad stink," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
After 3 Losing Days, Stocks End the Week With a Flurry

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks surged yesterday, as investors shrugged off worries about a war with Iraq and drew some optimism from the latest assessment of the economy by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. The three main gauges posted a weekly gain and snapped a two-week losing streak. 
 Analysts said many investors were looking for bargains after three days of declines. News that brokerage firms had reached a settlement on conflict-of-interest charges and that the Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott, had resigned his leadership post added to the good mood. 
 "The fewer of those types of things people have to worry about, the more people can focus on the fact that the economic news is not all that bad and the prospects for the stock market in 2003 are pretty good," said Scott Wren, equity strategist for A. G. Edwards & Sons. 
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 146.52 points, or 1.8 percent, and closed at 8,511.32. In the previous three sessions, blue chips fell 262 points, to their lowest level in nearly six weeks. 
The broader market also finished higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 8.95 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,363.05. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 11.51 points, or 1.3 percent, to 895.76. 
For the week, the Dow rose 0.9 percent, while the Nasdaq edged up 0.05 percent and the S.& P. 500 gained 0.7 percent. 
Mr. Greenspan told the Economic Club of New York on Thursday that since the Fed's last rate cut on Nov. 6, there was some evidence that the "U.S. economy has been working its way through a soft patch." He added that the country faced no immediate threat of deflation. 
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that the economy posted a solid growth rate of 4 percent in the third quarter, unchanged from the estimate made a month ago, even as worries persist about just how much the economy is weakening. 
And 10 of the country's largest brokerage firms, including Citigroup and Goldman Sachs, agreed to pay about $1.4 billion to resolve conflict-of-interest allegations in one of the largest settlements ever with securities regulators. 
That helped lift the financial sector stocks, with Citigroup rising $1.14, or 3.1 percent, to $38.14, and Morgan Stanley jumping $1.74, or 4.3 percent, to $42.04. 
Analysts say investors have been hesitant to commit to stocks in recent weeks, particularly amid escalating talks about a possible war with Iraq. On Thursday, the United States declared Iraq in "material breach" of a United Nations disarmament resolution. 
In addition, some investors are still looking to cash in some gains from the blue chips' eight-week surge in the autumn, and are uncertain whether Wall Street can stage its traditional holiday rally in the last two weeks of December. 
Nike climbed $3.57, or 8.6 percent, to $45.10, after it said net profit grew 18 percent in the second quarter on strong international sales. 
But Halliburton fell 42 cents, or 2.2 percent, to $19.08, after it said the Securities and Exchange Commission's inquiry into the company's accounting practices had become a formal investigation. 
In the bond market, the 10-year Treasury note fell 6/32, to 100 10/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 3.96 percent from 3.94 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32, to 107 7/32. The bond's yield was unchanged at 4.89 percent.
The two-year note declined 2/32, to 100 16/32. Its yield rose to 1.74 percent from 1.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Medicare to Cut Payments To Doctors 4.4% Next Year 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
The Bush administration announced today that Medicare payments to doctors would be cut 4.4 percent next year, after a 5.4 percent cut this year. Federal officials predicted that doctors would, as a result, be less willing to accept new Medicare patients.
 If the cuts are not reversed, Congress and the administration will face the wrath of two politically potent constituencies, elderly voters and doctors who care for the elderly. But administration officials are desperately trying to control federal health costs, which they see as a major factor that contributes to federal budget deficits. 
 Doctors, outraged at the cuts, faulted both Congress and the administration for failing to avert the cuts, which start on March 1.
Dr. Mark H. Krotowski, a family doctor in a working-class neighborhood of Brooklyn, said: "The new cuts will force more physicians to turn away Medicare patients. That's the reality. Doctors will not have any incentive to accept new Medicare patients. While Medicare reimbursements are going down, our expenses are rising 5 percent to 10 percent a year."
The Department of Health and Human Services said the cuts might "cause fewer physicians to accept new Medicare patients" and could prompt doctors to increase their charges to some of the 40 million Medicare beneficiaries.
Dr. Jose V. Angel, president of the Iowa Medical Society, said, "Elderly and disabled patients will have to wait longer and travel farther to see doctors."
Doctors said the existing payment rates were already too low to cover the costs of caring for the elderly. 
"Physicians cannot afford to treat Medicare patients" under the new rates, said Dr. James C. Martin, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians.
Thomas A. Scully, administrator of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said he was making the cuts reluctantly.
"The reduction in physician fee schedule rates results from a formula specified in the Medicare law, and we believe that formula is flawed and must be fixed," Mr. Scully said. "Although Congress considered several options for fixing the fee schedule formula for 2003, and the House actually passed a bill to address these issues, no final action was taken before Congress adjourned."
The administration announced the cuts in issuing the Medicare doctors' fee schedule for 2003. It specifies the amounts paid to doctors for more than 7,000 services and procedures from routine office visits to complex surgical procedures.
Next year, Medicare is widely expected to pay $45 billion to more than 750,000 doctors and other practitioners.
Mr. Scully said that if the formula accurately reflected doctors' costs, they would receive a 1.6 percent increase next year, rather than a 4.4 percent cut. Congress should "fix the formula," he said.
But that was not always the position of the administration. In his budget request in February, President Bush assumed that Medicare payments to doctors would be reduced next year and did not offer any proposal to stop the cuts.
Then in March, the administration told Congress that any infusion of new money into Medicare should be used for prescription drug benefits, "not for increasing payments to fee-for-service Medicare providers."
In the last few months, scores of lawmakers have called for an increase in Medicare payments to doctors. But some members of both parties insisted that if doctors received an increase, then Congress should also raise Medicare payments to hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations, and such changes would have greatly increased the cost of any legislation.
John C. Rother, policy director of AARP, said the cuts in Medicare payments to doctors were "an unintended consequence" of the payment formula.
"Congress should correct it as soon as possible," Mr. Rother said. "We are getting complaints that it's becoming difficult for Medicare beneficiaries to find a doctor willing to accept them in some parts of the country. We don't want that problem to spread."
Under the formula for paying doctors, spending increases with Medicare enrollment and economic growth, among other factors. Doctors say they have been shortchanged for several years because the government underestimated economic growth in the late 1990's and the number of people who would be in the Medicare fee-for-service program.
While acknowledging the errors, administration officials said they did not have the legal authority to correct them.
Dr. Yank D. Coble Jr., president of the American Medical Association, said he hoped that patients would join doctors in lobbying Congress to "fix this Medicare debacle."
Representative Bill Thomas, a California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said: "I am deeply troubled by these successive and significant cuts to physicians who serve Medicare beneficiaries. I remain committed to addressing this issue and reforming Medicare when Congress reconvenes."

HEADLINE: Washington Talk; 
After All These Years, What Do You Say Now, Chevy Chase?

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 

 BODY:
Bellbottoms and disco dancing are still out, but one relic from the mid-1970's is decidedly back in: the Ford administration.
 President Bush continues to reach past more recent Republican administrations, including his father's, to tap the team of a leader sometimes called the accidental president. 
 That is helping Gerald R. Ford, once parodied as the Rodney Dangerfield of presidents, to enjoy a rehabilitation of sorts, bringing new respect for his leadership skills.
Only last week, Mr. Bush chose two men who cut their teeth in government under Mr. Ford: John W. Snow is the president's nominee for Treasury secretary, and William H. Donaldson for chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
If confirmed, they will join a group thick with Ford proteges. Vice President Dick Cheney was Mr. Ford's chief of staff. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld is reprising a role he had under Mr. Ford. Paul H. O'Neill, whom Mr. Snow would succeed at Treasury, was on the Ford budget team. And Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chief, was chairman of Mr. Ford's Council of Economic Advisers.
The former president calls them "my boys," and beams with pride to see them running the show, associates say.
David Hume Kennerly, the official White House photographer during the Ford administration, said: "I feel like Rip Van Winkle. It's like I woke up 25 years later, and not only are my friends still in power, they're more powerful than ever."
Of course, some Bush appointees made their mark under Ronald Reagan (think Colin L. Powell) or George Bush pere (Andrew H. Card Jr.), and many of those from the Ford administration served in succeeding administrations as well. 
Still, "Bush's administration resembles the Gerald Ford cabinet more than it does his own father's," notes Douglas Brinkley, director of the Eisenhower Center at the University of New Orleans.
While many Americans associate Mr. Ford with the pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon, the retreat from Vietnam and the lapel buttons exhorting the nation to "whip inflation now," some students of government say he deserves greater recognition for having assembled a team of decent, pragmatic and capable leaders who were untainted by scandal or self-promotion.
"It was one of the classiest cabinets I can remember," said Stephen Hess, a senior fellow in government studies at the Brookings Institution.
Mr. Ford surrounded himself with officials who had a strong sense of how to get things done, said James M. Cannon, a biographer of his.
"He had a remarkable array of managerial talent in his administration," Mr. Cannon said. "Literally scores came out of that administration and succeeded in business, an unusually high number."
One was Mr. Cheney, who became chief executive at the Halliburton Company. Early on in the Bush administration, the president made him top headhunter.
Mr. Cheney had built up an impressive Rolodex in the Ford White House, and quickly lured former colleagues back into government. He is the connective tissue in Ford redux.
The Fordites bring an ethos that seems to suit Mr. Bush. Loyalty is paramount. Leaks are abhorred. Grandstanders are unwelcome. Mr. Bush's administration, like Mr. Ford's, insists on team players.
It may seem odd that in putting together his team, Mr. Bush has largely overlooked the Reagan administration. After all, he shares Mr. Reagan's Western style, tax-cutting zeal and hail-fellow personality.
But some analysts say the Bush family -- and no one doubts that the first President Bush had a hand in personnel advice for the second -- has been very pointed in bypassing the Reagan loyalists. The Bushes are simply less ideological than Mr. Reagan's faithful, says Mr. Brinkley, of the Eisenhower Center.
"Centrist Republicans are never comfortable with right-wing conservatives," Mr. Brinkley said. "Gerald Ford doesn't like Ronald Reagan."
The Ford-inspired cabinet, by contrast, is filled with "people who are not ideologues," Mr. Brinkley said. "They're conservative, but they're flexible."
Mr. Ford, who turns 90 next summer, was not available for an interview, his spokeswoman said. He meets periodically with his former charges, who at an event last summer included Mr. Rumsfeld, Mr. Cheney and former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.
Mr. Kennerly, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer, joked that his friends from the Ford years had returned in order to atone for past fashion crimes. Back then, Mr. Cheney wore plaid, Mr. Kennerly recalled, adding that "everybody just wanted to come back wearing better suits."

HEADLINE: DIVISIVE WORDS: THE CONSEQUENCES; 
A Nixon-Era Distraction Steps Out of Limelight

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
Six weeks after a midterm election that returned Republicans to power in the Senate, consolidated President Bush's political influence and seemed to assure Trent Lott's future as majority leader, the furor over his words has hurt the Republican Party and the White House in ways that only time will measure definitively.
 On issues like judicial nominations, affirmative action, welfare reform, tax cuts and even the environment, many Republican leaders, conservative commentators, White House advisers and business groups had quietly agreed in recent days that the Lott imbroglio would complicate the Republican agenda in Congress and the country at large. 
 "Regardless of what one may think of the words he spoke or what one may think about race, an objective observer cannot argue that Trent Lott could do anything but distract from the opportunity that a new Republican majority in the Senate presents," an official of a major trade association said on Thursday. 
Today, some of those people were quick to pronounce Mr. Lott's retreat as the end of an unpleasant episode. 
"I think most Americans will conclude that Trent Lott did the decent thing, that the Republican leadership, including the president, chastised his statements, and that the party has shown its clear resolve to have zero-tolerance for insensitivity to these racial issues," the Florida Republican chairman, Al Cardenas, said. "And that the Republican Party is a mature and courageous party, moving forward."
Bill Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, said, "Lott is really virtually the last of the products of Richard Nixon's 'Southern strategy' to be in major positions of power in the Congress, and with his leaving, you will have cleared out people who, fairly or unfairly, have a somewhat compromised image to the country as a whole."
But the past may not be so easy to leave behind, given race's enduring hold over politics, from the Civil War and Reconstruction to the civil rights revolution and affirmative-action debates of today. For all Mr. Bush's desire to broaden the Republican appeal to black and Hispanic voters and for all his personal rejections of prejudice, he and his father before him have used the symbolism of the past to political advantage.
Indeed, no sooner had Mr. Lott stepped down, sped by Mr. Bush's stern condemnation, than the president's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, found himself faced with renewed questions from reporters about whether Mr. Bush regretted his visit in 2000 to Bob Jones University, which then banned interracial dating.
By midday, Democrats were circulating questions about the civil rights records of Mr. Lott's all-but-certain successor, Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, and the new chairman of the party's Senate campaign committee, George F. Allen of Virginia, including Mr. Allen's acknowledgment that he once had the Confederate battle flag in his living room.
Mr. Lott's departure from the leadership will do nothing to increase the Republicans' narrow working control of the Senate, and Democrats predicted that their party would be emboldened to press issues of its own that might have otherwise languished, including expanding the earned-income tax credit for the working poor as part of any Republican drive for deeper tax cuts.
Some Democrats have even suggested the possibility of bringing up other issues previously thought to have little hope of passing, including an increase in the minimum wage, legislation banning racial profiling, increased financing to combat AIDS and the like.
But in other ways, having helped to oust Mr. Lott by his strong public comments and his aides' private lobbying, Mr. Bush will be riding higher than ever on Capitol Hill, with the help of a close friend and telegenic new Senate leader in Mr. Frist, a transplant surgeon who has a conservative record but also embodies the face of the New South as surely as Mr. Lott evoked the Mississippi ghosts of 40 years ago.
"It could be a hangover for them, or it could be cathartic," said Don Fowler, a former Democratic national chairman from South Carolina. "It is clear to anyone who has been involved in this process for as long as I have that underlying the Republican revolution of the last 30 or 40 years has been a deep-seated undercurrent of racism. And what Trent Lott has said and done just peels that right back and makes it clear to anybody who wants to look at it.
"What this has done is created an opportunity for Republicans to cleanse themselves by casting Senator Lott out of the temple, and that might serve to be therapeutic. I don't know." 
Mr. Fowler also said it was possible that Mr. Lott's serial apologies might "alienate some of their base" and drive some Republicans to vote Democratic because of economic interests.
Mr. Cardenas, the Florida Republican chairman, said he believed that "the burden shifts to the Democrats" to explain, justify and account for racially charged comments made over the years by party officials. Some Democrats cautioned quietly of the risks of overplaying their hand, lest they, too, be accused of playing the race card and fanning the controversy.
But at least one prominent Southern Democrat spoke out with unusual forcefulness. This week, before Mr. Lott stepped down, former President Bill Clinton told CNN that he was being scapegoated for saying out loud what Republican strategists have known privately for years.
"How do they think they got a majority in the South, anyway?" Mr. Clinton asked. "I think what they are really upset about is that he made public their strategy."
What upset some conservatives most was Mr. Lott's increasingly effusive apologies, including one on Black Entertainment Television this week.
"That tended to cast a racial shadow over many legitimate and widely held conservative views," said Douglas J. Besharov, a welfare policy expert at the American Enterprise Institute. "They can be wrong. But they're widely held, and they're innocent of racial animus." 
Mr. Besharov said it was hard to predict the ultimate effects of Mr. Lott's case on public policy.
"There's been talk all around town," he said, "that the president wants to reform various social programs from the 60's, modernize them, not abandon them, but update them. This would cause me, if I were in the White House, to think twice about that."
