HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Newtown, Conn.; 
Debate on Developing Old Hospital Site

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: NEWTOWN, Conn. 

 BODY:
ON a 189-acre spread of pastoral land where deer, foxes, pheasant, wild turkey, rabbits and groundhogs thrive under a hunting ban, the defunct state-owned Fairfield Hills Hospital sits forlornly. The 16 massive, deteriorating brick buildings of the former psychiatric center, with a total of 1 million square feet, and several outbuildings are vacant except for one that houses satellite town offices.
 Contracts conveying the land and buildings from the state to the town for a purchase price of $3.9 million have been expected since the allocation was approved by the town voters in June of last year, but there is no deadline. "I thought we would be finished by now," said Herbert C. Rosenthal, Newtown's first selectman, "but I'm optimistic that the lawyers and the Office of Policy and Management will have a contract and a deed by June 30 of 2003." 
 The question is, What then? The potential for developing hundreds of thousands of square feet of offices, hundreds of units of housing, thousands of square feet of retail space, a hotel and other uses has the town deeply divided. Not surprisingly, there is a wide difference of opinion among residents about whether buildings should be torn down and about what kinds of development should be allowed. Some are not swayed by the prospect of substantial tax revenues from commercial and residential development and favor limiting development to open space, a new Town Hall, municipal playing fields and cultural activities in the existing buildings. 
Newtown is a 60-square-mile residential community of 25,000 people, where the average price of a home is $500,000. A recent public opinion poll produced conflicting results. Respondents to questionnaires distributed by The Newtown Bee, a local newspaper, revealed that economic development was generally favored for producing revenues, but options for developing specific commercial projects that would generate such revenues were all met with disfavor.
"Economic development is the biggest point of contention," Mr. Rosenthal said. "It probably would be better for the town and for developers to demolish some buildings and have open land that can be built on. We're pressed for housing." 
With the state's 12th-highest median income, at $90,000 per household, Newtown implemented its own regulation requiring that new multifamily housing contain 20 percent affordable units, but only one complex, River View, is in compliance. "We're not even close to the 10 percent per town that the state wants," Mr. Rosenthal said. 
At the same time, there is resistance to allowing open space to be overrun with development. "Newtown is concerned about housing pressure from too-expensive lower Fairfield County," said Richard A. Harral, principal in the planning firm of Harral Michalowski Associates, which was hired by Newtown in 1999 to come up with a master plan for the property. It will be presented to the town early next year.
"It costs $8,000 a year to educate a child," Mr. Harral said. "Houses don't pay that in taxes. There is also concern for open space and the loss of it through housing." 
Mr. Harral has been working with the Fairfield Hills Committee, appointed by Mr. Rosenthal. He indicated that the master plan would probably designate half the property for municipal, educational, cultural and recreational uses, and most of the rest would be commercial, with minor amounts of housing and small stores. Half the existing buildings would probably be torn down. The town will retain ownership of the land, no matter how the existing buildings and new construction are developed.
THE town has approved issuing bonds to raise $21.8 million to cover removal of asbestos and lead paint, demolition or rehabilitation of some buildings, insurance against unknown environmental liabilities, creation of a new Town Hall on the site, preparing a master reuse plan and securing water rights. The payments would be spread out over three years beginning in 2004, according to Ben Spragg, Newtown's financial director. "Tax increases would be gradual," he said. "$7 million a year accounts for just four-tenths of a mill."
Newtown homeowners pay 33.8 mills, or tax dollars, for every $1,000 of assessed value, while towns it sometimes compares itself with keep taxes low with commercial development. Greenwich, for example, has a mill rate of 10.3, New Canaan, 13.2 and Darien, 14.98, but house prices are extremely high. Some argue that lower house prices in Newtown mitigate the higher tax rate. 
Newtown's state representative, Julia Wasserman, a Republican, said: "In the early 90's, there was a hue and cry for more commercial land in Newtown. Business people have said at public hearings that we need more space for corporate offices and commercial development." 
In 1992, when the hospital closing was decided, the State Legislature established a study committee for disposing of the property. It was then an 800-acre tract with 60 buildings, including the remains of a former farm with a piggery, dairy barn, greenhouses, slaughterhouse, root cellar and a barn for 37 horses of the Governor's Horse Guard. 
Richard Nuclo, director of asset management for the Office of Policy and Management, said: "Through legislation, 350 acres was given to the Department of Agriculture for haying, experimental farming and open space; the Garner Correctional Facility got 114 acres; 22 linear acres were created on both sides of Deep Brook; and various other allocations of land went to the Governor's Horse Guard, a power plant and a new sewer plant. Seventy-five acres were allocated for Wasserman's Way, a new east-west road through the property that connects Route 25 on the west end to the intersection of Interstate 84 and Route 34 on the east end. The hospital remained on its 189 acres." 
Ms. Wasserman said: "People don't realize that they have all that state-owned acreage in open space. The town is correct in purchasing the hospital property, but it can't rush into a finite plan. I would love to see one of the biotech or pharmaceutical companies move into some of the existing buildings."
How the property is developed will be determined by the town's Planning and Zoning Commission after public hearings. Despite mixed use zoning, developers of housing and commercial projects would have to apply for special exceptions, said Elizabeth Stocker, community development director. 
The Harral Michalowski plan synthesizes and embellishes several plans that have been floated over the years. In 1998 the state, unhappy about spending $1.2 million annually to maintain empty property, put out requests for proposals from developers. Three were chosen out of 12 responses.
Becker & Becker in New Canaan turned in a mixed-use plan for preserving all the buildings for municipal offices, a school, 200,000 square feet of offices, 100 units of housing with a 20 percent affordable component, 200 other units restricted to those over age 55 and a regional Y.M.C.A. The plan would have added a swimming pool at the Y.M.C.A., but no other new construction.
Wilder Balter Partners of Westchester proposed an 18-hole golf course and a mix of housing for families and people 55 and older, and a central cluster of about 25,000 square feet with small stores and restaurant space. It called for demolishing all buildings. "They are functionally obsolete," said Robert Wilder, the firm's principal, "and a huge deduction of the value of the property."
Spectrum Skanska of Westchester offered a plan for 575 units of housing for people 55 and older and combination residences and studios for artists and craftsmen. Additional uses would include 45,000 square feet of local retail, a country inn, a children's museum and a choice of three sites on which the town could build a new school. 
A year later, all three proposals were tabled by the state when the town decided it would buy the property rather than lose control to an outside developer. The three developers, who had spent a year and from a few hundred thousand dollars to $1 million each on preparing and presenting their proposals, were not amused. Mitchell C. Hochberg, a partner in Spectrum Skanska, is still smarting from the abrupt cutoff. "After a year the state said never mind, we're selling it to the town," he said.
According to Mr. Nuclo, the state made it clear to developers that the Office of Policy and Management is legally required to offer surplus state property to the town in which it is located and that therefore the developers were taking the assignment at their own risk. "As soon as we heard from Mr. Rosenthal that the town wanted to pick up its option of first refusal, we called the developers and followed up with a letter," he said.
Mr. Wilder argued that the situation was not quite that simple. "The problem was when a town spends three years working with the state to come up with a mixed use zoning ordinance and the state then sends out a request for proposals, you are led to believe the town is not going to buy the property," he said. "The state wanted out in the worst way, and it has not been a winner in this. We offered $9 million."

HEADLINE: Hot Under the Buttoned-Down Collar 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
THE genteel town of Princeton is up to its buttoned-down collar in controversy over redoing its storybook downtown.
 With tempers raised and lawsuits threatened, the borough council last week approved a $13.5 million bond ordinance to finance the biggest downtown development project in this college town in almost 20 years. 
 Like so many older suburban towns facing smart growth issues, Princeton is struggling to retain its village-like character while competing with the lure of giant shopping malls. Unlike other municipalities, however, Princeton is home to the state's most prestigious university, where a symbiotic relationship requires that both the Ivy League school and the patrician town live up to a near impossible standard of taste and excellence.
And so the facelift will not go through without a fight. It was standing room only in the council chambers, where for three hours last Tuesday night the public expressed its opinion on the controversial project that will add a 5 1/2-level parking garage, a 15,000-square-foot public plaza, 77 apartments, a grocery store and 6,000 square feet of retail space to the heart of an already crowded downtown. 
"You have 100-120 people show up at a meeting to tell you how upset they are with this project," said one resident, Mark Freda, who seemed to express the sentiment of the majority of speakers. "You have a petition with over a thousand signatures, you have letters to the editor against it. Why are you still supporting this project as it is presently designed?"
Nonetheless, by the end of the evening, five of the six council members sided with the mayor in approving the financing, saying the development was need not only to ease parking problems but also to take better advantage of two underusedparcels of land in the heart of town. Through parking fees and land leases, the project is expected to pay for itself over the next 25 years, and, according to the mayor, generate additional revenue for the borough in the future.
"This is the last piece of space where we can do anything in town," said Mayor Marvin Reed. "In other towns people buy up older houses, then redevelop the land. We don't do that in Princeton. We can't afford to."
Of course, it is the very fact that it is the last piece of developable land in Princeton Borough that has turned this proposal into the most divisive issue to confront this community in recent history.
Critics of the proposed development have accused the borough council of acting in bad faith by ignoring growing opposition and pushing through a plan, the details of which were largely decided on behind closed doors. The plan, they say, will not solve the town's severe parking shortage, but rather create more traffic and put added pressure on Princeton's already ailing retail community. After last Tuesday's vote, they vowed to fight approval of the development plan itself, which the council is to vote on next month, with the threat of a lawsuit.
But for many, last week's vote signaled the end of a two-year dialogue about what to do with the two borough-owned parking lots on Spring Street between Witherspoon and Tulane Streets. The discussion began in September 2000, when a newly formed civic group, Princeton Future, took up the task of assessing how Princetonians felt about their town. 
"The idea was to assemble the talent in town on a volunteer basis, and figure out a way for people who know things to get together with the neighborhoods so the citizens could be more informed," said Sheldon Sturges, a cochairman of Princeton Future, along with Robert Goheen, a former president of Princeton University, and Robert Geddes, a former dean of the university's architecture school.
Over the next several months, the group met numerous times and held open panel discussions. Along the way, the borough council had contracted through Princeton Future the services of a Philadelphia firm, Brown & Keener, to develop a plan for the Spring Street lots. The plan Princeton Future came back with was called "Madison Square." Backing up to the site of a new public library, the design included a 24,800-square-foot civic square, 15,000 square feet of additional walkways and open space, a 25,000-square-foot marketplace, 18 apartments and a 483-space parking garage.

A Plan Evolved Over Months
Using this blueprint as a working model, the borough council began negotiating the specifics of the plan in closed sessions over the next seven months. Relying on a section of the state's Sunshine Law that allows government bodies to consider financial matters behind closed doors, the council heard proposals by five developers in private, ultimately choosing the design of Nassau HKT Associates, whose principal, Robert Powell, is a former borough councilman.
When the council emerged this June with a project that more than quadrupled the number of apartment units, significantly reduced the size of the public space, and added an extra level to the parking garage, many residents felt they had been sideswiped. One council member, Wendy Benchley, now concedes that the process might have gone more smoothly if the public had been let in on it sooner -- though her qualms did not stop her from approving the financing.
"I felt that the plans themselves and even the finances could have been out in the public domain faster," said Ms. Benchley. "But I also knew we had to negotiate with the developer privately in order to get the best deal we could."
As for the goodwill Princeton Future tried to foster, the end result was just the opposite. Many began seeing the group as an "elitist triumvirate" trying to foist its expertise on local residents.
"Princeton Future was set up for all the right reasons, but by the very nature of how it was set up, it was going to come to all the wrong conclusions," said David Newton, vice president of Palmer Square, the block-long retail center in downtown Princeton.
As a result of the squabbling, a new civic organization was formed, Concerned Citizens of Princeton, which spent the summer gathering signatures seeking a referendum on the proposed development. The group also distributed a survey to 1,000 households, asking residents' opinions of the project. Asked whether the council should approve or abandon the project, only 28 percent of the 670 respondents expressed their approval, 43 percent preferred to abandon it and 29 percent suggested revising the plans, said Herb Hobler, a resident here who developed the poll. On the question, "Do you feel the borough council should move forward without surveying the community?" 74 percent responded "no."
The poll was promptly dismissed by the council as biased when Mr. Hobler refused to disclose the name of the polling expert whom he consulted.
"I'm appalled by the resistance they seem to have to the opposition," said Mr. Hobler. "It doesn't surprise me that if you have a survey that you happen to disagree with the results, you're going to question it. But if they don't like it, then do their own survey."
Which is exactly what many residents have been urging the council to do, in the form of a nonbinding referendum.
"We were told that to get a referendum, we had to have 628 signatures, so we had 25 or 30 people working the streets in the heat of the summer," said Jim Firestone, the chief organizer of the opposition. "Three out of four people we talked to said, 'We don't want that.' "
After collecting almost 1,100 signatures and presenting them to the mayor, the group was told last month that because the land was being developed under the state's Local Redevelopment and Housing Law, previously reserved for blighted areas, the borough was exempt from a binding referendum usually required before financing a bond, although nothing precludes a nonbinding vote. The property in question, formerly the site of a PSE&G gasworks plant, is considered a brownfield, where the gas company is currently removing coal tar residue. 
"You have this prime property in the middle of town," said William Potter, a lawyer here. "To find it blighted just because PSE&G is cleaning it up, then to say, 'We have a trump card and you can't have your referendum,' that's not what the law and the constitution intended."
Mr. Potter said he warned council members that they "could end up in court, tying up this project for many years."
As the lone voice on the council against the proposed development, Roger Martindell has encouraged the citizens' grassroots efforts while lobbying his colleagues to slow the process and hold an advisory referendum to measure the pulse of the community.
"We don't have to run off to lawyers to see if we should seek input from the public," said Mr. Martindell, a lawyer himself. "It's controversial, there are a lot of people on both sides, and nobody can count noses. Shouldn't the voters have a say on something they're going to have to live with for the rest of their lives?"
The original impetus for redeveloping the two parcels of land was to find a solution to what most people agree is a severe parking problem in town. Between the demands of local residents, the estimated 1,000 restaurant and shop employees, spillover from the university and tourists, nearly all the metered parking spaces on the street are constantly occupied, as well much of the existing garage space. 
The town's merchants have been feeling the pinch, particularly in the last seven months since PSE&G closed the 189-space parking lot to clean it up. In surveying 30 area merchants, Mr. Firestone found that business has been off about 25 percent compared with the same period last year. The first casualty of the parking crunch was Pyramid Books, the used bookstore on Witherspoon Street that went out of business a couple of weeks ago, with Witherspoon Bread Company threatening to be next.

Stores Fear for Their Lives
Shopkeepers fear that disruption from construction of the development, which is being planned in two phases and could tie up the downtown for the next three years, will find more stores following in Pyramid's footsteps.
"If they do go through with this project, we'll see a lot of mom-and-pop stores go out of business, and that includes me," said Ray Wadsworth, owner of the Flower Market for the last 24 years, who joined a dozen other merchants last Tuesday night to oppose the project.
As the situation has become more critical, parking has risen to the top of the political agenda here, with the project becoming a leading campaign issue.
"I've been elected three times now and the last time I ran I made no bones about it that I was determined to work on this problem and find a solution, as I was elected to do," said Mayor Reed. He stopped short of the kinds of comments that one fellow council member, Peggy Karcher, was chastised for earlier this fall after she claimed she had a mandate to see this project through.
The new garage will have 500 parking spaces; however, after the loss of the two surface parking lots, allocating spaces for the new apartments and retail space, and giving over the 85 spaces promised to Princeton Township in front of the new library going up adjacent to the development, the borough will end up with about 60 new parking spots.
"They're going to create more parking, but they're also going to create a need for more parking, so what is the net gain?" asked Mitch Forest, the owner of Forest Jewelers on Nassau Street.
Alternative solutions to the parking problem have included creating a lot on the outskirts of town and shuttling workers, tapping into the underused space in the Palmer Square parking garage, opening up more on-street parking, or even, as one speaker suggested, putting the money toward building bike lanes throughout town. Mr. Martindell said he might have voted for the proposal if it had addressed these long-range planning issues.
"If we had included any of these alternatives, the project would have probably won my vote," he said. "Instead, we've got a garage that's too big, that will cause a major disruption and that will adversely affect the quality of life in town. We're going to end up being more like a downtown Trenton or New Brunswick, and not a town I look forward to living in."
Notably quiet throughout most of the discussions has been Princeton University, except in the role its two former leaders have played in Princeton Future. Often criticized for not doing more for the borough of Princeton, the largest landowner in town has again come under fire by residents like Bob Zagoria, a Princeton alumnus, who calls the university the "elephant in the room that nobody seems to see."
"The university has said it has a vested interest in the future of this town," said Mr. Zagoria. "When they recruit professors or students, they're selling this town as part of the attraction. They have an $8 billion endowment. They're the obvious party to step in and help when the town is hurting."
As a charitable tax-exempt institution, much of the university's property cannot be taxed by the borough. But Pam Hersh, Princeton's director of community and state affairs, said the university was still the biggest taxpayer in town by virtue of the numerous properties it has on the tax rolls. In addition to the $2 million in taxes and $1 million in sewer fees that Ms. Hersh said the university paid the borough each year, she noted that Princeton had provided large gifts for major projects in town, like the new library and borough hall landscaping, that average a quarter-million dollars a year. The borough has also recently renegotiated the university's voluntary contribution, which will rise from the current level of $100,000 a year to about $400,000 in the next five years.

University Defends Its Role
"I'd be the first one to come down on the university if I thought they didn't care, but we do a really good job," said Ms. Hersh, who questioned the idea that the town is hurting. "This is a healthy town and it's healthy because we contribute about a billion dollars in economic activity here. If we weren't here, it wouldn't be so healthy." As to tapping into its endowment funds, Ms. Hersh said that money went toward financial aid programs. 
"People look at our endowment as though it is their endowment," she said, "but we happen to be serving a higher purpose here. We're here to educate kids, not to build municipal garages"
In addition to the garage, the 77 proposed apartments are also stirring up controversy. With 12 units being designated affordable housing, the apartments have been praised as a chance to add more diversity to Princeton's population. Six of the units will be set aside for low-income and six for moderate-income tenants. The rest are expected to rent for about $3,000 a month. Mr. Firestone said promoting this project in the name of diversity was absurd.
"With this project, we're going to lose the diversity of this town," he said. "Because when the restaurants and shops start closing, all those low-income workers who now walk to work are going to have to move out of town."
While he is personally unable to afford a court action, Mr. Firestone said others were talking about putting their money together to file a lawsuit seeking a referendum.
"I don't think this is over," he said. "With people going out of business one after another, nobody's talking about walking away. Would you be willing to walk away if you thought your rights were being taken away from you?"

HEADLINE: Lighting Up The Stage, The World 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART

DATELINE: PURCHASE 

 BODY:
JENNIFER SCHRIEVER saw "Phantom of the Opera," her first Broadway play, as a teenager, and what bowled her over was not the acting or the music or the chandelier but the lighting. "I connected with it right away," she said.
 Immediately, she said, "I knew this was something I wanted to do." 
 She experimented with lights at Ridgewood High School in New Jersey, spotlighting the honor society inductees and "hitting the drum and players" of the jazz band with orange lights surrounded by deep blues. "Really sexy for high school," she said. 
Now, as a junior in lighting design at Purchase College, she is one of a few dozen students learning a skill that is more and more in demand, not just in show business but by museums, restaurants, cruise ships and department stores. 
Still, because the Purchase program is part of its Conservatory of Theater Arts and Film Department, many students have their hearts set on show business, where jobs, especially in New York, are "extraordinarily tight," said Daniel Hennesian, the conservatory director. That in fact is Ms. Shriever's dream: Broadway, Off Broadway, the opera or the ballet -- anything, as long as it's in New York. Others, like Sarissa Michaud, are leaning toward something more specific, in her case, dance. 
Lighting design occupies a peculiar niche -- an art that is ephemeral and intangible, that almost never exists by itself.
"It's the air we breathe," said Michael J. Cesario, head of graduate studies at the Theater Arts Department. "You know how some days there's electricity in the air? Or the reverse? You can show that with lighting."
Lighting design has been taught at Purchase since the early 1970's, shortly after the college's creation, a time when rock concerts, with their wild, pulsing lights, were expanding its possibilities.
Bill Mintzer, a Broadway designer, founded the program with ideas that are still central to it: that lighting is as important to a show as acting or sets and that lighting designers should know not only theater arts inside and out but should also be able to articulate their feelings about a show.
Nevertheless, audiences rarely notice the lighting. They leave a show talking about the actors, the music, the sets or costumes but hardly ever the lighting.
"The only time our stuff is noticed is when it's bad," said David Grill, a Purchase teacher and graduate who recently completed the lighting design for Radio City Music Hall's "Christmas Spectacular."
But bad lighting, he said, can turn beauties into hags. Skillful work -- perhaps amber combined with other warm colors -- can remove wrinkles and years from an actor's face, he said. Lighting can also can create storms or sunshine. It can move the play seamlessly and quickly through time and space.
"It's telling the audience what to look at and what to feel," said Mr. Cesario. "How do you help a character be happy or sad? What color is the nighttime sky? Most people say blue. But is it blue and lavender and black and puffy gray with red in the distance? Is a sunlit room warm amber? Or bright and sharp?"
Only a handful of universities offer lighting design as an academic degree program and at nearly all, it is a graduate degree. But Purchase offers both bachelor's and master's degrees, which are nearly identical. There are six lighting design professors, most of whom also work on Broadway or at the opera or ballet and who have several Emmys and Tonys among them.
Currently, there are 30 undergraduates and two graduates majoring in lighting design. Graduate degrees are for students unfortunate enough to have chosen another school first, said Mr. Cesario.
That approach is a bit controversial among theater academicians.
"You put kids 18, 19, 20 immediately into lighting design and they're too young," said Ming Cho Lee, chairman of the Design Department Yale University School of Drama. "You need to study the history of architecture, the history of art and music and literature. You need to know why the plays were written, what is the content, how it relates to society. So you need economics and political science. Otherwise you're just doing lighting as spectacle."
Mr. Cesario has heard that before. It still makes him raise his voice.
"Yes, we take 18- and 19-year-olds!" he shouted. "Yes, we assume that at 18 they're grounded. Can 18-year-olds make a choice about their life's work? We say they can. Can a 20-year-old understand the emotional depths of plays? We say they can. Not just any 18-year-olds. We won't take any, 'Hey, that looks like fun!' kids. But the kids we graduate with bachelor's degrees are ready for jobs and when others are still in graduate school, they'll be out there working."
Six or seven undergraduates nodded knowingly as he spoke. Purchase undergraduates begin to study lighting design in their sophomore year. They study the tools: color theory, electricity, mechanics and technique. They use a lab with about 50 lighting devices -- lights, dimmers, a computer to control them. They use mannequins to learn about the effects of angles, shadows and degrees of brightness and then transpose what they have learned to performers.
Out of the lab, they are steeped in the liberal arts of the theater: philosophy, history, plays as literature and costume and design. They also learn to write and to articulate their opinions and feelings about a work. "They have to be able to sell a director on their ideas," said Mr. Cesario. "They don't just walk in to the director and say, 'Tell me what you want.' They say, 'This is what I want.' They know the play with their gut and intellect. So if the director yells: 'Give me more blue!' they know it's odd icy crystal blue, not a soft blue."
They are taught that the core of the lighting decision for each play is a personal image, which should be concrete but should not necessarily come directly from the play. The image that Ms. Michaud, 21, chose for "A Streetcar Named Desire" was a delicate Faberge egg clutched and gradually crushed by the sweaty hand of a laborer. As the play progresses and Blanche DuBois slides into insanity, the color of the lighting, like the sweat-dissolved dye of the egg, becomes washed out and faded.
Ken Posner, a Purchase graduate who designed lighting for the Broadway show "Hairspray," said he was not upset that the actors and musicians and set and costume designers get all the applause. "The one occupation in theater that's fairly egoless is the lighting designer," he said.
But Ms. Michaud does not agree. "That's why a lot of lighting designers are cocky," she said. "If the lights aren't on, nobody's going to see you."

Far left: Ken Posner, a Purchase graduate and lighting designer of the show "Hairspray" at the Neil Simon Theater in Manhattan. (Photographs by Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times); (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
The Tax ClockIs Ticking. Quick: Pick a Charity.

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
LOOK at the calendar. It's almost the last minute, and you still haven't decided which charitable groups will receive your end-of-year checks. You have this week to do a little research.
 Baby boomers aren't the most generous generation, but they're not bad. Statistics from Independent Sector, an association of nonprofit groups in Washington, show that people aged 40 to 49 gave, on average, $1,827 in 2000, the most recent numbers available. That's a bit more than the amount from younger age groups, but not as much as from 50- to 64-year-olds, a mix of boomers and people who were born just before and during World War II. They gave $1,912, on average. 
 But boomers are also pressed for time, or at least we complain that we are. So we often give without checking to see if the charity is worthy of our money. Luckily, there are organizations that do the research for us, and the one I found easiest to use is the Charity Rating Guide and Watchdog Report from the American Institute of Philanthropy in Chicago (www.charitywatch.org; 773 529-2300).
Using various criteria, the institute gives hundreds of charities letter grades, from A+ to F, making the process as simple as looking at your child's report card. And like the teacher's note that accompanies that card, the guide also explains how an organization ended up with its grade.
My dad died a couple of years ago from a type of lung cancer, so I'm curious about cancer charities. The guide breaks down charities by category; the cancer group has 23. Of those, five received A's, six got B's, two C's, two D's and eight F's. Of the A's, two received the highest grade of A+: the Cancer Research Institute of Manhattan and the Foundation for the Children's Oncology Group, now called the National Childhood Cancer Foundation of Bethesda, Md.
The guide measures the percentage of a charity's expenses that are spent on program services instead of on fund-raising or administration. Usually, the higher the percentage spent on services, the higher the grade. Both the A+ cancer charities had more than 90 percent of their expenses going to program services; the guide says the percentage should be 60 percent or more.
Along with that, their cost of rasing money was low, $10 or less to raise $100. The guide says that cost should be $35 or less. One of the cancer charities that received an F, the National Cancer Center of Plainview, N.Y., had 7 percent of its expenses going toward services and spent $81 to raise $100, according the the guide.
Of the more than 400 charities rated by the guide, 155 received A's, including 26 at A+; there were 58 F's.
Jeanne Gillert, the grants manager of the foundations of the Zarrow families in Tulsa, Okla., that were in the oil field services business, said she uses the guide all the time.
"It's a quick-and-dirty way to easily look and see how an agency is doing and how they are doing in their category," she said. "You can look at services to youth and see how the Boy Scouts compare to the Girl Scouts." (The girls get an A-, but the boys get a C for reasons I'll get into below. It's not as simple as girls rule, boys drool.)
Ms. Gillert said the guide is just one resource for her. She also looks at a charity's Internal Revenue Service Form 990, which gives a more complete breakdown of revenue and expenses. These forms, also used by the guide to arrive at its grades, are available at www.guidestar.com. Another resource is the site of the Better Business Bureau Wise Giving Alliance, at www.give.org, which also evaluates charities and breaks down their numbers.
Pat Nolan, program director of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, a volunteer service organization in Washington, said she has been using the institute's guide for about five years.
"I can use the guide and tell our president, 'This is a very good group,' " she said. "I could also steer her away from a particular group if it didn't do well in the guide."
THIS is where the Boy Scouts' problem comes in. Just because a group received a poor letter grade doesn't mean it is unworthy. The guide reduces an otherwise good grade if a group has what the guide deems as large financial reserves (the idea being that other charities need the money more). The Boy Scouts would have received an A, but got that C because they had four years of reserves. 
But Ms. Gillert said a lot of assets aren't necessarily bad. "I like to see agencies with three years of reserves for times just like these in the economy," she said. "That way, they are stable and can ride the ups and downs that come with fund-raising."
Sara E. Melendez, the chief executive of Independent Sector, also urged caution when using a guide.
"It may not be a compete picture," she said. "A group may have invested in computers one year, so administrative costs have gone up, but their services haven't changed."
That's why donors should do more active research of charities, she said.
"Go visit them and offer to volunteer," she said. "There is no better way to know what an organization is like than by volunteering with them. You get to know them and see if the money is wisely spent."
Of course, that bumps into our lament that we're too busy. Nothing is ever easy, even giving our money away.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
From President to Prof

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLL 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK 

 BODY:
THERE is grade inflation. Then there is inflation.
 At least that is the way some former colleagues see the recent appointment of Francis L. Lawrence, the former president of Rutgers, who will be returning to the classroom in the spring with a salary of $225,000. 
 Dr. Lawrence weathered many storms during his 12-year tenure -- including a controversy over remarks in 1995 linking genetics to test scores -- and now he faces another.
"This is obscene, a travesty, and a slap in the face to the whole Rutgers family," said William C. Dowling, a professor of English at the university. "Fran Lawrence does not have a publication record that would earn him a teaching job at Rutgers in even our weakest department."
According to the university, when Dr. Lawrence returns to teach and lecture here and at the Camden campus he will hold the title "university professor" and head the Center for Organizational Development and Leadership Roundtable within the communications department, where he will organize forums among leaders in education, business, health care and government.
Not that Dr. Lawrence is a stranger to the classroom. During his time here he presented guest lectures, though he never taught a course. Before coming to Rutgers, Dr. Lawrence -- who has degrees from St. Louis University and Tulane University -- held the title of distinguished professor at Tulane, where he was provost, academic vice president, dean of the graduate school and taught 17-century French literature.
"By his own choosing he did not teach a full course because he knew that given the demands of a full presidency he would miss classes and that would be unfair to the students," said Mark Maben, a spokesman for Rutgers.
Others on campus were less generous.
Professor Dowling complained: "Letting Fran Lawrence teach a course in leadership is like bringing Dr. Kevorkian in to run your hospice operation at a local hospital. He is notoriously the worst at the thing he will be teaching."
Thomas J. Figueira, a professor of classics and ancient history and who heads the university's faculty association, told The Philadelphia Inquirer: "He is almost entirely unqualified for the position. He has none of the credentials you would expect for a top-line scholar."
Dr. Lawrence was on vacation and unavailable for comment, according to Mr. Maben.
As president, he earned $287,000 a year and received a $75,000 stipend for fund-raising activities. Dr. Lawrence, who weathered growing discontent among the members of the faculty, stepped down in February when his Republican supporters lost power in Trenton and new Democratic governor and a changed Legislature took over.
There are currently 17 professors at Rutgers who earn more than $200,000 a year, Mr. Maben said, with the highest paid being Kenneth Breslauer of the chemistry department.
To be sure, when Dr. Lawrence left he was not without his supporters, who pointed out that under his leadership the university's fund-raising increased nearly fivefold, faculty research almost tripled and the percentage of minority students doubled.
Last week, Gustav Friedrich, dean of the Rutgers School of Communication, Information and Library Studies, praised Dr. Lawrence's work and said the students would benefit greatly.
"He has many decades of teaching experience," Dr. Friedrich said, "and he has a wealth of experience in leadership, so he will bring a lot of talent to the students."

HEADLINE: Business; 
It's Not Too Late to Reinvent Your Own Wheel

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
 HERMINIA IBARRA, the author of "Working Identity: Unconventional Strategies for Reinventing Your Career," argues that economic, social and technological forces will continue to encourage midcareer professionals to reinvent themselves. Following are excerpts from a telephone interview in Paris, where she lives. WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

Q. You say that more people are reinventing themselves now than two decades ago. How do you know that?

A. We don't have a good count. Anecdotally, most people have seen people around them make pretty big changes in what they do for a living. We just don't have the comparative data. But I think there are strong economic forces and some social forces behind this trend. Economically, we've been through a real boom economy. Until very recently, people haven't been as focused on mere survival. It's the classic hierarchy of needs. When your economic needs are satisfied, you move into the realm of self-actualization: "What would I really like to do?"
Another effect of the economic boom was that people saw other people doing new and different things. That encouraged them to give it a try: "If so and so has made a much more fulfilling life as a free agent, maybe I don't have to stay stuck in something I don't see as fulfilling."

Q. What are the social forces behind the trend?

A. Maybe because we spend more time at work, people expect more and more out of it. Maybe 30 years ago, I put in my hours whether the job was interesting or not. People nowadays expect much more out of their jobs in terms of fulfillment and challenge. Yet at the same time, they want to strike a better work-life balance. Another aspect is that the employment contract has broken down over the past 15 years. Employers are saying: "Look out for yourselves. Maybe we can better equip you for the next job. But don't expect a job for life."

Q. Is professional career change largely an American phenomenon?

A. Not at all. In Continental Europe, the social contract has been strong. Companies have had somewhat less freedom to downsize until recently, but now that is breaking down. The United Kingdom has been closest to the American model, but I'm seeing a lot of interest in this subject here in France. Reinvention isn't as easy to do here as it is in the United States.

Q. Why is reinvention easier in the United States?

A. The Americans have a culture that says reinvention is good. It's a place where you want to create a new life. That has not been the history in Europe. Here the school system is different and institutions are different. Historically, people have been encouraged to stick to the path they choose early in life, in high school. But that has been breaking down.

Q. What is the intellectual contribution of your book?

A. I would say there are two major contributions. One is that when you're making a very big change, there is a period when you're truly in between. You're exploring many possibilities but you're not wedded to any, including your own job. There is a limbo-like period.
The other major contribution, and I would rank this higher than the first, is that the way we make progress is by experimenting about what I call "possible selves." It's not that self-reflection or self-assessment is useless. But a lot of times the only way we learn about ourselves is by doing, by testing. We may have an idea of what it's like to become a teacher at age 40 and develop that in our minds and take tests that show our aptitude. But all that means nothing until we actually try it.
So my most important argument is: Do not try to figure it all out before you make a move. Use small steps. You can't make a big move in the dark. You need more information. And the only actionable information comes from experimenting and interacting with people in that area you're exploring.

Q. Is the trend toward career reinvention permanent?

A. I think it's a trend we're going to continue to see. When I started this project in early 1999, everybody said what a great time for this topic. Of course, that was a time when people were making changes to take advantage of the incredible economy. Over the past year or two, people tell me it's a great time for this book because the economy has sunk to these depths. The economic factors seem to cancel each other out.
I think there are some underlying forces having to do with the knowledge economy and globalization that will continue to push this trend. People expect to get a lot out of work, and they want to do it increasingly on their own terms.
Technology is another major force. People have information about and exposure to different possibilities. There is much more information available online, for example. How many people do you know who work from their homes today compared with 15 years ago?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Herminia Ibarra

HEADLINE: CITIES; 
In Pennsauken, Winners and Losers

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: PENNSAUKEN 

 BODY:
AT first glance, this faded township of about 36,000 made up largely of homes that sprang up in the prosperous years after World War II -- would hardly seem like a place where someone would want to sink $24 million.
 But that is exactly what James B. Kennedy, executive director of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, is doing -- even after he said, "If you are at all familiar with Pennsauken, it's a dump." 
 Nonetheless, last month the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority approved $24 million for development of an arena here to seat from 5,000 to 7,000 spectators, which is expected to cost about $65 million. The remaining $41 million is expected to come from bonds issued by the Camden County Improvement Authority.
At a time when more and more cities view stadiums and arenas as a panacea for impoverished urban cores, the selection of Pennsauken -- situated on the Delaware River between Camden and Trenton -- is puzzling to some, particularly with the state committed to resuscitating neighboring Camden with a $175-million infusion and the gaze of two state-appointed officials. 
"If you are going to have an arena, you should put it in the largest city in the area," said Ali Sloan-El, a Camden City Councilman. "It only makes sense."
But an arena in Camden did not fit in with the plans of George Norcross III -- widely regarded as the political boss of South Jersey and a close ally of Governor McGreevey -- who has for years been shopping for a place to house a minor league hockey franchise. Mr. Norcross, an executive with the Commerce Bank, could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Sloan-El is not the only person to question the selection of Pennsauken as the site of what is being called the South Jersey Civic and Conference Center, an arena with other rooms for meetings and other events.
Development of a 35-acre site here -- bounded by a labyrinth of highways made up of State Routes 90 and 73 and U.S. Route 130 -- would mean the uprooting of the Pennsauken Mart, a shabby collection of 150 stores. The Can-Can, a strip club, and the South Jersey Expo Center, would also go.
"It would do better in a depressed place like Camden, which needs as much enhancement as it can get," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers.
State Senator Diane Allen, a Republican whose district includes Pennsauken, said she would be pleased if things worked out, though "I haven't seen any drawings or heard any specifics."
But Assemblyman Guy R. Gregg, a Republican from Sussex County who is a vocal opponent of spending state funds for sports or entertainment projects, questioned the need for a minor league hockey arena given the economic climate. "If Mr. Norcross wanted to spend his own money to build it, I'd be all for it," said Mr. Gregg.
Then, even more sarcastically, Mr Gregg continued: "I admire his creativity, getting all that money from C.R.D.A. I'm stunned that the people of Atlantic County aren't wondering why that money isn't going to build roads or schools there."
For now, there is no tenant for the proposed center other than a hockey team, and the vendors at Pennsauken Mart have questioned whether the arena is needed, particularly when the price is their livelihoods.
"I've been here 14 years and this is the first time the Mart has been 100 percent occupied that I can see," Gary Belfus of M&M Lock at the mart said one recent Sunday morning. "We have a wonderful clientele here and there is all this free property nearby in Camden for an arena. I don't understand, except they view the mart as downscale. This business has been in the family for 50 years and lots of kids have gone to college on it."
Not that Pennsauken was Mr. Norcross's first choice for a hockey team. Initially, he focused on Lawnside, an historic middle-class black community. State Senator Wayne Bryant, a Democrat from Lawnside, and his brother, Mark, who is the town's mayor, were both pushing a site on the edge of town. But residents did not want the disruptions. Then the campus of Camden County College in Gloucester Township was considered but dismissed as being too far from major highways.
While Mr. Norcross was looking for a location, various groups in Camden lobbied for the arena, though they said their interest was summarily dismissed. "This is George Norcross, and he wanted it somewhere else, so that is where the politicians in his pocket will put it," Mr. Sloan-El charged.
Merchants at the Pennsauken Mart have been presented with an alternative location on the busy Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Camden, part of which was bulldozed before the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia in the summer of 2000 so that visitors passing through would not be greeted with a scarred landscape.
Camden's city attorney, Christine Tucker, said the city would go along with any plan to attract businesses, which have been fleeing for 40 years. "Our residents just don't have many places to shop," said Ms. Tucker.
While questions have arisen about the location of the arena and its potential for success, the Casino Reinvestment and Development Authority as well as the Camden County Improvement Authority seem to have no such qualms. "We looked for funding in many ways, but until the C.R.D.A. money came through, I don't think we could have done it," said Philip P. Rowan, executive director of the improvement authority.
The $24 million grant for the Pennsauken arena is the largest amount that the agency has spent outside Atlantic City -- for what Mr. Kennedy characterized as "a dump."
"I think Mr. Kennedy regrets that statement," said John J. Tarditi Jr., a Haddonfield borough commissioner and Commerce Bank executive who is a partner with Mr. Norcross in the hockey franchise. "But what is good about the Pennsauken site is that it is adjacent to so many major roadways."
While most of those lobbying for the arena would certainly not characterize Pennsauken -- at least publicly -- as a dump, they do say the area qualifies for outside assistance.
"We consider Pennsauken part of the urban core, said Mr. Rowan. "It is not just an inner-ring suburb, but a place with 50-year-old housing and industrial and commercial areas that need redevelopment."
Pennsauken itself has hired a consultant, Public Solutions Inc. of Haddonfield, to help determine how to redevelop the non-residential sections of town. It hopes to eventually refurbish some areas along the Delaware north of Camden, but first wants to concentrate on the area of Pennsauken Mart, said Louis S. Bezich, the president of Public Solutions and an ally of Mr. Norcross.
"The demographics are just right there for this kind of arena," said Mr. Bezich. "Certainly this is a positive for Pennsauken. We have figured it would bring in $1.5 million a year in jobs and contracts. And though there would be a loss of some tax revenue for the public project, it would make the redevelopment of the surrounding site for offices, housing, restaurants, maybe even a hotel that much more attractive."
It is Mr. Bezich's use of the word "demographics" that burns in the ear of opponents like Mr. Sloan-El, who scoffs at using funds intended to for inner cities to build a hockey arena that will primarily cater to middle- and upper middle-class suburbanites.
"Do you think there will be many African-American or Latino construction jobs there?" asked Mr. Sloan-El. "Do you think it will cater to those patrons?"
Defending the hockey team, Mr. Rowan said that "you need an anchor tenant for these arenas."
He added: "If it weren't for George Norcross's hockey team, we wouldn't have that. But it will only account for 11 percent of the uses. There will be conferences and small conventions and scholastic sports events and concerts."
Mr. Rowan's optimism about the profitability of an arena here is not shared by everyone. Dr. Hughes of Rutgers said that at best the arena would be a money-losing attraction for other businesses.
"The Sovereign Bank Arena in Trenton, for instance, is not self-supportive, and we have no other similar arenas to compare it to," he said. "Even the Meadowlands development. The best you can say is that it brought other office buildings to Secaucus and enhanced its image somewhat."
But Jeffrey Nash, the Democratic director of the Camden County freeholder board and an ally of Mr. Norcross, said the region needed its own arena.
"Every time there is a big high school basketball game or an indoor track championship, it always goes to Newark or New Brunswick or Elizabeth, maybe sometimes to Atlantic City," Mr. Nash said. "When Camden had its great basketball team a couple of years ago with Dujuan Wagner and they played Roman Catholic High School from Philadelphia, they had to do it at Temple University because there was nothing that could hold it here. Graduations, school concerts, gymnastics meets, even local board meetings should have a place to go. I am sure hockey will be a big attraction."
Yet the record of how minor league indoor professional teams have fared would seem to undercut such confidence. Attendance at the Sovereign Bank Arena where the Trenton Titans, a minor league hockey team, play has declined. In 1999. the Titans' first season, more than 7,000 fans attended each game; so far this year only about 5,600 have come. The Boardwalk Bullies, Atlantic City's minor league hockey team, attracts fewer than 3,000 spectators a game.
Other sports have done even worse. The Trenton Shooting Stars of the International Basketball League, despite a winning record, disbanded after two seasons because of sparse attendance. The Lightning, Trenton's entry in the Indoor Professional Football League, ceased operations after only five games in 2001.
Still, the plan to raze Pennsauken Mart and move it to the Admiral Wilson Boulevard is a notion that has intrigued Mr Rowan, who would like to see someone take over an abandoned 15-acre parcel. To try to make this happen, Mr. Rowan said he was to meet with Eliot Kattan, the mart's owner, though Mr. Kattan's tenants are skeptical.
"This is a good business here," said Rita Ponomarev, who has owned Rita's Candies at the Pennsauken Mart for six years. "We work hard. But what can I do if they close us down? Nothing."
However, Mr. Nash, the freeholder director, had a lower opinion of the Pennsauken Mart -- with shops featuring bargain electronics, clothing, knick-knacks and food stalls connected by a series of dingy corridors. He noted that while there were a lot of good businesses in the shopping center, there had also been problems there that required police assistance.
"And I'm not sure we would need the tattoo parlor or head shops," he added.
Mr. Rowan was a bit more sympathetic.
"I grew up in Camden, and a great day as a teenager was to go to the Pennsauken Mart," he said. "Even now, I go there to Cass's Soft Pretzels. I buy half a dozen and when I get home, my wife sees four-and-a-half left and says, 'What happened?' So I'm hoping a lot of these people will want to come to Camden."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A 15-acre abandoned plot on Admiral Wilson in Camden, above, is being mentioned as possible new site for the Pennsauken Mart, which may have to make way for the South Jersey Civic and Conference Center, an arena with rooms for meetings and other events. HEADLINE: SHAKEN AND STIRRED; 
Dances With Tastebuds

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
TRYING to come up with a drink that holds the holidays in a glass is a tall order.
 I've never been sold on eggnog, to me a nauseating idea from its name on down to the nutmeg. The fact that you can buy it in supermarkets, in dairy cases, like a quart of brunch omelets, doesn't help. 
 But Champagne -- what's not to like a lot? It pops; it bubbles; it knows how to work a glass. It acts like a party guest. And Champagne cocktails can be an improvement on the drink, which is strangely banal after a flute or two, like beauty without any social backup. 
A midpriced bottle of Champagne or a similar sparkling wine, $18 or so, is a useful economy too, served as kir royales, with the addition of a fruit liqueur like creme de cassis or creme de framboise. You can look for less likely, more exotic flavors, like creme de peche, which is peach, or creme de mure, blackberry. It's a nice touch to have a bar stocked with an interesting variety. With white wine, they make a good rotation of aperitifs year-round.
The standard Champagne cocktail is Champagne poured over a sugar cube soaked in Angostura bitters. The drink dates back to the 19th century and had a heyday in the 1930's. A variant with Cognac was called the Gloria Swanson in the late 1940's, shortly before she played Norma Desmond in "Sunset Boulevard." The drink, besides being Ms. Swanson's calling card, was also known in other circles as the king's ruin, named for the society cafe and hotel bar habits of deposed European royalty. You feel lightheaded without the crown anyway -- why not drink all day?
The diamond fizz is Champagne with the juice of a lemon and a teaspoon of sugar. The black velvet adds Guinness stout. My favorite, the stratosphere (who wouldn't try it to find out?), calls for creme Yvette, which is produced from Parma violets and turns out a purple cocktail. You garnish it with cloves.
At Craft, Tom Colicchio's ingredient-fanatical restaurant at 43 East 19th Street in New York, the house drink is a Champagne cocktail that is seasonal like the food.
During the fall and winter, Matthew MacCartney, the beverage director, mixes Champagne with cubes of Bartlett pear, bathed briefly in a pear liqueur. The taste, as simple as something perfectly ripe, is fresher than the sum of its parts.
"You don't want to overcomplicate it," Mr. MacCartney said. "You don't want to cover up its taste. Adding pear gives the drink an extra subtlety, more aroma, and it's pleasing to the eye."
Craft claims that if you make the cocktail correctly, the pear will "dance" in the glass.
For a holiday drink, how much happier can you get?

CHAMPAGNE COCKTAIL
From Craft

1 teaspoon fresh Bartlett pear, cut into 1/4-inch dice and macerated in pear liqueur, to cover (Craft uses Belle de Brillet.)
5 ounces Champagne.

1. Peel, seed and dice 1 pear into equal 1/4-inch cubes. Place the cubes in a plastic container, and pour in enough pear liqueur to cover. Let the pear macerate in the refrigerator for 2 hours (not more, or the cubes will become oversaturated). If the pear is properly macerated, the cubes will dance in the glass.

2. When ready to serve, spoon about 1 teaspoon of macerated pear into the bottom of a Champagne flute. Pour Champagne slowly into the flute (Craft uses a Riedel Restaurant Series glass, with more of a wineglass shape), because it tends to bubble up in reaction to the pears. Serve.

Yield: 1 serving.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for CLAES FORNELL; 
How Wal-Mart Changed the Game

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
 LAST WEEK, FAO Inc., owner of F.A.O. Schwarz and Zany Brainy toy stores, warned of possible bankruptcy, Blockbuster sharply reduced its 2002 profit estimate, Best Buy cut its profit forecast and Circuit City warned of a loss. Among the reasons, the common denominator was Wal-Mart Stores, which has been moving aggressively into toys, consumer electronics and DVD's, and selling them more cheaply than these stores do. So, what should have been the strongest part of their year, the Christmas selling season, has ranged from disappointing to disastrous. Claes Fornell, a business professor and director of the National Quality Research Center at the University of Michigan, and the chairman of the CFI Group, a consulting firm on customer satisfaction, talked last week about Wal-Mart's latest impact. JULIE FLAHERTY

Q. Buying a digital television or laptop at Wal-Mart was inconceivable a few years ago. How did that change?

A. Three things have changed. The first one is that information is more readily available now to evaluate these products and to know more about them, primarily via the Internet. Second, the question is really what service is here, and from our research it does seem that the service one gets from the personnel in the specialized store is not as useful or good as it was 10 years ago. Third is that prices for all these items have come down drastically, so they are no longer quite as significant in the basket of things we buy.

Q. Specialty retailers have long tried to distinguish themselves with better service than places like Wal-Mart. Do consumers not care about service now, or is Wal-Mart offering better service than it once did?

A. At the University of Michigan, we measure customer satisfaction in something called the American Customer Satisfaction Index. When we started in 1994, a high-service retailer, Nordstrom, for example, had very high customer satisfaction scores, whereas at the other end of the spectrum we probably had Kmart and Federated parent of Bloomingdale's, Macy's and other department stores . Now everybody, including Wal-Mart, scores about the same in customer satisfaction. Even Nordstrom seems to have lost its edge. So it's more difficult to compete when everyone is offering the same level of service. Kmart is still below the others, and so is Federated, but not by a whole lot. Even Wal-Mart has dropped a little bit.
Everybody is becoming more similar. There is a tendency toward sameness. And that will only help the biggest player, that will only help Wal-Mart, because of their size and their power in negotiations with suppliers. Wal-Mart is also offering good service in terms of convenience -- it's easy to get to, it's easy to park -- and selection. We shouldn't discard those two things.

Q. What is likely to happen to Blockbuster, which seemed surprised by the extent of the discounting that has made DVD's almost as affordable to buy as to rent?

A. Here we have another fairly extreme situation. The marginal costs -- the extra cost of developing another DVD -- is almost nothing. Whenever you have high-level competition, no uniqueness, and you have marginal costs diving quickly toward zero, it's a lethal combination, because it drives profit margins also to zero. And it's very, very difficult to get out of. So Blockbuster is in for a very, very tough ride.

Q. Does Wal-Mart face danger in selling too much?

A. If they venture into areas that are different, where they need to pay more attention to customization, more personal service, it would be risky. You look back on Sears and others that have tried to get into areas of financial advice, tax advice, stock advice -- those are very different markets. It would be risky to pursue things where they don't benefit from economies of scale. I don't know if they can sell cars, for example. But the step from computers to cars? Maybe not totally impossible.

Q. If specialty retailers can't compete on price, how can they fight back?

A. We've seen this before. If you go back 50 years ago or so, we had the same kind of discussion: Will specialty retailers be driven out? And many of them were, of course, by the big retail chains like Kresge and Sears. But some managed to stay in business. These days, they may have an even tougher time. We know they can't compete on price, but can they compete on service and quality? That's very doubtful. I'm not so sure they can attract the high-quality staff, because the margins are not there to pay for a compensation that such people would demand. They can fight back by having unique merchandise and catering to a segment of the population that is smaller, obviously, but that appreciates that uniqueness. It's pretty obvious that it may be doable to be small, and difficult to be medium-sized, where the big players will squeeze the medium player out. Just look at Kmart being squeezed between Wal-Mart and Target.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Claes Fornell

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Bottom-Fishing for German Stocks

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

 BODY:
GERMANY has led the world's stock markets on their two-and-a-half-year downhill run. The country's benchmark DAX index has lost more than two-thirds of its value from peak to trough, and a new survey of Germany's economy, Europe's largest, is unlikely to persuade investors that their assessment has been harsh.
 Little headway has been made in alleviating chronic slow growth and high unemployment, the survey concluded. Its results, issued on Tuesday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, an institute set up by the world's developed countries, cited deep-rooted causes for Germany's woes -- high taxation and government spending, an inefficient labor market and excessive business regulation. It said the weak global economy had made the afflictions more acute. 
 The DAX, which peaked at 8,136.16 nearly three years ago, fell as low as 2,519.30 this October; it has since recovered to 3,024.22. But even with that rally, the the German market is still among the world's worst performers in 2002. The DAX is down 41 percent for the year, although the recent strength of the euro makes the decline 32 percent for American investors. 
Still, many German companies are global heavyweights that trade in the United States and are widely held in blue-chip portfolios. These include DaimlerChrysler, Deutsche Bank, Siemens and Allianz, the insurer. Some analysts and fund managers, even those who are wary of the overall market, contend that some German stocks are opportunities -- sound companies whose prices have been dragged down unfairly.
"There is a danger of throwing out some very good companies by throwing out everything with a German tag," said Stephanie Gerrard, senior fund manager at Aberdeen Asset Management in London and a specialist in Continental equities. "They've got good businesses and products, and managements who have demonstrated, long term, that they can deliver. And you're not paying much for them, because expectations are so low."
But trying to find diamonds in the rough can be tricky when the rough is so large. Many investors find it hard to look past the weak returns and dismal economic backdrop. They often compare Germany to another economic power that fell on hard times more than a decade ago.
"Germany seems to be in an awfully difficult situation," said Peter Wright, co-manager of the Morgan Stanley Institutional International fund, which Morningstar credits with the best 10-year performance among diversified foreign stock funds. "It's doing a good job of imitating Japan in many respects. There are a lot of banks that tend to be low quality and high risk, and industry is heavily capital intensive and export dependent." None of the fund's 25 largest holdings are German companies, according to Morningstar, which said that the fund is now closed to investors.
Germany has been unable to right its floundering economy partly because it is in the euro zone. German authorities cannot lower interest rates; the 12-nation euro group has a single rate, set by the European Central Bank. They also cannot reduce taxes to stimulate growth, because Germany's fiscal deficit already breaks the 3 percent ceiling allowed for euro members under the Growth and Stability Pact.
Especially disheartening to many economists and investors are the continuing increases in taxes in Germany, which already has one of the highest tax burdens in the world. "Everyone else ignores the stability pact, but Germany persists in raising taxes and cutting expenditures in a downturn," said Gabriel Stein, an economist at Lombard Street Research in London.
The economy is heavily unionized, and pay in major sectors is set by collective bargaining between the unions and employer federations. It is rare, Mr. Stein said, to pay lower salaries to less-skilled workers or to allow temporary or part-time employment. Many workers retire at 55, and the population is aging, so the work force is likely to shrink.
Over the next decade, Mr. Stein said, the economy is likely to grow no more than 1 percent a year. "There will be years when the economy doesn't grow, not because of recession but just because growth is slower than average," he said.
Ms. Gerrard at Aberdeen looks for companies that will succeed despite the inhospitable climate. In choosing a stock, she said, "you need to find one with a product so different or special that it transcends the internal economic issues or has a very strong management that can offset some of the drags of the political situation."
Two that qualify are BMW and its rival, Porsche. "Both have products that are envied across the world, and they have executed extremely well," she said. "The fact that they are German-based shouldn't be held against them. They have actively looked for markets outside Germany."
She warned, though, that a proposal to raise taxes on company cars may hurt the stocks, especially BMW's, in the short term.
She is avoiding another -- DaimlerChrysler, the maker of Mercedes-Benz cars. "The problem is not the Mercedes element, but Chrysler," she said. "The risk is that U.S. consumers can't carry on supporting the economy for as long as they have."
Ms. Gerrard also likes Schering, the drug maker, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock fell when the company issued a profit warning after the government announced plans to cut reimbursements for drug purchases by 6 percent. But that should mean only a one-time hit to profits, she said, and the stock "is starting to look like pretty good value" after the sell-off.
W. George Greig, manager of the William Blair International Growth fund, is keeping his portfolio light in German holdings, but said he expected a few companies to have strong growth, including Altana, the drug and chemical maker; Medion, a distributor of computers through discount retailers; and Puma, the shoe and sporting goods company. Altana trades on the New York Stock Exchange.
Morgan Stanley's European model portfolio has six German stocks: Allianz; Fresenius Medical Care; BASF, the basic-materials company; Fraport, the airport operator; and Merck and Schering, the drug makers. (Merck & Company and Schering-Plough of the United States began as subsidiaries of the German companies but are now independent.) Allianz, Fresenius, Schering and BASF trade on United States markets.
Allianz has not been a model performer. The American shares fell about two-thirds between the end of May and their October low, and declined 4 percent on Wednesday after the company said its chief executive, Henning Schulte-Noelle, would resign in April.
Lehman Brothers includes four German companies in its European model portfolio: Porsche; Deutsche Bank; SAP, the software maker; and Infineon Technologies, a semiconductor company. All but Porsche trade on the New York Stock Exchange.
Merrill Lynch is neutral on Deutsche Bank, but it advises selling two other banks, Commerzbank and the HVB Group, formerly Bayerische Hypo-und Vereinsbank. Frustrated by the slow pace of consolidation in the banking sector, Merrill's analysts call it a "structural underperformer." They also have sell ratings on Allianz and another insurer, Munich Re, whose stock has experienced a similar large fall. 
JAMES LATORRE, research consultant to the Harbor International fund, said that one of the few German stocks he likes is the tire maker Continental, which is in the portfolio because "it's not run like a German company; it's run for profit." 
Mr. LaTorre previously invested in Deutsche Bank to try to take advantage of an effort at industrial reform in 1999, when the government took steps to encourage corporate giants to untangle their web of cross-shareholding. But not much came of it, he recalled, and he unloaded the stock.
"We cooled on Deutsche because the whole German story never added up," he said. "The sense was that these cross-holdings would be sold to more return-oriented shareholders and that the managers of these sleepy German companies would have to wake up. We thought Deutsche would be right in the middle of this, but it didn't happen. Germany is not reforming as fast as we hoped. But that's Germany."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
The Big Question for Gold: How High Can It Fly?

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE surge that sent gold to a five-and-a-half-year-high of $346.50 an ounce last week is not just one of those mirages that have tantalized investors periodically over the last 15 years, only to vanish quickly.
 This rally has lasted since March 30, 2001. The price of gold has risen 34 percent since then, making it the strongest move of this duration since the rally that ended in early 1988, with gold at $477.80 an ounce. 
 As usual, explanations vary for gold's climb. They range from a change of heart by speculators, who now are betting on higher prices, to the three-year decline in the stock market. The expected war with Iraq may be prompting some investors to seek gold as a haven. And gold enthusiasts are worried that the Federal Reserve's determined effort to avoid deflation could guarantee some jump in inflation soon. 
This time, though, gold has built a floor, for now, around $300 an ounce. That floor is a result of a major decline in hedging by gold producers over the last two years. Such hedging, involving the selling of huge amounts of borrowed gold, helped to break the back of gold rallies for years.
So there is little reason to believe that this rally will abruptly disappear. Instead, the question is this: How much higher can gold go?
The answer, some analysts say, will be found in the behavior of individual investors, who have yet to make a big move back into the gold market. If they make that move, the price may climb higher. If they don't, the rally may falter when speculators, who seem to be powering gold now, decide that the run has gone far enough. Still, no big decline appears in store.
Philip Klapwijk, the managing director of Gold Fields Mineral Services in London, a precious-metals research firm, said there was little hard evidence of current investor inclinations. Most information is anecdotal. But the sales of American Eagle gold coins and of precious-metals mutual funds can give some hint of individual investors' sentiment, while trading of gold futures on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange can give a sense of speculators' views.
Sales of American Eagle gold coins jumped to 43,500 ounces in November from 31,000 ounces in October, according to the United States Mint. But sales for the year still might not beat the 325,000 ounces sold in 2001, and they are far behind the almost 2.1 million ounces sold in 1999, at the height of year-2000 computer fears. So there is interest, but no run yet.
Another sign of individuals' interest is the flow of money into mutual funds that buy stocks in precious-metals companies. This year through last week, $465 million had poured in, after a net outflow of $251 million in the same period a year earlier. The 2002 pace is well above the average annual fund flow of just $84 million since 1992, according to AMG Data Services. 
For investors in the stocks of these companies, the payoff has been even better than the rally in gold itself. For the year, the CBOE Gold index, which includes 10 gold mining companies, is up 47 percent, while the price of gold is up 22 percent, after it slipped on Friday to finish the week at $341 an ounce. But that money is not pushing up the price of gold, just the price of gold mining stocks.
SPECULATORS, meanwhile, are hungry for gold. Based on reports from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, noncommercial traders, including speculators, held about 87,000 futures contracts to buy gold and about 32,000 contracts to sell gold as of Dec. 17, a net buying position of 55,000 contracts. That is the largest since 1996, a sure sign that the sentiment these days is to bet on a price rise -- not the price falls of the past.
This sentiment pleases John Hathaway, a gold fund portfolio manager at Tocqueville Asset Management. "Here is an asset class asleep for 20 years," he said. "You have room for reallocation of world financial wealth to gold and just a small amount going into gold would have a big impact because it is such a small asset class."
But first, investors have to catch Mr. Hathaway's fever.
