HEADLINE: Peru's Former President Plots His Return to Power 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 20 

 BODY:
In a secluded house in Kojimachi, a power neighborhood bounded by the British Embassy, a stone moat of the Imperial Palace and the ziggurat dome of the Parliament building, a man in a business suit known throughout Japan as Fujimori-san was methodically plotting his political comeback.
 Focus groups, fund-raising and a multicolor Web site to rally the faithful are in motion, Alberto K. Fujimori, the former president of Peru, said in an interview this week. Last week, a specially commissioned 100-page biography landed on desks in Washington, including a few at the White House. 
 "Why run for Congress?" Mr. Fujimori, 64, retorted dismissively in English, when told he could easily win a parliamentary seat in Japan, his land of self-exile. Switching to the Spanish of his native land, he said, "I want to be the ejecutivo." 
Or as Satomi Kataoka, his elegant, 30-something girlfriend, addressed him soothingly after a small sushi lunch here: "President." 
Just over two years ago, Mr. Fujimori interrupted a flight home to check into a Tokyo hotel and fax his resignation to Lima, ending 11 years as Peru's leader. He feared removal by Peru's Congress, which was responding to popular anger over what was widely viewed as a fraudulent presidential election and a televised videotape of Mr. Fujimori's right-hand man, Vladimiro Montesinos, handing cash to an opposition congressman. Ever since, the Peruvian authorities have tried to win his return for trial on charges ranging from corruption to murder. 
But now, in tacit recognition of Mr. Fujimori's gradual political resurrection, the beleaguered government of President Alejandro Toledo is not rushing to secure his return to Lima, even for a trial. Two weeks ago, Peruvian diplomats marched into Japan's Foreign Ministry with a new demand: that Japan shut down his Web site, www.fujimorialberto.com. 
While Japanese officials refuse to interfere with the Web site, the Toledo government drags its feet on extradition. Mr. Toledo's cabinet approved the extradition request last May, but work has not started on translating the 700-page document into Japanese. The translator said it would not be ready until next fall. 
The official Japanese position is that the request is a waste of time and money. The son of a Japanese-born couple, Mr. Fujimori was given a Japanese passport days after arriving here in November 2000. Also, there is no extradition treaty between Japan and Peru. Last summer, a Lima court dropped embezzlement charges against Mr. Fujimori's brother-in-law, Victor Aritomi, who stayed on here after serving as Peru's ambassador to Japan. 
"The Toledo government is losing interest," said Hidetaka Ogura, a former Japanese diplomat who is advising Peru on the extradition case. "There is more interest in economic cooperation." 
During the Fujimori decade, Japan funneled $3 billion in foreign aid to Peru. The Japanese public was captivated by the ethnic Japanese success story, forcing a succession of governments to make Peru one of Japan's largest aid recipients. With Mr. Fujimori's departure from Peru, and angry demonstrators outside the Japanese Embassy demanding his extradition, Japanese officials allowed aid contracts to expire. The Toledo government is far more interested in having aid restored than in having Mr. Fujimori returned. 
Speaking at the house of Hideaki Kase, a leading conservative intellectual, Mr. Fujimori said he never bothered to hire defense lawyers -- partly because he could not afford them, partly because he saw the charges brought against him in Peru as politically motivated. 
"There is no illegal enrichment," he said, ridiculing the prospects of Kroll Associates, the American investigative company, which started a search last month for any ill-gotten assets that Mr. Fujimori may have hidden. "In two years, no foreign bank accounts have been found," he said. "I don't have any accounts in Panama or anywhere else." 
In Tokyo, Mr. Fujimori lives alone in a 850-square-foot apartment, shopping and cooking for himself. Using office space in a hotel owned by Ms. Kataoka, he takes daily Japanese-language lessons and writes articles for his Web site. 
In the interview, Mr. Fujimori avoided talking about Mr. Montesinos, his disgraced intelligence aide who was convicted last summer of embezzling nearly $3 million in public funds. But, earlier this month, he addressed the charges in statements made for the biography. 
"No one knew that Montesinos was taking money for himself -- they found $77 million of his in Swiss bank accounts," Mr. Fujimori said in the biography, which was written to argue his case in Washington. 
Talking for more than an hour, Mr. Fujimori recalled visiting former President George Bush in Kennebunkport, Me., in 1997. As Peru's president, he said, he got along well with "Bush father." Now, with Republicans back in power, he said he believed that Washington would gain a new appreciation of his pro-business economic policies and his counterterrorism tactics. 
He said the criticism would shrink in the hard light of the post-Sept. 11 world. In a 1997 case that drew prosecutors' attention, but no charges, Mr. Fujimori directed a commando attack on the Japanese Embassy residence in Lima, where left-wing guerrillas had held 72 hostages for four months. Fourteen guerrillas, two soldiers and a hostage were killed. Two months ago in Moscow, he noted, Russian soldiers trying to rescue hostages held in a theater by Chechen guerrillas left 41 guerrillas and at least 129 hostages dead. 
In response to the Peruvian murder charges, Mr. Fujimori repeated rebuttals that he had no direct command over a Lima death squad unit that carried out two attacks in the early 1990's, killing a total of 25 people. Support came two weeks ago from a former Peruvian Army officer charged with heading the squad, Maj. Santiago Martin Rivas, who told congressional investigators, "Due to my military rank, I could never have reported to the president." 
With the United States planning military trials of terrorism suspects, Mr. Fujimori said Americans today might now understand why he resorted to military judges a decade ago. "Who dared to punish a terrorist leader?" he said. "Either they were freed or punished very lightly. Faceless judges and military courts -- this allowed punishment." 
For Americans, this authoritarian system of justice was symbolized by a military court's conviction in 1996 of Lori Berenson, a New York native, on charges of collaborating with Marxist rebels. At the time, the conviction focused intense American criticism on Mr. Fujimori and the military court system. But in the last 18 months, a civilian court retried and reconvicted Ms. Berenson, Peru's Supreme Court upheld the conviction and Mr. Toledo ruled out a presidential pardon. 
Today, in light of America's campaign against Al Qaeda, counterterrorism experts are taking a second look at Mr. Fujimori's success in breaking up the Maoist Shining Path group by tracking and capturing its shadowy leader, Abimael Guzman. 
Rebutting all charges against him as "political," Mr. Fujimori said worse massacres took place under his predecessor, Alan Garcia. Last month, followers of Mr. Garcia won 25 percent of the vote in regional elections, and some political pundits started talking in earnest about a Fujimori-Garcia contest shaping up for Peru's 2006 presidential election. 
Without saying so directly, Mr. Fujimori evidently hopes to follow Mr. Garcia's political strategy, staying out of Peru for several years until all charges are dropped, then returning on the shoulders of popular acclaim.
Indeed, instead of hiring lawyers, Mr. Fujimori has installed in Lima two architects of an embryonic political machine: Carlos Raffo, his former press aide, and Keiko Fujimori, his oldest daughter who served as first lady after his 1996 divorce. 
Meanwhile, he continues his methodical life, declining to show too many of his cards at one time. Offering a cryptic clue to a return date, Mr. Fujimori, an advanced Japanese speaker, said: "I am learning 30 new Japanese words a day, putting them in my notebook. When I leave, I will be speaking Japanese fluently."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alberto K. Fujimori, Peru's former leader, is working to repair his image from his self-imposed exile in Japan. (Stuart Isett for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Tough Times Translate Into Layoffs, Fewer Hours and Deprivation

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN

 BODY:
Carlos Guevara sat hunched over a sewing machine in a Brooklyn garment factory, 10 hours a day, six days a week. Every 15 to 30 seconds, he would push a white cotton neck lining off to the side of his table.
 Six cents. 
 That is how much he earned for each one of those linings -- a nickel and a penny, for his pocket, for his family.
Each minute brought him and his family a bit closer to a meal. Each brought him a fraction of the way closer to paying the rent on the family's one-bedroom apartment in Richmond Hill, Queens -- one story below the elevated track of the J and Z subway and one story above the perpetually gloomy street below. 
As tough as the work was on his fingers, Mr. Guevara longs for those days to return. So does his wife, Blanca. She worked at the factory, too, earning about $400 a week in the summer of 2001. While Mr. Guevara earned about $600 a week at the factory, she always worked fewer hours than he did so she could spend time caring for their children: Reina, 5; Maroni, 4; and Oliver, 2.
But now neither Mr. Guevara nor his wife works at the factory. Mr. Guevara's hours were cut in August 2001 and, facing slackening sales, the factory closed the following October. Because his old job has vanished, he has spent much of the last year looking for a similar one.
"They used to have three columns of job openings," he said recently, sitting on a worn living room couch and holding up the classified listings in El Diario. "Now, maybe one."
At the charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, tales like the Guevaras' are common. "It's all too familiar at this point," said Robert Siebel, the executive director of Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, which has helped the Guevaras pay their utility bills. "I think we're dealing largely in most of our centers with people you'd consider the working poor. They have income, but their income is inadequate for some of their primary needs, particularly housing."

Help Here and There
 Like many other poor families in a slowing economy, the Guevaras are trying to avoid welfare by seeking employment -- whatever they can find.
"We have children," said Mr. Guevara, 47. "At this point, we're looking for anything."
Recently, he sewed eight dresses for a sweet 16 party for a friend's daughter. But the dazzling sequined gowns were more a favor for the friend than a way to sustain his own family. He naturally gave his friend a discounted rate, $640 for a month's effort. But he was grateful for that money, the equivalent of 10,667 white cotton neck linings.
Like many other poor families, the Guevaras have been helped by the Neediest Cases Fund, which provides money to seven of the oldest and most respected charities in New York.
In August, KeySpan Energy cut the family's gas because they were several months behind on paying their bill, which grew to $1,404.16 for cooking gas and an additional $720.81 for heating. Mrs. Guevara began to prepare food for her children on an electric hot plate.
In September, she went to the office of Rosa Orihuela, a caseworker for Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens. To help the family meet long-term needs, Mrs. Orihuela helped Mrs. Guevara set up a monthly schedule for paying bills. For immediate relief, Mrs. Orihuela gave Mrs. Guevara tuna fish, peanut butter and other foods that could be eaten without cooking and, with money that had been donated to the Neediest Cases Fund, she wrote a check for $410.93 to KeySpan to have the family's cooking gas restored.
"I felt really bad because she has these small children," Mrs. Orihuela said. "They had, at this point, no steady income, only whatever they make here and there."
Weeks later, as the weather turned colder, Mrs. Orihuela wrote another check, so the family would have heat again. But in October the heating gas was not yet restored; the Guevaras depended on the faint orange glow of a small space heater. It sat on the floor of the living room, a few feet from the large picture windows where Mr. Guevara displays examples of his handiwork in hopes that people will knock on his door and buy them.
The space heater purred around the clock for weeks until it was given a break after KeySpan received Mrs. Orihuela's second check -- $720.81 from the Neediest Cases Fund.
At the Catholic Charities administrative office in downtown Brooklyn, Mr. Siebel said the Guevara's case is a typical example of the modest and temporary nature of help for the working poor from the Neediest Cases Fund.
"They're asking for something very specific because they are concerned about making it to the next month," he said. "They're not looking for more than they need, and when they get back on their feet they're not back to us."
The Guevaras -- and countless others struggling to provide for their families but facing a loss of income -- have found that Neediest Cases has helped them survive particularly difficult times.
"It has a stabilizing influence," Mr. Siebel said. "With it, we're able to keep a person in housing as they pursue other income and career and training opportunities. Oftentimes it staves off something radical, like an eviction or a utility turnoff."
In some cases, charities use the money from the fund to provide a temporary cushion for people with little or no savings who have lost subsistence-level employment. In other instances, the fund helps provide job training for those lacking the skills that potential employers seek.
"We provide career counseling and job training for almost 5,000 people each week," said John Ruskay, the executive director of UJA-Federation of New York, an umbrella agency that is supported by the fund. "We provide 3,000 adults with E.S.L. -- English as a second language -- each week. We provide child care for 13,000 children a year."
Mr. Ruskay said charity plays a particularly important role for what he called an underserved population -- those who exist somewhere between the self-sufficient and the people who have to rely on government aid. "Those that are at the poverty level get a range of government services," he said. "Those that are working don't qualify for those. Hence, we need to provide them with things like additional food supplements, medical supplements, scholarships for preschool."

Juggling Jobs and Family
 For 13 years, Marie Fong-Sam, a single mother, worked two jobs to provide for her three children, Wendy, who is now 21, Johnny, now 18, and Tracy, 6.
For the last eight years, since she has lived in her own house in South Ozone Park, Queens, her day has begun at 6 a.m., when she wakes to prepare herself for work and Tracy for school. Ms. Fong-Sam has to be at her first job at 9:30, so by 7:30, she walks to the bus stop and catches the Q40 local for a 15-minute ride to the Sutphin Boulevard station, where she catches the E train for a ride to 42nd Street. There she transfers to the 2 train uptown to 149th Street and Third Avenue in the Bronx. A five-minute ride on the Bx4 bus takes her to her job as a school lunch helper at South Bronx High School, where she earns $11.25 an hour.
Two buses. Two trains. Two hours.
"I used to live in the Bronx," she said, explaining why she works at a job so far from home. She said she was happy with the job and loath to ask for a transfer.
At the high school, she helps prepare the equipment to serve thousands of children, and later, she sanitizes food trays. Her shift ends at 2 p.m.
Before she leaves, she calls her boss at the Parker Meridien Hotel on West 57th Street in Manhattan, where she works as a housekeeper.
"This is Marie," she says. "Do you need me today?"
Sometimes, her boss says he is unsure. "Don't worry," she replies. "I'll call back again."
At $18.57 an hour, the job at the hotel pays much more than the one at the school, but it is less steady.
"I need to show them that I want my job," she said. "I'll come in for three hours, four hours, anything they have."
For 15 years, Ms. Fong-Sam worked a late-afternoon and evening shift at the hotel, starting an hour after she left the school and finishing at 10:30 p.m. With another ride on the E train and the Q40 bus, she was able to get home before midnight.
The two jobs allowed her to pay her monthly mortgage of $944, her utility bills and even the $240 monthly tuition for Tracy, who is in first grade at a parochial school.
"But then Sept. 11 happened," she said.
A week later, she was laid off by the hotel as the city faced a sudden decline in tourism.
With her expenses mounting, Ms. Fong-Sam sought help from the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, another of the seven agencies supported by Neediest Cases. 
"When she first came in she was overwhelmed and just really tired from the struggle," said Hilary Kleine, her social worker from the Brooklyn Bureau. On top of it all, Ms. Fong-Sam's refrigerator would frequently break, and her food would sometimes spoil.
The bureau gave her $950 for a new refrigerator, $317.20 for her oil bill and $300 for food. Ms. Kleine recalled that Ms. Fong-Sam called her shortly after the new refrigerator was delivered. "They were so excited to have ice cream," she said.
In the spring, she was offered a full-time job at the hotel on a morning shift, but she did not want to risk giving up her school lunch job, which has health benefits.
Now, she works at the hotel from 9 to 4 on Saturdays and Sundays, though she earns only a fraction of her former income. She is one of the most senior employees to have been laid off, and could be working full time again if the hotel needs two more people for her old shift. "But if they decide to take only one, I'm going to be left behind," she said.

Ripples From Trade Center
While many New York jobs like Mrs. Fong-Sam's have been cut or lost as an indirect result of the attack on the World Trade Center, many of those who worked in the twin towers have themselves asked for charity for the first time in their lives.
Last year, The Times ran a special campaign to raise money for a fund that helped needy victims of the trade center tragedy.
When the money in that fund had been spent or allocated to ongoing projects, some of those who lost work in connection with the trade center attack received help from Neediest Cases.
One of those was Nery Veras, 43, who was a bus boy at the Marriott Financial Center hotel across West Street from the twin towers. He and his wife, Paulina Ventura, 44, tried for months to survive without asking for help. But with a rent of $656.04 a month and two children, Nery Jr., 9, and Fredeliza, 15, living at home in the West 140's in Upper Manhattan, it was not easy. In June, they had to turn to the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.
Judith Milone, assistant director of member services for the federation, another Neediest Cases beneficiary, said that by the time Mr. Veras applied for help, the federation had spent the money from the 9/11 fund. She noted that there were more stringent guidelines for helping people with money from the Neediest Cases Fund than with the money earmarked for victims of 9/11, because this year the Neediest Cases Fund had to do the double duty of helping trade center victims and those in poverty. As it does every year, the federation requires that people helped by Neediest Cases prove that after receiving the grant they will be self-sufficient -- a stipulation that was waived for terror victims.
The hotel reopened in January, and Mr. Veras got his old job back. Because he was able to show future income, he was eligible for help from Neediest Cases, Ms. Milone said. "He's one of the fortunate ones," she said.
After Mr. Veras described the amount of money he owed his landlord, the federation authorized a grant of $1,312.08 for two months' rent, so the family could avoid being evicted from their one-bedroom walk-up apartment.

Finding a New Start
Another man who lost time at work because of the destruction of the trade center was Nainsingh Bist of Valley Stream, N.Y. He was a shift captain and sommelier at Windows on the World.
"I don't feel comfortable asking for money," he said.
Mr. Bist was born in Nepal and grew up in Bombay. He moved to New York in 1982, and started working in the restaurant business right away. He worked at two restaurants, first as a waiter and then as a captain and sommelier, before joining Windows on the World in June 1996.
It was the peak of his career, but he thought it would be a little more long-lived. "After that, nothing seems right," he said. "I never thought I would look for another job."
But on Sept. 11, he watched the collapse of the towers from 20 blocks away. He lost his job and many co-workers.
Gripping his temples with thumb and forefinger, he recalled the sleepless nights that followed the terrorist attack and the horrific images it created. He found a part-time job at the Garden City Hotel, where he began working on Sept. 17, 2001. But the memories of his old job and deceased co-workers kept returning, and he found he was unable to concentrate on work. "I couldn't think," he recalled. "I was blanked out."
That was before the eight funerals he attended.

Grief, Fear and Counseling
 Compounding the emotional turmoil was the loss of income he faced. He worked at the part-time job for four months while collecting unemployment insurance benefits for his days off. He found that between the job and the unemployment benefits he was earning about $405 a week. "It was not enough to support the house," he said.
As a way to cope with mounting grief and worries about meeting his expenses, Mr. Bist attended group counseling sessions in Syosset, N.Y., offered by FEGS, a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation and formerly known as the Federation Employment and Guidance Service.
Gina Tudisco, a counselor at the agency, helped him and other survivors work through their apprehensions.
"In order for them to cope on a job they had to have that emotional strength," she said. "Although they all wanted to get back to work, psychologically they weren't able to do it.
"You get a lot out of talking about your emotions and listening to each other in a group," she said.
For Mr. Bist, the sessions proved to be a big help. "They gave us hope," he said. "They lifted us up."
Mr. Bist told Ms. Tudisco that he was worried about the health insurance for his wife and three children. She applied for a grant of $1,400 from the Neediest Cases Fund to buy two months of health insurance for the family when their benefits expired, which was last month. They were not eligible for Medicaid because Mr. Bist owns his home, he said.
Not having to worry about the insurance for two months enabled Mr. Bist to concentrate his efforts on starting a new business, the Tandoor Grill, an Indian restaurant in Rockville Centre, N.Y. "It's a new business and the roots are still weak," he said. "I can't even think about insurance right now."
If the restaurant succeeds, he said, he will not have to worry about his family's health insurance again.
That is the future that Mr. Bist is hoping for. "I never had to apply for charity before," he said. "This is the first time, and I hope it is the last."

HEADLINE: On West Side, Rail Plan Is Up And Walking 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
A once-quixotic proposal to turn an abandoned rail line on the far West Side of Manhattan into an elevated public promenade has been formally embraced by the Bloomberg administration, almost exactly a year after the Giuliani administration moved to demolish the hulking structure.
 Now, rather than seeking to tear down the 1.45-mile railroad viaduct, known as the High Line, New York City has asked the federal Surface Transportation Board to grant a certificate of interim trail use, which would preserve the route as a distinctly urban stretch in the national rails-to-trails network. 
 "We think the High Line, ultimately converted into a park, will enhance the character of the entire far West Side," Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, said in an interview on Friday.
"The High Line will remain up," he said, "and in conjunction with this we would seek to rezone portions of the areas surrounding the High Line in order to accommodate residential development. We think the High Line can be an important amenity." 
The City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, said, "It's a huge step in the right direction." 
That is not easy to envision while standing in the dark shadow of the viaduct, which has all the charm of an el. But it becomes clearer on the deck, where trees, weeds and wildflowers among rusting tracks and switches create a verdant swath through Hell's Kitchen, Chelsea and the Gansevoort Meat Market.
As a practical matter, the CSX Corporation, which manages the High Line, is still under an order from the Surface Transportation Board to pursue demolition, an outcome sought by Chelsea Property Owners, which objects to the structure as a dismal, dangerous blight that cannot be rehabilitated feasibly, attractively or economically -- especially at a time of budget deficits.
Douglas Sarini, president of the group, which represents commercial owners along the High Line route, did not reply to requests for comment.
Earlier this year, however, the group said in one of its fliers: "Money doesn't grow on trees. And the last time we checked, it wasn't growing in the weeds of the High Line, either."
In fact, there is no money now to create a public space, nor even a plan to follow, although a private group called Friends of the High Line intends to sponsor a competition for ideas early next year.
What last week's filing does do is ally the city firmly with efforts to rehabilitate the 69-year old High Line, which runs about 30 feet above sidewalk level from Gansevoort to 34th Streets on a path that primarily parallels Tenth Avenue. The line, which in some places runs through or has spurs into buildings, linked the warehousing and industrial district along the Hudson River to the rest of the nation until 1980, and has been deteriorating since then.
"I understand that for property owners and many in the community that if you have to choose between the High Line as it currently is and no High Line, bringing it down makes sense," Mr. Miller, the Council speaker, said. "But I believe -- and I think the administration has also seen -- that when you consider the possibilities for a preserved and reused High Line as a public space and a signature moment in the New York landscape, that the positives are almost limitless."
Robert Hammond, co-founder of the Friends of the High Line, said the city's action was "at the top of my Christmas list." Two years ago, his well-connected but fledgling group faced considerable skepticism when it suggested that the High Line might one day rank with the Promenade Plantee in Paris, an old railroad viaduct that has been turned into a landscaped walkway.
A year ago, the group was in court, along with the City Council and C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, challenging the tentative demolition agreement reached on Dec. 20, 2001, in the last days of the Giuliani administration. The High Line's backers argued that because the agreement involved property easements along the route of the viaduct, it should have been subject to the city's uniform land-use review procedure, known as Ulurp.
In March, they won a ruling from Justice Diane S. Lebedeff of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, who wrote that the administration's "determination to forego Ulurp review was undertaken without 'lawful procedure' and was an 'error of law.' " The ruling is being appealed. What is also holding up demolition is that a final, signed agreement has yet to be reached. And in its filing with the Surface Transportation Board, the city expressed "serious doubt" that such an agreement could ever be attained.
Instead, Mr. Doctoroff said, the city now hopes to reach a new agreement with CSX in the next few months, permitting "interim trail use," although he cautioned that this is a legal term; it does not mean that the viaduct would be open to strollers, skaters and bicyclists any time soon.
"A significant investment will have to be made," Mr. Doctoroff said.
In its filing, the city said that to establish an interim trail use, it would be willing to assume full responsibility for management of the right-of-way and any legal liability. 
Without taking a position, Laurie Izes, a consultant to CSX, who is overseeing the High Line, said the company was "interested in a responsible and expeditious solution" and would review the filing if the board granted the city's request for interim trail use.

HEADLINE: Few Curse the Darkness During Winter Solstice 

BYLINE:  By ALAN FEUER

 BODY:
It would be hard to dispute the proposition that New Yorkers are nocturnal creatures. After all, the city comes alive after dark and -- at least, as Frank Sinatra used to say -- it never sleeps.
 Last night was the winter solstice, the longest night of the year, a good opportunity to explore what New York City residents would do with an extended period of darkness -- 886 minutes, to be precise -- from 4:32 p.m. yesterday, when the sun set, until 7:18 a.m. this morning, when it rose again, according to Tim Morrin, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service. 
 The solstice itself occurred last night at 8:14 p.m., Mr. Morrin said. In the northern hemisphere, it marked that bleak and lightless instant when the sun was furthest to the south in relation to the equator. 
John Donne described just such a moment in his poem "A Nocturnal Upon St. Lucy's Day," which was published in 1633. 
"The sun is spent, and now his flasks/Send forth light squibs, no constant rays," Mr. Donne wrote. "The world's whole sap is sunk."
Sunken sap and squibs of light aside, many New Yorkers planned to celebrate the solstice as a joyous occasion. There was, for example, an afternoon of choral music and pagan rituals yesterday at the Musical Theater Works on Lafayette Street.
The event was sponsored by the Coven Kyklos Ton Asterion, a Wiccan group, and the Four Winds Earth Chorus, which describes itself on its Web site as an volunteer organization created to perform and promote "the sacred music of Pagan, Native American and Earth-Honoring peoples."
Before the advent of the light bulb, said one of its founding members, Heather Griffith, watching the darkness of night encroach on the daylight was a harrowing experience. Back then, there was a mistaken impression that the sun might vanish altogether.
"So what we're celebrating," Ms. Griffith explained, "is the sun is coming back. We'll have our ritual concert, which is open to the public, but I know various people who will stay up all night with their friends and covens, singing to the sun."
For those with a more ecumenical bent, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine held its 23rd annual winter solstice concert last night. It featured Paul Winter on the saxophone, Barry Olsen on the marimbas, Eugene Friesen on the cello, and the Forces of Nature Dance Theater Ensemble.
As sunset approached yesterday, inquiries were made to a handful of businesses that, presumably, would flourish under the cover of darkness.
At Rosetta Lighting, a lamp and light bulb store on West 45th Street, the manager, Ray Ramirez, was asked if he had noticed a sudden spike in sales.
"No," he said glumly. "This has been one of those fateful years. Business is very bad."
A similar question was posed to the bartender at the Holland Bar, a cozy grotto on Ninth Avenue behind the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
"The longest day of the year has nothing to do it," said the bartender, who gave his name as Savoy George. "We have hard-core alcoholics here. This is where people go to die of liver cirrhosis. If we're open, the customers will come."
On a hunch, an electronic message was sent to the New Jersey Real Vampire Association. It seemed like a sure bet that vampires would appreciate a long, dark night, although representatives of the group did not respond to efforts to reach them.
So it was left to Isaac Bowman, an unemployed man who was milling about on Seventh Avenue as dusk approached, to offer his own plans for the coming night.
"I'm going to a hotel," Mr. Bowman said. "Looks like I've got a little more time to sleep tonight."

HEADLINE: A Lean Season for Charity on the City Sidewalks 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
Apparently, New York is not in the giving vein this holiday season.
 Charitable donations from pedestrians have declined this year, according to nonprofit organizations, sidewalk Santas and the other solicitors who collect tens of thousands of dollars every year for the needy on the streets of Midtown Manhattan. 
 Volunteers of America, a nonprofit organization that assigns 10 bell-ringing Santas to Midtown every Christmas season, reports that donations are down 25 percent from last year, itself a lean giving year because of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.
The Salvation Army, which has roughly 1,000 bell-ringers soliciting contributions at 300 sites in the New York area this season, says kettle donations are down at least 20 percent from last year. 
"People don't realize, a lot of people depend on those little red kettles," said Craig Evans, a spokesman for the Salvation Army.
The group uses the kettle donations to provide presents and meals to needy families on Christmas, as does Volunteers of America. Both groups report an increase in needy families requesting assistance this year.
"We really depend on the small street donations," said Linda McNeil, a spokeswoman for the Volunteers of America. "We normally raise $50,000 from kettle donations, but it doesn't look like we'll make that this year."
James Grant, a Salvation Army volunteer who stood at Madison Avenue and 58th Street yesterday, said: "There's not as much generosity this year because the spirit is dying. Last year, people had 9/11 as a reason. Now they're using it as as an excuse." 
Mr. Grant and his wife, Ann, stood next to a hot-dog vendor outside the rear entrance to the F. A. O. Schwarz toy store. The couple exhorted passers-by to pitch money in their traditional red plastic pot.
Depending upon whom you ask, this season is yielding less in donations because of the sagging economy, fewer tourists or the weather, which has not exactly resembled a winter wonderland.
Still, holiday spirit was prevalent on Fifth Avenue yesterday. Outside F. A. O. Schwarz, young volunteers with Santa hats and cardboard cups asked passers-by for change. The James Brown song "Super Bad" blared from the radio of a sidewalk vendor selling designer knockoff handbags. He also sold photographs of the Manhattan skyline, with or without the World Trade Center. 
The aroma of roasting chestnuts mingled with a smorgasbord of foreign accents and the honking of gridlocked taxis. People filed past wearing sandwich-board signs advertising sales on gentlemen's suits, cameras or bikini waxing.
But still, "it's nothing like the big years of the 80's and 90's," said Frank Henderson, 70, of Harlem, who has sold pencils on the crowded sidewalk in front of the Cartier jewelry store at Fifth Avenue and 52nd Street every December for the past 35 years.
Mr. Henderson, who was holding an actual tin cup with pencils in it, wore a sign around his neck announcing that he was blind. His 13-year-old guide dog, Max, lay at his feet.
"I used to be able to make $90 in three hours," he said.
Things did not seem so bad yesterday either, as dollar bills flowed into his cup. He promptly transferred them to his pocket.
Jaymes Everett, 65, a retired electrician from the Bronx who has played Santa in front of Saks Fifth Avenue for three years, said shoppers have been long on excuses and short on money this year.
"I'm hearing, 'I'll be back,' or 'I don't have the money right now,' " he said. "People say, 'I gave at the other block,' or 'I mailed it in.' Suddenly everyone's in a rush, or they don't speak English."
Though things seemed tough on the sidewalks, there are areas in Manhattan where charity never seems to go out of style. 
For 63 years, the Salvation Army has sent a brass band to play Christmas carols for the lunchtime crowd at the restaurant 21 on West 52nd Street. Yesterday, the band played for diners who looked up from their cigars, Scotch and steak tartare and dropped cash or checks into the tambourines passed around by band members.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sidewalk solicitors of all kinds are reporting tough times. Frank Henderson has sold pencils on Fifth Avenue near 52nd Street each December for 35 years. Now is "nothing like the big years of the 80's and 90's," he said. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: YACHT RACING; 
Conner Is Out of the America's Cup Competition but Not Down

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 21 

 BODY:
The wind was gusting to 35 knots, the waters on the Hauraki Gulf roiling fiercely. The America's Cup yachts had been docked all day, so no one ashore could believe that a 60-year-old skipper ventured out in his 24-foot sailboat.
 "I got permission," the skipper, Dennis Conner, yelled to the harbor patrolman standing in the tower. "Go ahead, check." 
 Conner pulled into the open water recently with a five-person crew, sailing toward the starting line of a rum race. 
"Yeah, a bunch of kids and yahoos from the yacht club get out here and try to run each other over," Conner said. "Then they meet back at the bar and get drunk."
Conner, the old man at sea, is still a shot-and-a-beer guy trapped in a Moet & Chandon world.
His yacht was knocked out of the America's Cup competition last month, more than two months before the Auld Mug will be presented. Now, Mr. America's Cup is tending tomatoes and feeding chickens at his base here. He will stay until the final in February, pay for this Stars & Stripes challenge by speaking to sponsors and taking potential sponsors sailing aboard a spectator yacht.
"I wasn't good enough; I take responsibility," he said of the New York Yacht Club's campaign. Conner knows he picked the wrong mix. He decided to train in Long Beach, Calif., instead of New Zealand. The backers committed late. He signed his contract with the yacht club late, started fund-raising late, arrived in Auckland late and was finished by the quarterfinals. In the total-commitment world Conner created for the sport, that is not how the game is played anymore. 
"When I started in '74, we only spent $1.1 million for the whole campaign," said Conner, who has mounted nine Cup campaigns. "We didn't launch our boat until May and the Cup was in September, and there were only 12 in the crew. I think we spent $3 million in 1980."
Conner's budget for the 2003 Cup was $45 million, half the $90 million spent by the Swiss pharmaceutical magnate Ernesto Bertarelli and by the software entrepreneur Larry Ellison. The boats backed by those billionaires, Alinghi and Oracle, are still racing.
The prestart for the rum race was still 10 minutes away when Conner tacked the boat toward the Royal New Zealand Yacht Squadron, a nondescript split-level ivory building along the rocky Auckland shore.
"See that," he said, pointing from maybe 100 yards away. "That's where they keep the Cup. Right there. The trophy is in that building." 
Conner, the only man to lose and recapture the world's oldest sporting trophy, is further from the grail than he has been in 30 years -- maybe too far to clutch it again.
"I think there's a good chance this could be it," said Conner, who won the Cup in 1974, 1980, 1987 and 1988.
If the Swiss boat Alinghi wins, the Cup is going to Europe.
For now, Conner waddles around his base, barbecuing red snapper and steak for his remaining crew, looking for the next draft choice and a Friday night victory on the water.
Conner's competing in an Auckland rum race is like Michael Jordan's showing up at the downtown Y for an afternoon pickup game.
His crew was international, with fairly wide-ranging experience. Vince Brun, a transplanted Brazilian considered one of the greatest yachtsmen in the world, trimmed the mainsail, as he had on Stars & Stripes. Two of Conner's other sailors were also aboard: the trimmer Morgan Trubovich, a native New Zealander now living in Southern California, and Brian Terhaar, a hulking grinder from San Diego whom they call Bowwow.
Eventually, the winds calmed to about 25 knots, and a gaggle of boats appeared for the prestart. Next to the sleek 40-and 50-footers on the water, Conner's boat was the tiniest, a Ross-780 Trailer Sailer, the Kiwi Menace II.
He nailed the start in a tight jam of sails and sterns. Some of the larger boats eventually caught and passed Conner's. Trying to make up ground after rounding the second buoy, he was on a collision course with a mammoth rusted freighter. Conner navigated to his right, with maybe 10 yards to spare.
"Good on ya', Dennis," a man from another boat said. Well done.
The Kiwis hated Conner less than 10 years ago. He called one of their own a loser after a race and once labeled a Kiwi designer a cheater. A popular bumper sticker in this nation of 3.5 million people used to read, "Dirty Dennis." 
But Conner wore them down with his candor, his nasal drone, his everyman longevity and the fact that he is one of a few syndicate bosses left whose crew members' nationality actually resembles that of the boat. Being a sailing legend does not hurt here, either. When he went to a Luciano Pavarotti concert three years ago, 5,000 New Zealanders began chanting Conner's name.
"The people on the streets, the working class, they pull for me," he said, heading for the third mark. "The richies? They go for whatever billionaire they happen to like at that moment."
Part of Conner still needs to tell everyone that his father was a fisherman, that he did not come from money or privilege.
"Has Larry Ellison been on the cover of Time?" he said.
He tells you how he sold all 31 of his America's Cup boat models to help pay for his last campaign and owes about $2 million this time. "But I have a plan," he began. "I'm going to sell one of my boats."
He may be cash poor, but Conner is worth $4.1 million, and he admits that he has a good life. He lives in San Diego with his second wife, Daintry, a 32-year-old from Greenwich, Conn., who believed in his relative bare-bones quest as much as he did.
"It was like a fairy tale to her, a ticker-tape parade up Fifth Avenue, turn right up 44th Street," he said, alluding to the New York Yacht Club. "She envisioned it."
What's wrong with American sailing?
"If you had kids, you wouldn't want them to be sailors," Conner said. "You want them to go to the best schools you could afford. Our best and brightest aren't encouraged to stick with this sport.
"Here, because the sailing pays so well relative to the rest of the economy, it's a great way to increase your station in life and your happiness quotient. If you're a great sailor here, it's better from a financial standpoint than being a doctor, lawyer or a businessman. I think the best-paid person in all of New Zealand is in pro sports. You know who it is? Tiger Woods's caddie."
The double takes outnumbered the waves in the Hauraki Gulf, with everyone wondering how they got to race against Conner. Not that Conner was above anyone. When a boatful of young, aggressive Kiwi sailors jibed left and seemed to have passing rights, Conner went right and came within inches of planting the side of his boat into their stern. They began raising their voices.
"Don't look at them," he said. "Don't look at them."
Like cutting someone off during a rush-hour commute, when you don't look, it means you are just oblivious, not malicious. The Kiwis wanted him to take his penalty turn, a 270-degree turn that essentially kills your position, but Dirty Dennis kept tacking along. He finished strong.
To the surprise of Brun and the crew, Conner cut across the entire fleet of another class beginning a race, waving to each skipper as his boat came within a few feet of them, like an overseas jaywalker pleading ignorance with the locals: "Thank you, thank you."
"I can't believe we made it," said Brun, who has been in his share of scrapes. 
The race over, Conner walked into his food supply shack when he got off the boat. He brought American mayonnaise, his own pork and beans, as if it were a long camping trip. "The richies have their own personal chefs, but I cook for my guys," he said. 
He poured himself a coffee cup full of Mount Gay Rum. "My sponsor," Conner said, hoisting the bottle. He added maybe two tablespoons of Diet Coke to top it off. Then Conner drove down to the yacht club bar to find out the results.
"It's Din-nis," the crowd whispered. His boat finished 5th out of 12, but because of its size he won the competition by 10 minutes on handicap. The prize was a bottle of Mount Gay Rum. Conner took the microphone from the host.
"These guys wanted me to take my penalty out there, but I'm giving them something more precious," he said, handing the bottle to the crew he cut off. "They deserve it."
The crowd raised glasses and clapped for the rotund American they once hated. Glenn Cunningham, wearing Birkenstocks and jeans, was among them. 
"He was public enemy No. 1," Cunningham said. "But over the years, you realize he's such a competitor. He's a warrior. He sheds a tear, you know? How many other America's Cup people come in here and drink with us?" 
In the bar, how many people Conner cut off does not seem to matter much anymore. How many people he has made feel small to make himself feel big is not the issue, either. At his age, the grievances ebb like the tide. Left is an old sailor, 60 in his gait but 20 in his mind, walking out of the yacht club that keeps the Cup that he used to own. 
"Forget the four wins, it's only been lost three times and I've lost it twice," Conner said with a rueful smile. He kept walking. A salty breeze caked his face and the sun receded behind the harbor bridge.
What will he do now that he is out of this competition?
"I'm here," Conner said. "I'm still in it. I'm part of it. There's another rum race next week."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Verizon Workers Laid Off In Westchester and Putnam

BYLINE:  By Nancy Haggerty

 BODY:
About 250 Verizon employees based in Westchester and Putnam found themselves out of work Thursday as part of the company's layoff of 2,400 workers statewide.
 Verizon, which operates in 29 states, Washington and Puerto Rico, attributed the cutback to the slumping economy, consumers' use of alternate technology and losses associated with the mandated sale and lease of its telecom network. 
 The company had employed 2,500 people in Westchester and more than 100 in Putnam, said a Verizon spokesman, John Bonomo. He said its dozens of offices in those counties would remain open.
Mr. Bonomo declined to say how many jobs were lost locally, but the Communication Workers of America, the union representing the majority of those affected, said casualties included 238 field technicians, as well as drivers, clerical workers and others.
Other companies in the area have also laid off workers recently. Last month, the Bank of New York laid off 51 of 71 workers in Westchester involved in employee investment, according to Robert Lillpopp, a spokesman for the state Department of Labor.
Clyde Jones, an account executive with the federally financed One-Stop Employment Center in White Plains, said that Michael Anthony Jewelers of Mount Vernon had also announced the layoff of about 100 workers. 
Mr. Lillpopp said his office had not received notice of any other pending cutbacks in the area.
"We're still holding our own in Westchester County in regard to what's occurring throughout the U.S.," said Sal Carrera, the county's director of economic development. Nancy Haggerty

HEADLINE: A Silver Lining to Scandals: More Are Drawn to Accounting 

BYLINE:  By THOM WEIDLICH 

 BODY:
JACOB M. KOLLAKUZHIYIL had been thinking for some time of moving on from his midsize accounting firm in Manhattan, where he had worked five years, to one of the big players. Mr. Kollakuzhiyil, a certified public accountant, wanted to crunch numbers for national and multinational companies instead of the smaller accounts he had been handling.
 So this summer, when he received a number of phone calls from headhunters, he readily agreed to the interviews. Five weeks later, he had a new employer. 
 "I was a little surprised," said Mr. Kollakuzhiyil, who began work at Ernst & Young in late October. "I thought it was going to be a little more difficult to find a job than it was."
Mr. Kollakuzhiyil's experience, it appears, is not all that unusual. Despite -- and maybe even partly because of -- the drubbing that the reputation of accountants has taken lately, they seem to be faring pretty well in the job market, both nationally and in New York.
The large accounting companies, and especially the big four -- PricewaterhouseCoopers, Deloitte & Touche, Ernst & Young and KPMG -- have absorbed accountants (and their clients) from their imploded former competitor Arthur Andersen and are still hiring others. Not only that, accounting is gaining, not declining, in popularity as a major in colleges.
As with most businesses, companies looking to hire accountants had a tough time finding people during the recent boom years, as many C.P.A.'s joined dot-coms and other start-ups. The accounting industry experienced the hangover once the party ended, but it now seems to have revived better than most.
For one thing, accounting is not cyclical; just as people must eat even in bad times, companies must do their books even when those books look bleak. And just as companies turn to their sales forces to make them rich when the economy is booming, they look to accountants to make them frugal when the economy sours.
"Part of the reason I picked accounting is that no matter what the economy is going through, you're always going to need an accountant," said Melanie R. Cobb, a student at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., who spent last summer as an intern at Deloitte & Touche and just accepted a job with its Parsippany, N.J., office.
The pay isn't bad, either. A survey released in November by Robert Half International, a recruiting firm for the financial industry, showed that in New York, where salaries are the highest in the country, a beginning accountant in audit, tax and management services at a large public accounting firm can expect to earn $54,000 to $63,000, a 1.6 percent increase over last year. A senior accountant in such a firm can expect to make $72,800 to $91,900 in 2003, an increase of 2.8 percent over the current year.
Paradoxically, the accounting scandals that have roiled corporate America over the last year may actually have made accounting more attractive to young people. In a recent survey in the CPA Personnel Report newsletter, accounting professors agreed that the scandals have raised accounting's visibility among students and increased its desirability as a possible career option. The article was headlined: "It's Hot! It's Sexy! It's ... Accounting?"
"I think the green eyeshade has been discarded and it's cool to be an accountant," said Lisa P. Young, director of recruiting for Ernst & Young.
T. Edward Hollander, director of the M.B.A. program in professional accounting at Rutgers, said the increased popularity of his program this year -- it had 115 applications rather than the typical 50 -- "may have a lot to do with the publicity" over accounting scandals.
"When students read that accountants are so important to the economy, they wonder whether they should go into it," Mr. Hollander said. "The effect has been positive."
The scandals may be helping in another way. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 requires more stringent procedures for top executives to sign off on financial statements. Those executives, in turn, are making underlings do likewise. And all those senior managers need expert advice.
"Sarbanes-Oxley has created enormous job opportunities for people," said Jeffrey R. Hoops, partner with Ernst & Young and president-elect of the New York State Society of C.P.A.'s.
The stumbling economy has also probably increased the lure of a profession that offers job security and good money. Whatever the reason, the number of students who majored in accounting rose by 2 percent in the 2000-01 academic year, after declining in the boom years of the late 1990's, according to the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. And Beatrice Sanders, the institute's director of academic and career development, says numbers for 2001-02 appear to show even more interest in the field.
On the demand side, a survey by the National Association of Colleges and Employers on the degrees projected to be most desired by companies this academic year showed that accounting jumped to No. 1 from No. 3 last year across the nation, and remained at No. 1, where it was last year, in the Northeast.
The public accounting firms are just now finishing up the bulk of their college hiring and preparing for the busy tax season. But they are expected to continue adding people next year at a strong clip.
Blane Ruschak, national director of campus recruiting for KPMG, for example, said that while campus hiring for 2001 and 2002 remained "pretty flat," at about 200 people in the New York metropolitan area, the firm expects the number to be "slightly up" for 2003.
And Cindy Beeman, KPMG's national director of recruiting, who handles the hiring of experienced accountants, said that in the 2002 fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, KPMG hired 800 such professionals in New York and that the company will probably do the same this year.
"The level of business hasn't gone away, it's increasing," Ms. Beeman said.
It is unclear exactly what effect the demise of Arthur Andersen will have on the job market. While the large firms did buy many practices from Andersen, both in New York and across the country, those accountants also had many clients to keep them busy.
The Andersen people by now have "filtered out of the system," said Al Tretola, a C.P.A. and principal with the Gotham Search Group, accounting recruiters in Manhattan.
But others say many new and experienced professionals who had offers from Andersen are still out there looking.
Michael A. Godlewski, a senior at Rutgers, said he began his job search in October, interviewing with five firms in Manhattan and New Jersey, including PricewaterhouseCoopers and Deloitte & Touche. Although he has yet to nail down a job (he has one offer pending), he remains optimistic. 
"I feel the market is definitely there, especially with the collapse of Andersen," Mr. Godlewski said. "It brings a lot of opportunity. There's so much more work because of the focus on audits."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jacob M. Kollakuzhiyil, a new accountant for Ernst & Young, was surprised at how easy it was to land the job. (Timothy Ivy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-22-02: QUESTIONS FOR SENATOR JOHN MCCAIN; 
Presidential Adviser

BYLINE:  By David Wallis 

 BODY:
Q: President Bush took office two years ago. Give him a midterm grade.
A minus/B plus. He rallied the country after 9/11. He has been clear-cut 
in his vision on the war on terrorism. 
He gets an A minus for the economy? 
On the economy I would give him a lower grade, probably a C.
Did you support the president's firing of his economic team? And was it handled well?
As far as Mr. O'Neill is concerned, it was handled in very rough fashion. This is a tough town. I appreciated Mr. O'Neill's candor. It's all too lacking around this town -- and in this administration. I did not know Mr. Lindsey at all, and perhaps that's a commentary on his effectiveness. Given the challenges we face with this economy, I think it's probably a good idea to bring in a new team.
You write in your memoir, "Worth the Fighting For," that to achieve your goals in politics, "you need a swift, hard punch to break through the public's skepticism." What has been the hardest punch landed by either opponent in the campaign-finance fight?
An effort to disparage my reputation. You see, if you can destroy McCain's integrity, then he has no credibility on the issue. That's been their strategy.
Do you believe that there is an organized effort to silence you?
I don't believe it's organized in that there's a cabal that spends its time in a conspiracy to destroy John McCain. But I know that they work together. I saw that in the court challenge to campaign finance reform.
Define "they."
It's interesting. From the A.C.L.U. to the Christian Coalition. From the Republican National Committee to the Democratic Committee of California. And the N.R.A. 
It's generally both extremes on both right and left. 
There's a lot of concern that a war in Iraq will bring higher oil prices and cripple the economy. Why do you think that weaning ourselves off Middle Eastern oil and developing alternative energy sources has not become more of a pressing national security issue?
It's an issue of leadership. I think the American people need to be informed by our president that if we are really ever going to have the degree of independence that we should have, it requires a reduction of our dependence on imported oil. That means certain sacrifices must be made by the American people.
Is the president calling on Americans to sacrifice enough?
If I had advice for the president, I would ask a lot more of the people who are ready to give. I would demand as my top priority legislation increasing national service programs. Also, recognize that climate change is real and start developing concrete policies to address it. The Glacier National Park with no more glaciers. Remarkable.
Do you think President Bush's tax policy embodies compassionate conservatism?
No, I don't, because I believe that low-income Americans in totality bear a much higher tax burden than wealthy Americans do, therefore there is a growing gap between the wealthiest and poorest Americans. At least the tax burden should be equitable.
Any ideas on how to jump-start the economy?
We probably need to have tax cuts directed at lower-income Americans, such as payroll-tax reductions, but I also think that as long as there continues to be corporate corruption, investor confidence will not be restored and the economy will not be restored. I think we need to put some people in jail.
Including Ken Lay?
 I would let the courts decide and then hang him. David Wallis

HEADLINE: FILM; 
Man With a Mission: Get the Film Made

BYLINE:  By ANNE THOMPSON; Anne Thompson is based in Los-Angeles and writes the Hollywood column for New York magazine.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
FOR four years, George Clooney waited to play Jim Byrd, the Zen-cool agent who recruits a fast-living television producer for the C.I.A. in the film version of Chuck Barris's bizarre 1984 memoir, "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind: An Unauthorized Biography."
 With its claim that his high-profile career as the instigator of television tripe like "The Gong Show" and "The Dating Game" had masked an undercover job as a government assassin, Mr. Barris's wacky, James-Bond-in-Hollywood account of sex, murder and intrigue seemed ripe for the movies. Mr. Clooney had fallen in love with a script written by Charlie Kaufman ("Being John Malkovich," "Adaptation"), and he clung to the role of Byrd as the project passed from hand to hand. 
 "It was as good an acting part as I'd had," he said recently. "The drag was, I watched the script change with different actors and directors attached." 
Bryan Singer, Sam Mendes and Curtis Hanson were among the would-be directors; Sean Penn, Mike Myers and Johnny Depp were among the possible Chucks. "Five times it had the green light, five times it fell apart," Mr. Barris said.
He had been awaiting a movie version of his story even longer than Mr. Clooney had -- since the 1980's, when Columbia Pictures was ready to film the book with Jim McBride ("The Big Easy") as director. But the project never got off the ground, Mr. McBride said, because he couldn't find a star willing to play Barris. "His reputation on TV was outrageous and vulgar," Mr. McBride said. The very idea of playing him "so offended Richard Dreyfuss that he wouldn't even read the script." 
"Confessions of a Dangerous Mind," the film version of Mr. Barris's book, finally opens on Dec. 31 in New York and Los Angeles. And it isn't because a big star was persuaded to play the leading role. It isn't because the current popularity of "reality" television has burnished Mr. Barris's reputation. It's because Mr. Clooney decided to direct it, and to stock it with enough other big names to make its quirky story viable in the marketplace. Julia Roberts, as a bad-to-the-bone Mata Hari, and Drew Barrymore, as a marijuana-smoking hippie, play the two women sparring for Barris's affection, and Matt Damon and Brad Pitt appear in cameos as "Dating Game" contestants.
Even with such stars, and with the admired but little-known Sam Rockwell playing Barris, the movie's box-office appeal is far from assured. A mixture of noir thriller, dark comedy and raucous satire, "Confessions" would be a risky undertaking for any director. Mr. Clooney was a first-timer. But he dived into the enterprise with characteristic brio, creating an exuberant tour through the frenzied mind of Chuck Barris and through three decades of American show business.
Recounting the history of his involvement in an interview at his Laurel Canyon home, a low-slung mock-Tudor tucked into a hillside, Mr. Clooney explained how he had ended up directing: "I didn't wake up and say I wanted to be a director. I wanted to be involved in getting the movie made, because I thought the script was that good. And it was starting to look as though it wasn't going to happen. I also felt, if I was ever going to direct, it had better be with the best screenplay I'd ever read."
Like a kid with a new train set, Mr. Clooney was bursting with enthusiasm as he described his work on the movie. "I knew I could create shots, steal from my favorite directors and work with actors," he said. He bounded upstairs to fetch evidence: a fat loose-leaf binder of black-and-white cartoon storyboards for every shot in the movie, which is jammed with complex cinematic feats. "The knock on me will be that it's over-directed," he said.
Ms. Barrymore and Mr. Rockwell had no such knocks. Ms. Barrymore was interested in being in the film even before Mr. Clooney became the director, she said in a telephone interview last week. "When George got involved, I knew it would get made the way it was supposed to get made, and I wanted to be a part of it more than ever. George is an amazing actors' director."
Mr. Rockwell compared Mr. Clooney on the set to the captain of a ship. "You jump off the bridge for George," he said. An actor's actor whose supporting performances in "Charlie's Angels," "The Heist" and "The Green Mile" won him a fair amount of attention, Mr. Rockwell said he was still recovering from the emotional and physical toll of playing Barris. "You have to do comedy and drama and mimic the person," he said. "There was a lot of pressure on me and George." 
The first shot on the first day, Mr. Clooney said, was one in which Mr. Rockwell had to stand naked in front of a television set in a hotel room. "It would be my worst nightmare," Mr. Clooney said, to spend his first day of work standing naked in front of strangers. But Mr. Rockwell was fine; it was Mr. Clooney who felt awkward. "I was really self-conscious," he said. "I was nervous about just saying things like 'Action!' and 'Cut!' But also, I was overly prepared. This movie required leadership, standing up in the trenches and saying, 'We can do this thing!' and not ever allowing a word of doubt to come in." 
Doubts, of course, are what Mr. Barris, 70, had to contend with from the moment his book was published. Now writing a sequel, "Bad Grass Never Dies," he deflected the inevitable questions about the accuracy of his memoirs by saying, "There are areas of the C.I.A. that I just won't talk about." Mr. McBride's take on the material he had hoped to direct in the 80's is that "the book never made his spying so outrageous that it wasn't half-plausible."
He added, "You kept asking yourself, 'Could this possibly have happened?' "
In acting the role, Mr. Rockwell said, "I had to do it as if it were real." But he has his doubts: "I think the main thing about Chuck is, he wants respect. Being an assassin, having an alter ego, is about him finding a way to respect himself."
For his part, Mr. Clooney said he didn't care whether Mr. Barris's book is true. "Chuck is a gentle soul who is exorcising demons," he said. "I don't want to know the facts, I just want to tell the story."
It was Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of Miramax Films, who allowed him to do so. At the 11th hour, Mr. Weinstein agreed to back the producer Andrew Lazar, who had optioned the film rights in 1997. Mr. Weinstein flew to Las Vegas for a four-hour meeting with Mr. Clooney at the Bellagio Hotel. "He talked about his vision for the movie," Mr. Weinstein said. "He's untested, but he knows how to surround himself. We went on gut instinct." Gut instinct and shrewd bargaining. "What distinguishes George," said Mr. Weinstein, "is that he understands the economics of moviemaking. He's the first guy to cut his salary."
In fact, Mr. Clooney has made salary reform something of a mission: as he did on "Ocean's Eleven," he persuaded co-stars like Ms. Roberts to lower their asking price as well. It's about being able to gamble on riskier productions by casting several stars rather than one. With his producing partner, Steven Soderbergh, Mr. Clooney made "Ocean's Eleven" and "Solaris"; their company, Section Eight, also helped make "Insomnia," "Far From Heaven" and "Welcome to Collinwood." The theory is that it's smarter to finance and market a $30 million movie with three stars than a $40 million movie with only one. "If you do that," Mr. Clooney said, "you're free to try and pick the best films possible. When you're a star who green-lights a picture, you start having responsibility for what kind of pictures get made. I want to be in movies I'm proud of."
Mr. Lazar, the producer, said that Mr. Clooney had to do more than drop his salary before the final deal was struck, particularly since Mr. Weinstein was holding out for a big star to play Barris and Mr. Clooney's choice was Mr. Rockwell, with whom he had acted in "Welcome to Collinwood." "George jumped through a lot of hoops for Harvey," Mr. Lazar said. To get to cast Mr. Rockwell, Mr. Clooney had to promise to make another movie for Mr. Weinstein and do a cameo in the next "Spy Kids" sequel -- until he landed Ms. Roberts and Ms. Barrymore.
Two days after he wrapped "Confessions," in April, he started shooting "Solaris." He worked with the editor of "Confessions" during his breaks and into the night (he gets by on four or five hours of sleep). The day after "Solaris" wrapped, he began his second film for the Coen brothers, the black comedy "Intolerable Cruelty." "You just get through it and focus on the one day ahead," he said. "If you think about a week, it'll kill you."
So will he direct again? "I'm hooked," he said. "I'm having the time of my life."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Hard Truths Are Avoided On Social Security

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
DON'T believe what was said about Social Security during this year's election campaign.
 Not the claim by Republicans that they could reform Social Security so that workers could divert part of their payroll taxes into private investment accounts with no risk that benefits would ever be reduced. 
 Nor the Democrats' assertion that the program, the government's largest, needs no more than small, painless adjustments.
And don't believe the polls from the major political parties, each of which asked questions designed to prove that the public was solidly on its side. 
Or the sentiment in the mean-spirited animated cartoon distributed by the Democratic National Committee that showed President Bush pushing a woman in a wheelchair down a slope representing a falling stock market -- supposedly a metaphor for what Mr. Bush's Social Security plan would mean for retirees.
Or the contention that many Republicans were elected to Congress in November after vigorously advocating private investment accounts under Social Security.
Politicians do not tell the truth about Social Security for one reason: the truth is too hard to bear.
Democrats cannot face the fact that this crown jewel of the New Deal -- the most popular program ever devised by the federal government, the central plank of every Democratic platform for more than 65 years -- will begin running out of money during the lifetime of most of today's workers and that, without changes, those promised retirement benefits cannot be paid. 
The reason is demographics, which no one can alter. Social Security works on the principle that each generation of workers pays taxes that cover its parents' retirement benefits. There are now 3.4 people employed for each retiree. At the end of this decade, when baby boomers begin to retire, the ratio will be 3.1, and by 2030, there will be only 2.1 workers paying taxes for each retiree.
Republicans have long resented the political mileage Democrats get from Social Security and have dreamed of making the system more like a private pension plan and less like a government welfare program. They cannot cope with the reality that instituting private investment accounts under Social Security would cost hundreds of billions of dollars in the first 10 years alone. Or that if markets went down and not up, lower-income retirees might become destitute in their old age.
The huge additional cost would result from the government's need to keep writing checks to retirees at the same time a portion of workers' taxes that would otherwise be used for benefits would be going into private accounts.
President Bush and his allies were cheered this year when a number of Republican candidates who did not abandon the principle of private Social Security accounts won tough races for the House and Senate. This proved, some Republicans said, that Social Security was no longer the third rail of American politics: instant political death for anyone who tampers with it.
But close scrutiny of their campaigns shows that few if any of these Republicans dealt with the matter squarely. 
Senator-elect John Cornyn of Texas, for example, asserted on the campaign trail, "We will never, ever, as long as I serve in the United States Senate, cut the benefits of retirees." (In one debate, his Democratic opponent, Ron Kirk, said: "John, you're a smart guy. You can't promise that money to our parents and promise it to us.")
THE ugly truth is that sooner or later, under every reasonable proposal to shore up the retirement program, taxes would be raised or benefits would be reduced or money would be shifted to Social Security from other government programs. Most likely, there would be a combination of the three.
But before any resolution is reached, the politicians need to bridge the philosophical gulf that divides those who are comfortable with a huge, government-run social program that involves almost every American from those who believe that, by and large, people should be responsible for preparing for their own retirement.
Logically, President Bush would offer his Social Security proposal early next year, and Congress would begin work on the matter at once. The sooner changes are made, the less disruptive they will be. 
But the president may be wary about spending the political capital needed for a big push on Social Security the year before he seeks re-election. And no one has ever accused Congress of being logical. 
The best bet is that action will be postponed until the crisis is on the doorstep, not just on the horizon.
