HEADLINE: Hong Kong Moves Ahead On Tightening Security Laws 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
The government here ended a public comment period today on plans for tough internal security laws, including a ban on the mere possession of "seditious" publications, brushing aside objections from businesses, human rights groups and foreign governments. 
 The government said it would introduce legislation as soon as practicable, with the goal of winning final passage by July. However, the government indicated that adjustments would be made to its plans based on the public comments that have been received. 
 Timothy Tong, Hong Kong's acting secretary of security, said tonight that while officials were aware of polls showing that up to 70 percent of the residents here had a negative view of the plans, they would still start the legislative process by February. 
"Hong Kong, being an inalienable part of the People's Republic of China, has both moral and constitutional obligations to protect national security," he said at a news conference.
Yet after receiving more than 90,000 comments on the proposal, government officials are likely to revise some provisions, Mr. Tong said.
"We will consider how best we can improve on our proposals and allay as far as possible worries raised by different sectors, such as those over the possession of seditious publications, increased police powers and unauthorized access to protected information." he said. "We believe there will be some adjustments to our proposals in the light of the views received."
Britain handed over this territory to China in 1997 after receiving a promise, enshrined in the territory's Basic Law, that China would respect Hong Kong's separate legal and economic systems for at least 50 years under the principle of "One Country, Two Systems."
But the Basic Law also contains a provision, Article 23, that requires new internal security laws after the handover.
A wide range of critics, from the American Chamber of Commerce to Amnesty International to the European Parliament, as well as democracy advocates here, had urged the government to issue a draft text of the legislation for public comment before asking the Legislative Council to take up the issue. The critics complained of ambiguities in the so-called consultation document in which the government outlined its plans.
"The government spent four years to draft that consultation document but has only given us two months to look at it," said Bella Luk, the director of the Hong Kong section of Amnesty International, which also petitioned unsuccessfully today for an extension of the comment period.
An additional period of public comment for a draft text of the legislation would give opponents another chance to oppose provisions like one that would allow even fairly junior police commanders to order searches and seizures without a warrant in security cases, and another that lengthens prison sentences and increases fines for sedition.
Banks and other businesses have been particularly alarmed by proposals for stringent penalties for the unauthorized release of government information, fearing that, as on the mainland, such a provision could be used to inhibit free speech about economic indicators or even the financial health of Chinese state-owned enterprises. Mr. Tong said that this concern would receive attention and might prompt revisions.
The government here has repeatedly pointed out that its proposal would actually narrow the grounds on which residents and foreigners could be tried for some offenses. Hong Kong already has fairly stringent security laws on its books. 
Mr. Tong said tonight that the executive branch here would proceed with its original plan to send the new internal security laws directly to the Legislative Council in February as a so-called blue bill, which discourages filibusters and amendments.
The bill would go through numerous hearings, but under the rules, the Legislative Council would be compelled to vote on the bill before adjourning in July. The measure is expected to pass.
Some Chinese nationalists here have embraced the government's proposal, contending that the laws will help make sure that Chinese rule over Hong Kong is never threatened.
They also contend that recent American antiterrorism efforts show that Hong Kong's efforts are part of an international trend toward balancing respect for civil rights with security worries.
"You need a lock for your door to prevent a thief from breaking in," said Ma Lik, the secretary general of the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong, a pro-Beijing political party.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Fire Destroys More Than a Mixed-Use Project

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 18 

 BODY:
The town houses, seated on a $10 million platform atop spaces leased to restaurateurs and retailers, looked complete. Inside, the insulation was in place, but the sprinkler system was not, nor was the drywall.
 City officials have not issued a report on how the Aug. 19 fire started, though they have said that it was the costliest in San Jose's history. Flames destroyed more than 100 apartments and town houses at Santana Row, an upscale mixed-use development by the Federal Realty Investment Trust that was a month short of its formal opening. 
 Steven J. Guttman, chief executive of the REIT, said he saw smoke and called 911. "They say they were here in two minutes, but it felt like the longest two minutes of my life." 
The fire delayed the opening of Santana Row, but its effects on the development -- and its cash flow -- left Wall Street analysts who had questioned Mr. Guttman's stewardship of Federal Realty feeling vindicated.
They had repeatedly assailed the project, saying that the company concentrated far too many resources and assets in one place.
The circumstances that put Mr. Guttman in a position to build Santana Row, and the price he has paid for his ambitious decisions, demonstrate the obstacles to creating the kind of large-scale, mixed-use projects, influenced by the new urbanism philosophy, that many cities desire.
Mr. Guttman initiated Santana Row, and he moved here, across the country from corporate headquarters in Maryland, to see it through. Last March, under criticism from Wall Street for putting so much of Federated Realty's money into Santana Row, he announced plans to resign as chief executive, and Federal Realty has indicated that it will back away from projects like this one.
 Dec. 20, the company announced that Mr. Guttman's resignation would take effect on Jan. 1 and that he would also resign as chairman then. Shares of Federal Realty have rallied since the announcement, closing at $28.75 yesterday, a 52-week high. 
"My wife will tell you I'm obsessive," Mr. Guttman said in a recent interview. Among other things, he has become obsessive about fire. Touring the site in September, when it still smelled of smoke and mildew, Mr. Guttman stopped at one point, fell silent and shivered at the sight of a construction worker with a torch. Asked if he was all right, he said: "I was watching that guy with the fire."
Planned as a $500 million development, Santana Row is densely zoned and ornately decorated with imported arts, ornamental fountains and tile mosaics intended to evoke the legacy of the Catalan architect Antonio Gaudi. 
It was built without assistance from the City of San Jose, using equity capital from the REIT, which it had raised from shareholders.
City planners and urban economists across the country are clamoring for projects of this sort -- a series of interlocking streets where places to shop, live and work are clustered with public spaces. But paying for such ambitious projects is challenging.
Discussing Federal Realty's investment in Santana Row, Matthew L. Ostrower, an analyst at Morgan Stanley who covers retail-oriented real estate investment trusts, said, "The rents at which it will be desirable to tenants will never justify what was spent on the project."
The company, he said, allocated too much money to buy land and infrastructure for several city blocks, leaving its investors with low short-term yields. 
"The markets just don't provide patient capital, generally speaking," Mr. Ostrower said. "Steve Guttman regarded himself as something of a visionary. He essentially ignored the public shareholders. Santana Row cost Steve Guttman his job."
While equity analysts assailed the short-term yields, debt analysts objected to the concentration of assets.
"You're looking at something that could wipe out 20 percent of the balance sheet of this company," said Richard S. Talmadge, the lead analyst of the company's debt at Fitch Ratings, arguing that the fire had vividly demonstrated his point. The company has filed more than $70 million in insurance claims and has been paid about $20 million so far. 
Mr. Guttman argues for a longer view than that of his critics. "REIT analysts are going to look at this in a one- or two-year microscope," he said. "We thought long term, and I still believe long term it's going to be one of the top real-estate developments in the United States."
The conundrum for proponents of new urbanism is summed up neatly at Santana Row, said Michael D. Beyard, a senior fellow at the Urban Land Institute, a research group based in Washington. "The question is what will be the type of developers to bring about these projects," Mr. Beyard said. "REIT's have the money, but not the time because they have to show steady profit," he said.
"Entrepreneurial investors have the time and inclination, but they may not have the money. That's why projects are so slow to be introduced."
Mr. Guttman was in an unusual position to bring about a mixed-use project on this scale: 22 acres in the first phase, including 441,000 square feet of retail space, a movie theater, 2,000 parking spaces, a 213-room hotel and 246 residential units.
Raised in Charleroi, Pa., a small town built around shopping centers and encircled by small towns built around steel mills, Mr. Guttman joined Federal Realty in 1972, just after graduating from George Washington University School of Law. The company's founders were former State Department officials in their 50's who had rolled $40 million in apartment building assets in the Washington area into a real estate investment trust.
They hired Mr. Guttman to handle acquisitions, and with limited capital, he bought dilapidated shopping centers, intending to renovate them and increase their profits. The strategy did not start to work until companies like the Gap and Barnes & Noble began renting spaces in small outdoor shopping centers. The company's greatest success has been Bethesda Row in Maryland, a 280,000-square-foot development that emphasizes restaurant tenants.
With that as a small model, the company bought 42 acres here, 3.5 miles from downtown, for $42 million. And then Mr. Guttman began executing ambitious plans.
He hired four architecture firms, intending to make each of the eight new buildings look as though they had been constructed at different times. He commissioned an artist to put ceiling panels evoking the 28 phases of the moon above the sidewalk. He bought an 18th-century chapel facade in the Languedoc-Roussillon region of the south of France for $28,000. He subsidized the rent on a 6,000-square-foot gallery space for Emmanuel Flipo, an artist from the south of France.
It added up. Federal Realty spent $205 million in equity capital and obtained a $295 million construction loan, which it has since retired with proceeds from the sale of more unsecured debt, bringing the company's total indebtedness to $660 million.
The roads and other infrastructure cost Federal Realty about $50 million. 
San Jose spent nothing.
"It would have been hard to declare that a blighted area," said Joseph A. Horwedel, deputy director of planning for the city. "There would have been strong opposition from other groups that depend on tax revenues."
Parts of Santana Row opened in November, two months late, with high-end specialty merchants like Gucci and Anthropologie anchored by larger Barnes & Noble and Crate & Barrel stores. Signed leases cover 331,000 square feet of retail space in all, with the remaining 100,000 square feet unleased. 
In part because of the fire, only 177,000 square feet of the retail space -- 41 stores including sidewalk vendors -- is open for business. Many of the companies, especially those opening a first or second store, were uninsured.
Most of the retail spaces are small, and so Santana Row is directly -- and successfully -- competing for tenants with Union Square in San Francisco, said Kazuko Morgan, a senior director of retail services for the real estate services firm Cushman & Wakefield.
Mr. Guttman said that if he had it to do over, he would not have concentrated such a high percentage of his company's assets in one project. "Federal Realty, in hindsight, would have been better not doing this project," he said.
As Mr. Guttman, who has taken up smoking again, showed a visitor around Santana Row last week, he ground his cigarette butt out on a garbage can, then crushed the visitor's discarded cigarette under his shoe for a good five seconds to ensure that it had been extinguished.

HEADLINE: A Christmas List for a Song This Year 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

 BODY:
Deflation hit true love this year -- at least the type spelled out in "The 12 Days of Christmas."
 Each year, as holiday spending reaches its seasonal frenzy, a Pennsylvania financial services firm offers its own quirky take on the economy, and this year, it calculates, the gifts spun out in the song -- from a perching partridge to drummers drumming -- would run to $14,558.06. 
 An expensive Christmas, true, and it counts on old-fashioned legwork to buy everything from the partridge's pear-tree perch to booking the milking maids and leaping lords. But the price, according to the PNC Financial Services Group in Pittsburgh, which has been putting together the index for nearly two decades, is down 7.6 percent from last year. 
And for what it's worth: Only twice before, in 1988 and 1995, did the index fall.
It would probably be fruitless to look for savings on the Internet, though. If you turn to the Web, the price zooms up to $24,595.28 -- 3.6 percent higher than a year ago -- though some items are cheaper.
Still, just look at the bargains to be found in our wobbly economy. Swans, for instance. Seven "a-swimming" are required -- and they have dropped to $300 each from $500 last year. Breeders, it seems, have an oversupply of trumpeter swans, said Rebekah McCahan, who has been compiling the light-hearted information for PNC since 1986.
And there is a surfeit of pear trees this year, with one Philadelphia-area nursery selling them at 30 percent less than last year, for $87.50 versus $125.
"Over all, we've seen the price of goods drop, which reflects what is happening in retail, where there are big discounts to encourage consumer spending and increase sales," Ms. McCahan said.
Gold prices rose, though, with five simple gold bands now going for $382.50, up 2 percent from $375 last year. Buying the rings online, though, would cut the price more than half.
Pipers and drummers, from the local musicians' union, were relatively cheap -- 11 pipers for $1,641.60 -- no increase over 2001, she said. But the leaping lords (from a Philadelphia dance troupe, Philadanco) and dancing ladies (hired from the Pennsylvania Ballet) were more expensive. Ten lords-a-leaping cost $3,921, up 4 percent, and the nine female dancers rose 2.2 percent, to $4,107, up considerably from their $1,602 price tag in 1986, Ms. McCahan said.
Eight maids-a-milking cost the same as last year -- $41.60 for an hour of minimum-wage toil, or $296.32 if hired via the Internet -- although Ms. McCahan acknowledged that such a service is hard to find these days because most milking is automated.
You might want to get them while you can. Over all, the price of the gifts is likely to rise again.
"As we see hiring plans improving and wages on the rise, we expect to see a rise in our Christmas Price Index next year," said Jeff Kleintop, the chief strategist at PNC's investment advisory group.
But never fear: the lords will leap again, the ladies will dance.

HEADLINE: Indians Fight to Regain Lands Lost to Railroad 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: LEECH LAKE RESERVATION, Minn. 

 BODY:
Richard Robinson Jr. remembers how much his grandfather Martin Bobolink, a hospital janitor, looked forward to retiring and returning to his land here. "He told us there was buried treasure there because his dad had put up gangsters," said Mr. Robinson, the acting chairman of the Leech Lake band of the Ojibwe tribe.
 But Mr. Bobolink quickly learned that the land and any loot that might be on it was not his. The Bureau of Indian Affairs told him he had signed the land over to the United States in exchange for a few thousand dollars. 
 "He swore until he died that he never received a check and never signed any papers," Mr. Robinson said. "He was dead certain." 
The story is a common one in what used to be Indian country, before the the relentless westward push of white settlers and railroads. Among the most effective tools of expropriation were nine laws passed by Congress in 1887, at the behest of James J. Hill, head of the Great Northern Railroad, and other railroad owners, which ensured that huge chunks of Indian land ended up in the hands of industrialists, homesteaders or, as in Mr. Bobolink's case, the United States government.
Now a chunk of the Hill fortune has been dedicated to reassembling that land and returning it to Indian control.
The Northwest Area Foundation, a $424 million philanthropy established by Hill's heirs, has given $20 million of seed money toward the effort, which aims to restore some 90 million acres on reservations around the country to Indian ownership.
"We're not saying it's going to be easy," said Cris Stainbrook, a Lakota who leads the Indian Land Tenure Foundation, which was created to lead the effort. "It's going to be very expensive, and probably the staff here now isn't going to be alive to see the mission completed. But it is the only way Native Americans can regain the means to preserve their sovereignty, their culture, their identity."
Philanthropy often seems tailor-made to assuage guilt, and the Great Northern was "one of the most Indian-subsidized railroads in America," wrote Michael P. Malone, a historian, in a 1996 biography of Mr. Hill. To build a railroad spanning the Northwest frontier, Mr. Hill needed a right of way through Indian country, and he used his friendships with politicians from Montana to Washington to get it.
So sharp-elbowed were the machinations of Mr. Hill and the other railroad tycoons that President Grover Cleveland initially vetoed the legislation they wanted in 1886, sharply denouncing the efforts of "a class of corporations carrying with them individuals not known for any scrupulous regard for the interest of the Indians."
Mr. Hill raged that the veto was "ridiculous" and drafted his friend William Vilas, the postmaster general, and others to persuade the president, also a friend, to reconsider, which he did. 
Indians and the tribe now own less than 5 percent of the 677,099 acres on the Leech Lake Reservation, and the population is exploding as Indians return to take jobs in casinos or lose welfare benefits and seek tribal assistance. "People are living two or three families to a trailer home or, in the warm weather, in their cars," said Pauline Johnston, director of the Leech Lake land department. "We have no place to put them."
The Hill heirs say their philanthropic efforts are guided as much by a desire to improve the community as they are to make up for their ancestor's past. "I guess you could interpret it as atonement, but I don't really think of it like that," said Louis F. Hill, a great-grandson. "If you're going to be philanthropic, why not be philanthropic in the community that brought you the wealth to begin with? That's what philanthropy traditionally has done."
He noted that other railroads got much larger land grants under the laws and that his grandfather, Louis W. Hill, was adopted by the Blackfoot tribe of Montana, which called him Graybeard, because of his efforts to bring economic development to their reservations.
Land repurchase programs are under way on reservations around the country, but the process is expensive and complicated. And the organizers of the program here recognize that $20 million will not even begin to buy back all the land the Indian Land Tenure Foundation wants to see in Indian hands.
The money will jump-start programs to educate Indians about protecting the land they do own by, for instance, writing wills that specify heirs or putting the land in trust. 
Land acquisition, by far the foundation's boldest goal, will take at least $400 million more and will require innovative private financing techniques. 
Through a series of treaties, the United States set aside 138 million acres in reservations owned by tribes and then almost immediately set about finding ways to get the land into non-Indian hands. Perhaps the most effective of those efforts was the 1887 package of laws. Six of those granted land to the railroads for expansion, and one of the other three, the General Allotment Act, supplied them their customers. 
That act redistributed reservation lands to individual Indians in 40-, 80- and 160-acre parcels that the government was to hold in trust for the new owners. Later, much of the unallocated reservation land was declared "in excess" of Indian needs and opened for development by non-Indian settlers and companies. Those settlers were customers for the railroads.
"Hill benefited, Harriman benefited, the whole series of railroad tycoons benefited from this systematic displacement of Indians from their land and their replacement by European settlers," said Karl Stauber, president of the Northwest Area Foundation, referring to Edward Harriman, one of James Hill's competitors.
Recovering reservation land that has passed into private or public ownership will be a big challenge. The largest block of land on the Leech Lake Reservation is part of Chippewa National Forest, and much of the lakefront property around the reservation's three biggest lakes is in private hands.
Property owners are more and more aware of Indian efforts to regain reservation land, and their asking prices get higher when a tribe shows an interest, Indians in Leech Lake said.
The Leech Lake band's budget for land reclamation this year is $435,000, all it could spare from the $12 million it earned in casino revenues; much of the rest was eaten up by necessities like housing, health care and education. In November, it spent most of the yearly budget to buy 425 acres at $1,000 an acre from a Sioux Indian.
Discrimination also keeps land out of reach. "The land over there on that corner is ours," Ms. Johnston of the Leech Lake land department, said, pointing out plots the band has recovered. "They didn't want to sell to Indians, so we used a white guy who helped us buy it."
Even the land that is in the hands of individual Indians poses problems for the foundation. The Allotment Act, which was shepherded through Congress by Senator Henry Dawes of Massachusetts, a friend of James Hill, gave Indians ownership of parcels of land, but as the land moved into the hands of their offspring, they owned the land collectively unless otherwise spelled out in a will.
"It's like owning a share of stock in a company," said Annabell Kingbird, assistant director of the land department. "In the same way a shareholder can't walk into a company and point to a desk or a computer and say 'that's mine,' an interest holder cannot point to any land and call it his."
Because the concept of private property was traditionally alien to Indians, many of them did not write wills. Left to the discretion of the probate court, ownership of the original allotments has become highly splintered.
Lee Turney's mother, for instance, left no will when she died in 1955. Her estate, four allotments totaling 110 acres, was in probate until the spring of last year. The court divided interest in the land equally among 210 descendants.
Mr. Turney, who lives on land owned by the tribe, holds interests of a little more than a tenth of an acre in each of the four parcels. "There is absolutely nothing I can do with that land, nothing at all," he said.
Even if he wanted to try, he would have to get the approval of a majority of the other 209 owners. "I guess I probably know about 10 of them, and that's being generous," he said. "I wouldn't even want to attempt to do anything. Families have enough divisions without this one."
Della Kingbird's mother used a gift deed to give her daughter an interest representing almost seven acres of an 80 acre parcel. In 1996, Ms. Kingbird got approval from 51 percent of the other owners to build a house on the land -- only to have the largest stakeholder die, voiding the approval process. "I gave up," she said.
She now lives on land adjacent to that plot. Not only did she have to buy it, she pays taxes on it, which she would not have had to do on the land her mother left her. 
Mr. Stainbrook of the Indian Land Tenure Foundation says he believes James Hill would have appreciated the foundation's efforts to end such complexity. 
"In some ways, I don't think James J. Hill would have been against what we're trying to do with his money," Mr. Stainbrook said. "He was always for developing the land in a way that would benefit the region and the country at large, in a way that made it productive, and we're really trying to do the same thing."

HEADLINE: Advocates for Poor Criticize City's Food Stamp Program 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
A processing problem that incorrectly removed nearly 4,000 people from the city's food stamp rolls in November has added fuel to a debate between the city and hunger-relief advocates, who have for months been accusing the Human Resources Administration of discouraging eligible families from receiving food stamps. 
 The number of people receiving food stamps decreased to 825,155 last month, a drop of 10,889 people from October. 
 About 4,000 were incorrectly removed from the rolls because there was not enough staff to process routine recertification paperwork, said David Neustadt, a spokesman for the city's Human Resources Administration, which runs the federally financed voucher program locally. Mr. Neustadt said he could not explain the rest of the decline. 
News of the processing problem and the general decline in food stamp rolls drew criticism from hunger-relief advocates.
"It is nothing short of amazing that the city even admitted they messed up for one month," said Joel Berg, executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. He said the city should investigate the cause of the mistake and possibly reprimand the employees responsible.
Mr. Neustadt said an unusual confluence of events, including a wave of early staff buyouts and a particularly high number of people due to have their eligibility certified again, caused the administration to fall behind. He added that no one would be disciplined because of it. A recent change in federal law that forces the city to cut off benefits automatically to anyone who has not been recertified by deadline exacerbated the problem, he said.
The paperwork has now been processed and all those incorrectly removed have been reinstated, Mr. Neustadt said, although there was a gap in benefits in some cases. Those who lost benefits by mistake have been issued replacement benefits.
With the problem fixed and others entering the rolls for the first time, the Human Resources Administration said that it was expecting that the total number of food stamp recipients would rise to 836,152 in December.
The November numbers come as hunger-relief advocates have intensely criticized the city for mishandling the program. They have complained that with unemployment rates at 8 percent, the highest in four years, the number of those receiving food stamps has risen by less than 5 percent over the course of the year. Currently, 800,000 New Yorkers with incomes low enough to qualify for food stamps do not receive them, according to a report released last week by the Community Food Resources Center. 
Hunger-relief advocates and their allies argue that lack of outreach by the city is behind the shortfall. In New York State, only 50 percent of those eligible for the program receive food stamps, according to the most recent reports by the United States Department of Agriculture, which administers the program on a national level. Nationally, the level of participation is 59 percent.
"When that many people who deserve benefits are not getting them, then we have no functional outreach effort," said Bill de Blasio, chairman of the City Council's General Welfare Committee. He added the problems were not just with informing a larger group about their eligibility, but in making the application process less daunting.
Recently, when the City Council sent undercover investigators to Human Resources Administration offices, it reported that a third were turned away without an application even when they expressly asked for one, a clear violation of the law. "Clearly," Mr. De Blasio said, "there are still a lot of problems with how individuals are treated at H.R.A. centers."
The agency responded that there was currently a $1 million outreach campaign and that it would start two new campaigns next year -- one for immigrants. In addition, the state will give additional training to staff members who handle food stamp applications next year and is likely to cut the 16-page application to two pages.
Mr. Neustadt said the city had conducted more than 1,600 undercover investigations of the agency's offices last year and turned up only 15 cases in which workers had failed to meet legally mandated standards. 

CORRECTION-DATE: December 27, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the decrease in the number of people on New York City's food stamp rolls in November misstated the reason the city began automatically cutting off benefits to anyone who had not been recertified by deadline. The federal government recently pushed the city's Human Resources Administration to enforce an existing law; the cause was not a new law.

HEADLINE: Two Cities, Two Immigrant Landings 

 BODY:
The arrival of hundreds of poor immigrants, many without education or English skills, caused great concern in Lewiston, Me., where old-line Yankee residents worried about the town's capacity to absorb the newcomers. Tension was inevitable.
 That was more than a century and a half ago, when Irish refugees from the potato famine came in search of work, quickly followed by a wave of French Canadians who were recruited by the mills to increase production. After a sometimes violent period of getting acquainted, the American model of acceptance and cohabitation -- and eventually intermarriage -- took hold. And that was good for the town, which staked its future on thriving textile mills and shoe factories. 
 Now the descendants of those immigrants are the community pillars, facing their own test of the American way. More than 1,000 black Muslim refugees from civil war, famine and disease in Somalia, many of them originally resettled in the Atlanta area, began arriving in the town of 36,000, unannounced, nearly two years ago. The women wear native dress, and the men gather at a makeshift mosque. Nonetheless, the Somalis have worked to fit into a community that is ambivalent about them. Mayor Laurier Raymond Jr. let the strain show when he used an open letter last fall to plead with his new Somali neighbors to stop the migration.
The mayor has said that he meant no ill will, that he was simply reacting to the depletion of city services. But a point was made, and whether by coincidence or in response, the flow of Somalis to Lewiston has sharply slowed in recent weeks. That may not be good for Lewiston. In the state with the fewest nonwhites and one of the oldest and sparsest populations, Lewiston has shrunk by some 6,000 residents in the last three decades. Its young people, facing newly shuttered factories, have joined a migration from the Northeast. Lewiston enjoys low unemployment, low crime, good schools and affordable housing -- all of which lured the Somalis, who did not like the poor urban neighborhoods they left behind. Half the Somali adults are employed so far. Some are starting small businesses, while others are getting job training and learning English. They are becoming contributing members of the community, just what Lewiston needs.
In New York State, another city found itself in similar straits but has taken a different approach. That city, Schenectady, has lost nearly one-quarter of its population -- going from 80,000 to 62,000 -- since 1960. Its mayor, Albert Jurczynski, the grandson of Polish immigrants, is working to reverse that trend. "We need new blood," he says. So he is recruiting Guyanese living in New York City, 150 miles to the south. On many Saturdays, a bus takes potential resettlers from Queens for a day trip and a sales pitch that touts Schenectady's livability. With his city stronger by some 3,000 Guyanese, the mayor reports that communities are being revitalized, new businesses are opening, and property values are going up for the first time in a dozen years.
The secondary migration of both these groups is not unusual. The Hmong from Laos left Pennsylvania and Minnesota to make a community in the Central Valley of California. Large numbers of Vietnamese came together in Orange County, Calif. Bosnians have gone to Utica, N.Y. These are the Little Italys and Chinatowns of today.
In this new wave, immigrants are finding opportunities away from large cities. Their impact, especially in older, smaller towns, can be enormous and positive. Schenectady sees its future with the Guyanese. And while immigrants like the Somalis need places like Lewiston, places like Lewiston can survive only with immigrants like the Somalis.

HEADLINE: COLLEGES; 
For N.Y.U.'s Coach, the Franchise Is Not the Team

BYLINE:  By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
Janice Quinn, the New York University women's basketball coach, was drawing a parallel between her team and her new business venture, a Blimpie franchise three blocks from the N.Y.U. campus. The business, like the team, is a start-up enterprise, she said, that will have to be built from the ground up.
 "We have one senior and two juniors on the team," Quinn said the other day between sips of an amaretto coffee at her two-month-old restaurant. "The rest are freshmen who have never played college basketball before and sophomores who didn't get a lot of experience last year." 
 She looked around. "I'm the freshman here," she said. "I try hard not to forget that the team is learning, and it's been good and humbling for me to be in my own new enterprise at the same time, learning as I go."
The Violets were a perfect 6-0 to start the season, capturing the N.Y.U. Tip-Off Tournament last month before losing in overtime to Mount St. Mary's on Dec. 10, their most recent game. They have beaten good teams like SUNY-Brockport, the College of Staten Island and Skidmore.
But Quinn said it was too early in the season to allow herself or her young team, the youngest in her 16 years as coach at N.Y.U., to think about a bid to the N.C.A.A.'s Division III tournament in March.
Experienced or not, this year's team will be measured against her previous ones, and Quinn knows it. After N.Y.U. won a Division III title in 1997, great things were expected from a team that many believed could not compete at an elite level because of the university's academic rigor and the dearth of dormitories. In Quinn's first 15 seasons, the Violets went 326-89, won four University Athletic Association titles and made eight trips to the national Round of 16, four times reaching the quarterfinals and twice the semifinals.
As with the Blimpie business, Quinn is learning something new about the Violets every day and making adjustments as she goes along.
"We literally have to plan their routine for them: when to show up at the gym, how to get ready for a game, how to sit on the bench," she said with a shrug and a smile. "You can take for granted that this is game-day routine, but it's not routine if they haven't done it before."
Everything has to be taught to freshmen accustomed to playing at home in their high school gymnasiums: how to break a 1-3-1 or 2-2-1 press, how to get out of a trap; what to expect from opponents and fans on the road. 
By way of example, Quinn shared an anecdote: "We had a great game against the College of Staten Island and I was talking to the kids the day before and said: 'They're going to come at us hard. You know how hard it is to play at C.S.I.' The kids all had this strange look on their faces, and Allison Herman, my senior, said, 'Coach, actually no one has played there before.' Herman said she had mononucleosis when we played Staten Island her sophomore year."
So far, the Violets are winning with defense, defensive rebounding and their transition game. Quinn has a 3-point shooter in guard Lauren D'Ambrosio, a 5-foot-7 senior who sat out the last two years, and a versatile on-and-off-court leader in Herman, a 5-11 guard/forward who led the team last season in rebounding (8.9 a game) and blocked shots (56) and was third in scoring (12.0 points a game).
Quinn, a former star player at N.Y.U., has a master's degree in finance and management from the Wagner School of Public Service there. Her career path took her toward athletics, but starting a business has for years danced in her head like visions of sugarplums.
A year ago, a clothing store five blocks from the Coles Sports Center closed, and Quinn saw an opportunity realized.
"I've worked and lived in this community for 20 years," she said. "I eat here and know what it's like to look for choices in food. I thought of Blimpie's because you can't find anything more down to earth than a Blimpie's sandwich."
She turned to an old friend, her former N.Y.U. coach, Sherri Pickard, for help. Pickard was living in Wilmington, N.C., working on a project for the local firefighters' union and doing some investing on her own, when Quinn called.
"It was last September or October," Pickard recalled as she poured herself a cup of coffee at the store. "I had a nice, simple, uncomplicated Southern life. Then Janice called and said she was going to start a business and asked if I was interested. I said: 'Not really. I doubt it. Probably not.' But she recruited me."
Quinn plans to leave the daily operations to Pickard while focusing on her day job: coaching. Pickard, a former standout at the University of North Carolina with master's degrees in economics and accounting, describes herself as the bottom line person in the partnership. All "that other nice stuff" is Quinn, she said.
Having opened the Blimpie's doors in October, Quinn knows it is too soon to think about profit margins and expansion, not when three of five new business ventures in New York State fail in the first year of operation.
"Success was getting the business plan together, then getting the funding and putting the deal together," Quinn said. "Getting the doors open was a huge step. We are now deeply entrenched in the third phase, which is to survive the first year."
As former athletes and coaches, Quinn and Pickard bring realism to the business.
"A whole lot of it comes down to the fact that we refuse to lose," Pickard said. "The competitive spirit. In coaching, when you see something going on that you didn't anticipate, you can be hardheaded and stick with the game plan, or back up, reassess and make a change. We've had to do a lot of that. Janice had to do a lot of that to get to the point."
Quinn nodded in agreement, then said with a laugh: "You don't know how often we've said, 'Well, now we know.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: N.Y.U.'s women's basketball coach, Janice Quinn, left, and Sherri Pickard at their Blimpie franchise near the campus. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nothing Under the Tree? Those Low on Cash Go to the Pawnshop 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
With only a few shopping hours left until Christmas, Michelle Kone dashed up to the bulletproof glass at Citi Pawn in the Bronx.
 Ms. Kone, 38, slid a small envelope bulging with gold bracelets, earrings and necklaces under the window. Without looking up, the pawnbroker quickly tested the gold and divided it into two piles: 12-karat and 24-karat. Then he weighed them separately, slapped the jewelry back down on the counter and yelled a number through the slide-through cutout: $265. 
 Ms. Kone smiled. "I'll take it," she said. "The last place offered me 200."
Citi Pawn on East 149th Street is one of a handful of pawnshops that thrive on the fringes of the bustling Bronx shopping area known as the Hub. This holiday season, the shops are reporting long lines of people anxious for cash to buy gifts.
Yesterday, on the busy streets of the Hub that line Third Avenue for several blocks north of 149th Street, throngs of shoppers took advantage of the mild temperatures to look for last-minute bargains in the cavernous stores with names like Mr. Discount, Save-A-Thon, Perfumania, Jimmy Jazz and Loco John.
At Conway, a discount store, customers waited at cashier lines with shopping carts full of toys. One of them, Victor Gonzalez, 33, said he had done all his shopping that day, spending $300 on gifts for his children.
"See this?" he said, holding up a doll set. "Yesterday they had it for $75. I got it today for $60."
But for some, it would take more than price cuts to make Christmas possible. They needed cash. So they lined up at local pawnshops carrying laptops, stereos, guitars and power tools. At one shop on East 149th Street, a 20-year-old student from the Bronx who gave her name only as Aisha pawned a gold chain for $30 so she could buy a gift for her 3-month-old son.
"It's an especially busy season this year," said Gerald Modell, president of the Collateral Loan Brokers Association of New York and the owner of four city pawnshops.
"The economy is down and many people have lost their jobs and need cash," he added. "People get into difficult situations and say: 'It's Christmas Eve, and I need $1,000. Where am I going to get it?' You can't go to your friends."
Mr. Modell, whose family owns the Modell's chain of sporting goods stores, called pawnshops "the poor man's bank."
Mr. Modell said there were probably fewer than 50 pawnshops left in New York City. Most charge a processing fee of $3 to $5 per transaction and a monthly interest rate of 3 percent. The pawner is typically given four or five months to reclaim the item.
Pawnshops, he added, are not just for the poor. "We service people who may not get their bonus or salary check until after Christmas," he said. "Also, you have rich people who pawn big diamonds for whatever reason. Maybe they're maxed out on their credit cards, or their taxes, or college tuitions. We don't ask why."
Blaine Messinger, who owns N.Y. Pawnbrokers on East 149th Street, said that more shoppers were pawning items for quick cash this year than in the past. "Where else can you do this?" he said. "You can't go to a bank and ask to borrow $200 for Christmas shopping."
Mr. Messinger said about 90 percent of his customers wind up redeeming their property. When jewelry is brought in for a loan, it is tested for authenticity, weighed and then appraised, according to the current daily market price. Appraisers then offer to lend the owner about 40 percent of that value.
Not everyone at the pawnshops was looking for a loan. Some, like William Marcano, 63, were looking for bargains. Yesterday afternoon, he gazed in the window of N.Y. Pawnbrokers at gyrating toy Santas. Swaying like hula dancers, the dolls flaunted shiny gold chains, bracelets and watches.
Mr. Marcano, a retired truck driver from the Bronx, looked at these items, and at the trays of gold earrings. He said he preferred buying jewelry in pawnshops because of the discounts.
He had just received his monthly Social Security check in the mail and cashed it, for $749. He planned to spend about $500 of it on jewelry for his girlfriend and gifts for his children.
"You've got to make everyone happy," he said.
But Ms. Kone's story was perhaps more typical. She had spent the morning thinking in her Bronx apartment, a block from Yankee Stadium, and decided that her four children deserved Christmas presents, even though she had no job and no money. She scooped up her gold jewelry and headed out the door.
She said that she had lost her job in April as an administrator at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Upper Manhattan and that bureaucratic problems have prevented her from getting many of her unemployment checks.
Since then, she has made four separate trips to pawn several thousand dollars' worth of gold, silver and diamonds, she said. Each time she has defaulted on the loan and lost the property to the pawnbroker.
Yesterday, she took the cash and hurried out of the shop and toward the Hub's discount stores. She stopped at Crazy Sounds, an electronics store, bought three portable CD players for $20 each.
"It's a start," she said. "You can't put a price on saving Christmas for the little ones."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Pawnshops like Citi Pawn in the Bronx, left, reported long lines yesterday. Nearby, business was also brisk in the shopping area known as the Hub, where a vendor sold toiletries. (Photographs by Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
TOY RETAILER TO CLOSE70 ZANY BRAINY STORES

BYLINE:  AP

 BODY:
 The troubled toy retailer FAO Inc. will close 70 underperforming stores by March as it attempts to return to profitability. 
The company said 55 of the stores to close would be Zany Brainy stores, which sell educational toys. FAO, which is based in King of Prussia, Pa., near Philadelphia, also owns F. A. O. Schwarz and the Right Stuff. The retailer operates 253 stores. It was not clear how many employees would be affected by the closures. FAO also said it has reached a "standstill agreement" with a syndicate of its lending banks that could postpone bankruptcy.

HEADLINE: Wine Prices Drop Sharply, A Good Reason for Cheer 

BYLINE:  By AMANDA HESSER

 BODY:
WHILE it has not been the best time to travel, invest in the stock market or indulge in truffles, there has never been a better time to buy and drink wine.
 After years of price inflation sent retail price tags of little-known wines soaring and the cost of wines by the glass well into the double digits, prices of wines have begun spiraling downward. 
 "Never in my lifetime have I seen so much great wine available at such a fair price," said Joshua Wesson, the president of Best Cellars, a wine chain. "There are great deals from just about any country that wine is made."
John McClement, the wine director at Keens Steakhouse in Manhattan, explained: "There's a glut of wine on the market, allocations aren't as hard to come by and the prices keep coming down." 
This means that the Raymond Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon, 1999, which Mr. McClement sold for $75 last year, is now $53. At Astor Wines and Spirits in Greenwich Village, the Laurent-Perrier Champagne, Grand Siecle, which was selling for $129.99 last year, has been slashed to $64.99. And at Chanterelle, in TriBeCa, the 1998 Chateau Fourcas-Hosten, which was $39 on the menu, is now $30. 
"I think a lot of people aren't admitting what's happening," Karen King, the wine director at Union Square Cafe in Manhattan, said, "because the minute you admit it, it's true."
Fluctuation in the market for wine, which is at base an agriculture product like carrots or rice, is typical. What is unusual about the current situation is that it is not simply a reflection of a shift in the economy or the weather. It is also the result of bad decisions. "All these people thought that there would be this arc upward of consumption," Mr. Wesson said of wine sales. "And although it's grown modestly in the United States, worldwide it's flat." 
During the economic boom of the late 1990's, when pricey cult wines were often as difficult to acquire as an Hermes Kelly bag, winemakers, particularly in California, bet on the future with great optimism and exuberance. In 1996, said Karen Ross, president of the California Association of Wine Grape Growers, there were 311,329 acres of wine vineyards. By 2001 the state's estimate was 570,000 acres. 
"Now," Mr. Wesson said, "a lot of producers are freaking out. They've planted all of these grapes and they don't know what to do with them."
California is being hit the hardest at the low end and high end of the market. Growers for the jug wine industry have largely overplanted, and are now watching the value of their grape crops tumble. 
Christian Miller, the director of research at Motto Kryla & Fisher, a consulting company that specializes in the wine industry, said the situation in the south Central Valley of California, where many of these grapes are grown, was so bad that growers are ripping out vineyards and replanting them with alternative crops like alfalfa and almonds or none at all, sometimes selling their land to developers. 
In the fine-wine market, there are simply too many players and not enough consumers willing to pay $100 for a bottle of wine. 
"The shakeout is going to be at the grower end first," Ms. Ross said. "It's been more than a decade since we saw major bankruptcies. People are anticipating that we're going to see that happening again."
Last month Sonoma Creek Winery, in Sonoma, Calif., filed for Chapter 11, seeking bankruptcy protection from creditors while it reorganized its finances.
Right now, many wineries have stocks of grapes packed to the rafters and their main goal is to unload the inventories before the new vintage comes in. So between now and the spring, when many vintages are released, may be a great time to buy. 
Even in some restaurants, where it never feels like you're getting a deal, you can enjoy wines that would not previously have been offered. At Keens Steakhouse, for instance, where wines by the glass are not priced higher than $9.75, the restaurant is now offering 1998 Markham Merlot Reserve for that price. A year ago, Mr. McClement said, he would have had to have charged $13 a glass.
Similarly at Restaurant Daniel in Midtown, there is a 1999 Marc Morey Chassagne-Montrachet, Les Virondots, for $23 a glass. Two years ago, Jean Luc Le Du, the restaurant's sommelier, said, he could not sell it by the glass because he would have had to charge $30. It has dropped in cost by as much as 35 to 40 percent a case. 
When California's cult wines got out of control a few years ago, many sommeliers began looking to Europe and Australia for reasonable prices. And they have continued to. Roger Dagorn, the wine director at Chanterelle, has found good buys in France. A few weeks ago, he was able to lower the price on the 2000 Olivier Leflaive St.-Auban on his menu to $50 from $60. 
Karen King, Union Square Cafe's wine director, has found great values in Spanish wines. "Portugal," she said, "forget it. There are going to be really good values over the next few years. It's going to be the next frontier."
In 2002, Ms. Ross of the Wine Grape Growers Association added, imported wines are expected to make up nearly 22 percent of the American wine market. Six years ago, they took up only around 17 percent.
Small wine retailers say they are not getting the best bargains because good wineries prefer to sell exclusively through restaurants, which are considered better marketing platforms for fine wines, or through large warehouse clubs, which can promise high volume. 
Earlier this year, for instance, the Bronco Wine Company, a wine conglomerate based in Ceres, Calif., began selling Charles Shaw's Chardonnay, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot at Trader Joe's for $1.99 a bottle. 
Jon Fredrikson, a wine industry analyst, said that the store was likely to sell a million cases in California this year. "People are going into these Trader Joe's where it's sold on an exclusive basis and buying 6 to 10 cases at a time," Mr. Fredrikson said. "That's cheaper than Pellegrino." Not quite. But close.
Jimmy Bradley, an owner of the Red Cat and the Harrison restaurants in Manhattan, is considering applying a similar tactic at the Mermaid Inn, which is opening in the East Village this February. 
He may mark up all wines just $10, he said, a radical move considering that most wines are marked up two or three times the cost. "I'm under the impression that the value in that will lead them to order more wine and come back more often," he said.
It's not that people aren't buying wine -- sales volume is up 6 percent for the first half of 2002, according to Motto Kryla & Fisher -- they are just buying differently. Chris Shipley, wine director at the "21" Club said: "I have a friend who coined the expression 'competitive spenders.' They're still out there but they've had their wings clipped a bit."
Mr. McClement added: "What might have been someone coming in and ordering a Harlan Estate at over $300 a bottle, they'll now come in and order two $90 bottles." 
Ms. King has found the same at Union Square Cafe. Wine sales are up over last year but, she pointed out, "Last Friday we put on Turley Zinfandel, Hayne Vineyard, 2000, and normally that would be selling like crazy and be gone in a week, and I just checked and we've only sold one bottle."
Many experts believe that prices on California wines will go lower. An excess of vineyards, Ms. Ross said, "starts to dampen the price for grapes, so eventually consumers will start to see more competitive pricing."
In the meantime, why not toast to a little certainty.

A Good Time To Buy

HEADLINE: The Shame of Norway 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As "A Nation That Exports Oil, Herring and Peace" (news article, Dec. 21) points out, Norway has become a very positive force in terms of promoting peace agreements between other countries. 
 However, Norway's identity as a good world neighbor continues to be tarnished by its selfish insistence on continuing to hunt whales. 
Norway resumed commercial whaling in 1993, flouting a moratorium established by the International Whaling Commission in 1986 in response to seriously dwindling whale populations. There is simply no excuse for continuing to hunt a species that faces the real possibility of extinction. 
 There is certainly no economic need for Norway's stance when, as you point out, its per capita gross domestic product is among the highest in the world. 
Here's hoping that Norway will come to see the error of its ways regarding whale hunting.

BRIAN J. MERRICK
Somerville, Mass., Dec. 23, 2002

HEADLINE: Arts Advocacy Group Ponders Its Good Fortune 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN KINZER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 

 BODY:
A low-profile arts advocacy group is pondering the delightful question of what to do with a sudden windfall of $120 million.
 Americans for the Arts, which helps local arts councils lobby for money and support, received the money in November from the philanthropist Ruth Lilly. Ms. Lilly also made a comparable gift to Poetry magazine. 
 "I have to think that with these additional resources, we can make a monumental difference," said Robert L. Lynch, the arts group's president. 
In recent weeks Mr. Lynch has sent 3,000 questionnaires to members and supporters asking what they think the group should do with its new treasure. In January it will hold a series of focus groups and individual interviews with arts administrators, public officials and donors. Then in February board members will go on a retreat to discuss their suddenly brightened prospects.
Mr. Lynch said that he expected to introduce a new agenda for the group at its next annual meeting, scheduled for June in Portland, Ore.
About 800 questionnaires have already been returned, and Mr. Lynch said most ask the group to do more of what it has already done.
Ms. Lilly's donation will arrive in several streams, including lump sum payments and long-term income over the next 30 years. Mr. Lynch said that almost all of it will be placed in an endowment, from which the organization will draw interest of $6 million to $7 million each year. That will nearly double its present budget.
"Our goal is access to the arts for all Americans, the opportunity for every American to connect with the arts," he said. "The way we hope to achieve that is by putting facts and information in the hands of decision-makers."
Americans for the Arts has a lobbyist on its staff in Washington. It also trains arts advocates around the country, gives them the tools they need to press their case and prepares public relations campaigns to support their efforts. Most of its financing comes from arts councils that pay dues, from foundations and private donors and from the proceeds of conferences and book sales. 
Last year Americans for the Arts issued a report called "Arts and Economic Prosperity," which surveyed the impact that arts and cultural programs can have in dealing with challenges ranging from neighborhood decay to juvenile crime. Mr. Lynch said its member groups, most of which are local arts councils, found the report highly useful.
"They can use as much data and facts as we can give them to help them explain the value of arts and arts education," he said. "We're talking about hard numbers that relate to the economic and practical effect of cultural districts, cultural tourism and arts education. When we talk to mayors, they're interested first of all in jobs and the economy, and then in things like education, crime, health, social problems and infrastructure. Our job is to show them how spending money on the arts can help them deal with those challenges in a very practical way."
That is not an easy sell. Many public officials view cultural programs as a frill, and cut them when budgets are tight. This year, for example, the Massachusetts Cultural Council's budget was cut by 62 percent and the California Arts Council's was cut by 41 percent.
As part of its effort to promote local arts initiatives, Americans for the Arts holds an annual banquet at which it honors public officials who have used culture-related projects to help revitalize communities. Recent recipients have included Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, Mayor Wellington E. Webb of Denver, Gov. John Engler of Michigan and Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut.
Mr. Lynch said the questionnaires he has reviewed so far express not only a desire for more information about the impact of arts programs, but also better training in lobbying techniques and more public-service advertising in support of the arts.
Ms. Lilly's donation, like the one to Poetry magazine, is designed in complex ways that have taken lawyers and other experts several weeks to decipher. Some of the money is in stocks and trusts that must be converted to cash, and it is to be disbursed according to a complicated timetable.
In a statement issued on Dec. 17, the arts group said it expected the donation to total more than $120 million. That will make it somewhat smaller than the one to Poetry, which the magazine's editor, Joseph Parisi, said could ultimately reach or exceed $150 million.
"It's the first time I can think of that a grant like this has been made to what we call an arts service organization, rather than to something like a museum or a performing arts center," said Janet Langsam, executive director of the Westchester Arts Council in White Plains, one of the many local councils that work with Americans for the Arts. "This is a signal that there are people in the country who really do care about seeing to it that there is a national arts presence and that we have the funds to advocate for it."
Ms. Lilly, who is 87 and infirm, is an heir to the Eli Lilly pharmaceutical fortune. Although she had made several donations to Americans for the Arts before, none were especially large. She has, however, made substantial contributions to cultural institutions in Indianapolis, her hometown, and evidently wanted to do the same on a nationwide basis.
Ms. Lilly's donation caps a period of astonishing growth in the number of local arts councils, which distribute funds to performing and visual artists and arts organizations in individual communities. Mr. Lynch said the first were founded in 1949 in three American towns -- Quincy, Ill., Winston-Salem, N. C. and Canon City, Colo. -- where people decided they wanted to bring culture to their communities instead of traveling to big cities to experience it. Now there are more than 4,000 such councils. Their members were instrumental in creating the National Endowment for the Arts in 1965 and in blocking several Congressional efforts to abolish it.
There has been a similar growth in the number of nonprofit arts groups, which range from some involved in political advocacy to others with special missions like presenting theatrical performances or arranging partnerships between museums and public schools. Mr. Lynch estimated that there were 7,000 such groups in the United States in 1965 and that there are 50,000 today.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert L. Lynch, president of Americans for the Arts. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)(pg. E5)

HEADLINE: China Airlines Confirms Plane Purchases 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
China Airlines, the government-controlled carrier of Taiwan, confirmed today that it had concluded large contracts to buy jets from both Airbus and Boeing, but said the financial weakness of other airlines had allowed it to secure deep discounts.
 China Airlines agreed to buy 10 long-range Boeing 747-400's and 12 medium-range Airbus A330-300's, with options to acquire 6 more of the Airbus A330's, the company said, confirming figures that it had released in October. At list price, the Boeings would be worth $2 billion and the smaller Airbus planes would be worth $1.7 billion, or $2.5 billion if the options are exercised. 
 But Roger Han, a spokesman for China Airlines, said that his company would actually pay considerably less, having bargained aggressively at a time when many other airlines are in financial difficulty and deferring or canceling orders for new aircraft. 
"Our transaction price is much, much lower than the list price," Mr. Han said, declining to be more specific. "There were some big discounts because right now the market competition favors airlines."
Part of the discount for China Airlines, Mr. Han said, lay in promises by Airbus and Boeing to help the airline dispose of many of its current Airbus and Boeing jets as they are replaced by the new planes.
It is rare for the participants in aircraft deals to talk publicly about the terms. Indeed, Airbus and Boeing have policies against doing so and said nothing about the details of today's transaction. But the China Airlines deal comes after considerable wrangling, political as well as commercial, and China Airlines has had to fight suspicions in Taiwan in particular that it is overpaying for the Boeing jets to help preserve Taiwan's military alliance with the United States.
China Airlines came close last summer to buying exclusively Airbus jets, after Boeing quoted prices that the airline regarded as uncompetitive. That provoked strenuous lobbying by the Bush administration and by members of Congress, especially from Washington state.
Boeing still builds many of its commercial airliners in the state, but has been struggling for new orders to keep its factories full because of the combination of the global economic slowdown and the attacks of Sept. 11, which have depressed air travel in many markets and left some airlines with little need for more planes.
American officials reminded Taiwan of the island's continued dependence on military protection from the United States against any possible attack by China, and Taiwan's reliance on purchasing weapons from the United States at a time when many other countries refuse to do business with it for fear of offending Beijing.
The lobbying was controversial in Taiwan, where several years of economic stagnation have produced a focus on economic issues over traditional security concerns. Many Taiwanese now view closer economic relations with the mainland as the best way to regain prosperity on their island, and this has made them somewhat less enthusiastic about close ties to the United States.
Boeing also noted in its sales effort that the 747-400 had a slightly longer range with a full cargo than its long-haul rival, the Airbus A340. Range and cargo capacity were important because one of China Airlines' biggest markets is in carrying the flood of computer chips and other products from Taiwan's high-tech industries to American cities that are 13 to 15 hours away by air.
Boeing welcomed the sale of the 747-400's, saying today in a statement that it was the largest deal this year for the intercontinental model. Mr. Han said that three of the jets would be freighters and were scheduled for delivery next year. Six passenger versions of the huge airplane are to be delivered from 2004 to 2006, along with a fourth cargo jet.
But today's deal appeared to offer no immediate benefit for Boeing investors, as the company said that it had earlier begun counting the 747-400's in its inventory of orders. The planes for China Airlines had previously been labeled as going to an unidentified customer, Boeing said.

HEADLINE: Japan Has No Shortage of Advice on Banks' Woes 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
Japanese policy makers have never been at a loss for ideas on how to clean up the nation's debt-laden banks. College professors, bank analysts and authors are forever offering opinions in newspapers and on television.
 But in recent months, several international agencies have also raised loud alarm bells. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, for instance, recently said Japan's banks needed more taxpayer money to survive. 
 Add the International Monetary Fund to the list. The fund is in the middle of a yearlong inspection of Japan's banks that some hope will shed light on the problem of bad loans here. Sayuri Shirai, a former I.M.F. economist with connections to her old employer, said the report, scheduled for next summer, would prove that several banks do not meet international capital standards.
After years of frightening warnings, though, the question is what impact these findings may have. Lawmakers and, to a large degree, the public have become so hardened to predictions of the financial system's demise that they tune out much of the advice, including some helpful ideas.
Complicating matters, the suggestions are often hurled by foreigners who are suspected of having ulterior motives. American bankers are often portrayed in the local media as vultures who swoop down on embattled Japanese companies, buy assets on the cheap and put Japanese employees out of work. Politicians stumping for votes routinely accuse Westerners and their Japanese sympathizers of financial imperialism.
More often than not, then, foreign advice, however useful, ends up fueling existing prejudices. The I.M.F. report may bolster reformers like Heizo Takenaka, Japan's financial czar whose plan to clean up the banking system has been diluted. Yet conservative lawmakers eager to maintain the status quo also may use the report to scare voters into opposing any radical reforms.
"The reaction goes both ways," said Michael Petit, the chief criteria officer at Standard & Poor's in Tokyo whose own credit reports have been volleyed around for political purposes. "Takenaka may try to use the international support, but the forces inside the government are ultimately the ones who say what gets decided."
As a practical matter, the I.M.F. report will have no binding impact. Unlike Russia, Argentina or Brazil, Japan has no foreign debts or loans from the fund. The country runs a huge trade surplus and has more than $400 billion in foreign currency reserves, so it can defend itself ably from speculators. Japan is also a leading contributor to the I.M.F.
But unlike reports by other international agencies and private banks, the I.M.F. report will be done in conjunction with Japan's Financial Services Agency in one part of the report. The two sides will compile a "stress test" that will simulate various models, including the impact on the banks of a stock market crash. The participation of government regulators will make it hard for policy makers to deny all the report's findings.
"Of course, people might say it is just the I.M.F. talking," said Ms. Shirai, who now teaches at Keio University and has recently written a book, "Megabank Crises and I.M.F. Economic Policy."
"Some politicians will oppose the report, but they can't complain because it has been approved by the government," she said.

HEADLINE: India Is Regaining Contracts With U.S. 

BYLINE:  By SARITHA RAI

DATELINE: BANGALORE, Dec. 24 

 BODY:
After slowing in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, outsourcing by American companies to Indian concerns or to their own Indian units has begun to pick up.
 The new contracts span the technology-related spectrum, going well beyond the software code writing of the last decade to include chip design, product development, call centers, consulting and other support services. They give Indian companies the opportunity to expand their repertory with work that holds much promise for future growth. And they account for a significant chunk of business in India, especially here in Bangalore and the country's other high-technology cities. 
 In just the last few months, dozens of Indian concerns have garnered contracts from big American companies to take over pieces of their operations. A unit of the Bangalore-based Wipro, India's third-largest software and services exporter, will be handling some of the worldwide reservation services for Delta Air Lines, a move that Delta expects will save $12 million to $15 million annually. 
India's top software company, Tata Consultancy Services, or T.C.S., part of India's Tata conglomerate, has signed up Lehman Brothers -- in a $70 million-a-year deal shared with Wipro -- as well as J. P. Morgan Chase, Fidelity Investments and GE Medical Systems. The local unit of Cognizant Technology Solutions, a custom software developer and services provider in Teaneck, N.J., has contracts for projects from MetLife, to upgrade its human resources administration system and streamline some computer applications, and from the UnitedHealth Group and Sallie Mae, the student loan provider.
For the American companies, which account for more than two-thirds of the work coming to India, the country has several advantages. Though wages in India have been rising, they still tend to be much lower than in the United States. That is particularly attractive in the current global economy, cost-sensitive executives say, as they follow the outsourcing path set in the early 1990's by technology companies from Silicon Valley seeking cheaper software coding operations.
India also has a large, well-educated, English-speaking work force with one of the world's largest clusters of engineers and programmers.
Even Bill Gates, the Microsoft chairman who is widely revered here, has given his imprimatur. "A couple of years ago, the biggest American corporations would have considered it risky to outsource mission-critical work to India, but it is now becoming a common-sense proposition," Mr. Gates said on a visit to Bangalore last month.
Microsoft is expanding its development center in the high-tech city of Hyderabad and is outsourcing some back office work to Wipro.
The software and back-office services outsourcing is one of India's fastest-growing businesses. In the year ended March 31, it accounted for nearly 3 percent of India's gross domestic product, up from 0.3 percent three years earlier, and is expected to increase to 7 percent in 2008. It has also contributed substantially to the country's healthy state of foreign exchange reserves in recent years.
According to Gartner Inc., a research firm based in Stamford, Conn., India is leading the world in offshore outsourcing services, with annual revenue of $8 billion, and outsourced projects from American companies to Indian concerns will become increasingly common.
Gartner has, however, warned that American companies that rush into outsourcing deals with Indian companies solely to cut costs are usually soon in trouble and that India's competitive edge over places like China could vanish if India does not continue to upgrade the infrastructure and stay on top of quality control.
India's three top software exporters -- Wipro, T.C.S. and Infosys Technologies -- said that with the post-Sept. 11 lull ended, they are busy fending off Irish, Philippine and other competitors. But they think they have the global edge.
"No country is able to offer the cost-to-quality advantage and scaling up opportunities that India does," said N. G. Subramaniam, T.C.S.'s vice president. Companies that start with a few dozen people in a pilot project could increase to thousands in a matter of months, he said.
Many also have been working toward becoming one-stop shops. "Early Indian services companies typically gained backdoor entry as code cutters but moved up the value chain to take on strategic parts of the client's business," said Vivek Paul, vice chairman of Wipro. For instance, he said, his company's first task for Home Depot was to maintain applications, but Wipro moved up by writing software to run computerized tasks and maintaining it in all Home Depot outlets.
As the scope of work farmed out to India has broadened, so has the spectrum of American companies doing the outsourcing. Companies in the credit card, insurance and financial services industries were among the first, in the early 1990's, but new converts include even some older, highly regulated industries like utilities.
Back-office and information technology service operations, like processing employee payrolls or fielding phone calls from customers, are now moving to India at an even brisker pace than outsourced software projects. Acknowledging the influx, the National Association of Software and Services Companies, the industry trade group known as Nasscom, has raised its projections for the country's back-office services industry to $21 billion, from $17 billion, by 2008.
Software companies like Wipro and Satyam Computer Services, meanwhile, are taking on the big consulting firms for large-scale consulting deals.
The mostly back-office and services jobs have been flooding across India, beyond the high-tech hot spots and into big cities like Delhi and Bombay, even as American companies continue to announce layoffs. That has spurred some criticism in the United States. Recently, when New Jersey state senator Shirley K. Turner discovered that a welfare and food stamp contractor had moved its customer service center to Bombay from Wisconsin, she sponsored a bill to require that workers on state contracts be American citizens, or legal aliens, or have some specialty for which such workers cannot be found. The bill was approved this month and forwarded to the state Assembly.
Back in India, outsourcing companies have been busy recruiting. One, ICICI oneSource, a Bangalore-based back-office concern owned by the Indian financial services giant ICICI Group, has attracted thousands of young "customer jockey" hopefuls for its call center with ads in the local newspapers saying "The C.J. Hunt is on!"
Such jobs are changing the lives of the thousands of young, urban men and women who fill the positions, toiling largely at night, synchronizing their work schedules with Americans halfway across the globe.
Saranya Sukumaran, 21, who is just out of college and three months into her first job, takes home 10,000 rupees, or just over $200, a month from her job on the help desk at the local unit of an American Internet service provider in a country where nearly half the population survives on less than $1 a day. From 10:30 p.m. to 7:30 a.m. five days a week, and calling herself Sharon "no last name," she responds to calls that have been routed to Bangalore. The money enables her to help her father, a junior official with the state-owned phone company who earns 15,000 rupees a month, support the household.
It also allows her to grab a $1 coffee at the hip cafes dotting Bangalore and splurge on luxuries like Levi's jeans and a Nokia cellphone.
"As a teenager I wished for so many things," she said. "Now I'm my own Santa Claus."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Young people, mostly recent college graduates, wait to be interviewed for "customer-jockey" jobs at a call center in Bangalore, India, that works for both American and British companies. (Namas Bhojani for The New York Times)
